proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The AAV7A1 Product Improvement Program (PIP) is comprised of the Assault Amphibious Vehicle (AAV) Modifications Line and, previously, the AAV Survivability Upgrade (AAV SU) program.
The AAV Modifications Line includes life-cycle support to ensure cost-effective combat readiness for the AAV Family of Vehicles (FOV). This is accomplished through continuous review of sub-systems to maintain system supportability, safety, procurement of replacement systems for obsolescence, and fielding of Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) for capability-based improvements of fleet assets, reduced total ownership cost initiatives, and improved AAV sustainment initiatives. The AAV Modifications Line procures modernized components and subsystems that impact safe and reliable use of AAV such as Intercom Modernization, Tactical Communication Modernization (TCM), technical refresh of servers and laptops for Command-variant (C-Variant), and associated support for the AAV FOV. These modifications support the extension of the AAV life cycle until 2030.
The AAV SU was a capability-based upgrade program centered on material upgrades in survivability and force protection while maintaining the required land and water mobility performance. The United States Marine Corps (USMC) decided to terminate the AAV SU program in order to better align to the National Defense Strategy; the remaining AAV SU funding will be utilized for program cancellation, which is expected to take between 12-24 months to complete.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $96.836M ($96.514M Active; $0.322M Reserve). The AAV program procured fleet-wide Vehicle Modifications including Emergency Egress Lighting System (EELS) Power Units and spares, Recovery-variant corrosion improvements, Intercom Modernization procurements and Remote Weapon Stations (RWS) for Personnel-variants, continued hardware/software technical refresh and Cybersecurity for the Command-variants; plus related Engineering Change Orders (ECO), Integrated Logistics Support (ILS), Production Engineering Support, Support Equipment, and Technical Publications for the AAV family of vehicles. The FY 2020 enactment includes congressional rescission of $74.756M to FY 2019 funding.
FY 2020: $39.495M ($39.166M Active; $0.329M Reserve). The AAV program procures fleet-wide Vehicle Modifications including initial procurement of Assured Position Navigation and Timing (APNT) systems, continues procurement of Remote Weapon Stations (RWS), and continues hardware/software technical refresh for the Command-variants; plus related Engineering Change Orders (ECO), Integrated Logistics Support (ILS), Production Engineering Support, Support Equipment, and Technical Publications for the AAV family of vehicles. The APNT system provides the AAV driver during the ship-to-shore maneuvers the ability to navigate a preplanned course while coming ashore and to stay within a lane that has been cleared of naval mines and other obstacles. The RWS allows on-the-move target acquisition and first-burst target engagement. It supports the MK-19 grenade launcher and M2 .50 cal machine gun. The RWS replaces the current obsolescent Up Gun Weapon System that is a leading deadlining subsystem on the AAV. The hardware/software technical refresh for the Command-variants have software releases quarterly each year to maintain the vehicles security certification. The net decrease of $57.341 between FY 2019 and FY 2020 is due to the combination of 1) the cancellation of the AAV Survivability Upgrade and associated termination costs in FY 2019 and 2) the increase in support for vehicle modification to replace obsolete vehicle radios for the AAV Family of Vehicles.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $87.476M ($87.142M Active; $0.334M Reserve). The AAV program will procure fleet-wide Vehicle Modifications including Tactical Communication Modernization, APNT, Remote Weapon Stations (RWS), and will continue hardware/software technical refresh for the Command-variants; plus related Engineering Change Orders (ECO), Integrated Logistics Support (ILS), Production Engineering Support, Support Equipment, and Technical Publications for the AAV family of vehicles. The TCM replaces the current fielded radios. The radios will be obsolete by 2024 due to the NSA cryptographic modernization mandate and will be unable to communicate with other units. The net increase of $47.981M between FY 2020 and FY 2021 is due to the initial procurement of TCM as the replacement for obsolete radios in the AAV Family of Vehicles and the continued procurement of Remote Weapons Stations.
OCO: FY 2021 OCO Appropriation Request: N/A

proc:Name.footnote: The increase in vehicle modifications from FY2020 to FY2021 ($48.098M) is attributed to initial procurement of Tactical Communication Modernization (TCM) to replace obsolete vehicle radios for the AAV Family of Vehicles and continued procurement of Remote Weapons Stations. This strategy reflects the Marine Corps' commitment to maintain capability and ensuring the vehicle is able to participate in conducting the assigned missions until replaced by the Amphibious Combat Vehicles (ACVs).

The USMC decided to cancel the AAV Survivability Upgrade (AAV SU) program in order to better align to the National Defense Strategy; the remaining funding will be utilized for program cancellation, which is expected to take between 12-24 months to complete. The FY 2020 enactment includes congressional rescission of $74.756M to FY 2019 funding.

The decrease in Peculiar Training Equipment and Simulators between FY2020 and FY2021 ($0.377) is attributed to the purchase of Computer Based Training (CBT) (WIN 10 Operating System Updates) and Command-variant Software WIN 10 Training Upgrades in FY2020. Operating system updates and associated training are provided approximately every three to four years.
The reduction in Production Engineering Support from FY2020 to FY2021 ($0.320) is attributed a decrease in the program office support requirement.
The increase in Support Equipment from FY2020 to FY2021 ($0.525) is attributed to the replacement of obsolescent parts on the Recovery vehicle; tools are required to maintain the changes.

proc:LineItem.proc:LineItemTitle: Amphibious Combat Vehicle Family of Vehicles
proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Amphibious Combat Vehicle (ACV) will replace the legacy Assault Amphibious Vehicle (AAV) in the Assault Amphibious (AA) battalions within the Marine Divisions. ACV-equipped AA companies will provide protected mobility and general support lift to elements of Marine Infantry battalions. The ACV, an advanced generation, eight-wheeled armored personnel carrier, will mitigate current and projected capability gaps by providing improved lethality against dismounted enemy troops, more effective land and water tactical mobility, and increased force protection and survivability from blasts, fragmentation, and kinetic energy threats.
In an Acquisition Decision Memorandum (ADM) dated 8 Jan 2019, ASN(RD&A), the Milestone Decision Authority, combined the ACV 1.1 and ACV 1.2 programs into a single ACV Family of Vehicles (FOV) that continues the established phased development and procurement approach. This approach allows the Marine Corps to procure a modernized assault amphibian to serve as the platform to perform missions across the range of military operations to include joint forcible entry operations.
The initial ACV Increment (FY2018 - FY2021) Personnel variant will deliver combat ready Marines from ship-to-shore in order to mass forces at littoral penetration points and continue to maneuver onward to inland objectives. Subsequent procurements (FY2022 - FY2025) are planned to expand the personnel carrier quantities and to procure command and control, improved lethality, and tactical recovery capabilities. In an ADM dated 12 July 2019, ASN(RD&A) authorized a third lot of LRIP consisting of 56 vehicles and directed that acquisition documentation reflecting this change shall be updated as part of the Full Rate Production (FRP) Milestone decision approval process. The first lot of full rate production will be procured in FY 2021. The merger and additional lot of LRIP are updates from the FY 2020 acquisition strategy.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $166.522M Funds used to procure Lot 2 (LRIP) of 30 vehicles, plus procurement of related items such as production support, systems engineering/program management, Engineering Change Orders (ECOs), Government Furnished Equipment (GFE), and integrated logistics support.
FY 2020: $300.935M Funds procure Lot 3 (LRIP) of 56 vehicles, plus procurement of related items such as production support, systems engineering/program management, Engineering Change Orders (ECOs), Government Furnished Equipment (GFE), and integrated logistics support.
FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation Request: $478.874M Funds will procure Lot 4, first Full Rate Production (FRP) lot of 72 vehicles, plus procurement of related items such as production support, systems engineering/program management, Engineering Change Orders (ECOs), Government Furnished Equipment (GFE), and integrated logistics support. Net increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $177.939M primarily due to the procurement and support of 16 additional vehicles in FY2021 and prime contactor foreign currency exchange costs and royalties to suppliers per the terms and conditions of the negotiated contract.
Production was adjusted in FY 2021 from 92 vehicles to 72 vehicles to allow for a more gradual production ramp and to pay for increased costs of design labor for Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), production and installation of ECPs, vehicle refurbishment following IOT&E, and increased logistics and support costs.

proc:Name.footnote: This element of cost includes the competitively-derived and pre-negotiated Surface Vehicle cost. The increase in cost between FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $56.654 is primarily attributed to the increase in FY 2021 for an additional sixteen (16) vehicles to continue the production ramp-up to Full Rate Production. Lots 1-4 (FY 2018 - FY 2021) procure ACV-P variants only. The increase in unit cost of $53K per vehicle is within OSD FY 2021 inflation indices, and is based on the negotiated and awarded production contract with the prime vendor.

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: FY20 award of 56 vehicles will occur via two actions due to the continuing resolution quantity restrictions. The first vehicle award (qty 30) occurred Nov 19.

proc:Name.footnote: GFE Communication Suites procurement includes tactical radios (2 AN/VRC-114V2 systems comprised of 4 PRC-117G radios and 4 antennas for each vehicle), Battlefield Command & Control Situational Awareness (currently via the Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P)), and satellite communications (via the Mobile User Objective System (MUOS) Diplexer). The increase in Communications Suites between FY2020 and FY2021 of $5.102 is attributed to the increase of sixteen (16) vehicles in FY2021.

GFE Remote Weapons Station (RWS) procurement includes the Mk-153 Common Remotely Operated Weapon Station, which consists of a single-mount weapons station and weapon (either an M2 0.50cal heavy machine gun or a Mk-19 40mm automatic grenade launcher), Main Processing Unit (MPU), Display and Control Panel (DCP), Control Grip, Laser Range Finder (LRF), Thermal camera system (TIM), Day camera system (VIM), Sight Servo Assembly (SSA) system, and Main Frame Assembly (MFA). The increase in RWS between FY2020 and FY2021 of $19.106 is attributed to the change in the acquisition strategy for RWS. Prior to FY2021, the program acquired existing RWS systems from the Army and refurbished these systems with parts and components in order to bring them to a configuration suitable for ACV. For FY2021 and beyond, the program is procuring new RWS systems because no additional RWS systems remain from the Army.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 1.1.3) Government Furnished Equipment - Remote Weapons Station

proc:Name.footnote: Systems Engineering/Program Management (SE/PM) is a recurring charge from the Prime Contractor. Recurring systems engineering includes the costs of maintainability/reliability engineering, maintenance engineering, value engineering, production engineering costs associated with the system, periodic system design/evaluation, and analysis of test results during production. Recurring program management includes the overall planning, direction, and control of the definition, development, and production of the system/program, including the functions of business management. Net increase between FY2020 to FY2021 of $1.951 primarily based on the contract cost in accordance with the awarded fixed price incentive contract. All terms were competitively-derived, negotiated, and accepted by the Government.

The increase in vehicle modifications between FY2020 and FY2021 of $15.000 is attributed to initiation of the refurbishment of twenty-six (26) LRIP Lot 1 vehicles which were utilized during conduct of Initial Operational Test & Evaluation (IOT&E). These vehicles must be reconditioned prior to fielding to operational units following the completion of IOT&E.

Engineering Change Orders (ECOs) address fact of life changes to vehicle configuration such as performance, safety, or reliability. The increase in ECO between FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $15.269 is attributed to anticipated ECOs resulting from the ACV Logistics Demonstration for Conditioned-based Maintenance, maintenance access panels and test ports, fuel/hydraulic/water/bilge line markings, and captive fasteners. The purpose and intent of the Logistics Demonstration was to evaluate the supportability of the materiel design, determine adequacy of maintenance planning, evaluate Technical Publications content (Operator, Operator Maintenance, and Organizational Maintenance Tasks), evaluate suitability and availability of maintenance training devices, evaluate suitability and availability of Test Measurement and Diagnostic Equipment (TMDE), evaluate Maintenance Allocation Chart (MAC) content, and evaluate adequacy of the Repair Parts and Special Tools List (RPSTL). Changes resulting to the vehicle from the Logistics Demonstration make the system more supportable.

The increase in Nonrecurring Engineering and Industrial Tooling between FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $4.261 reflects procurement of additional production tooling to facilitate an increase in production throughput and a nonrecurring charge to support process development for standard depot-level maintenance.
The increase in Production Support from FY2020 to FY2021 of $2.228 is attributed to program office support requirements transitioning from development to the procurement appropriation.

Acceptance Testing provides effort/materials associated with tests that are conducted to determine if the requirements and the specifications of the vehicle and/or contract are met. It is funded in the fiscal year in which the item is procured as part of the full funding policy. The increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $0.437 is based on the contract cost in accordance with the awarded fixed price incentive contract. All terms were competitively-derived, negotiated, and accepted by the Government.

Peculiar Training Equipment and Simulators represents the procurement of operator and maintenance trainers essential to conducting training prior to system fielding. The increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $5.565 is attributed to procurement of Operator and Maintainer training devices and Command-variant communication training systems in FY2021.

The increase in Pubs and Tech Data between FY2020 and FY2021 of $4.551 is attributed to procurement of updates to technical manuals, and procurement of the technical data package from the prime contractor per the terms and conditions of the contract.

Support equipment are devices required to inspect, test, service, adjust, calibrate, measure, repair, overhaul, assemble, disassemble, handle, store, or otherwise support the lifecycle management of the ACV. The increase from FY2020 to FY2021 of $1.741 is due to the procurement of shipping containers for the Remote Weapon Stations.

ILS includes Logistics Management Information (LMI) procurement and platform support products necessary for the planning and preparation to support the fielded system until organic support capability is established. This effort will enable a journeyman level repair technician(s) to disassemble, clean, inspect, overhaul/rebuild, repair/refurbish, reassemble and test, at a Government Depot, all secondary repairables identified by the Contractor during its Supportability Analyses and Level of Repair Analyses and documented in the LMI data tracking system. The cost is based on the contract cost in accordance with the awarded fixed price incentive contract. All terms were negotiated and accepted by the Government. The increase between FY2020 and FY2021 of $46.074 is primarily attributed to award of prime contractor total package fielding effort, and prime contractor foreign currency exchange costs and royalties to suppliers negotiated under the terms and conditions of the prime contract. The first four lots of ACV production were negotiated and priced under these foreign exchange and royalty terms, which were determined to be a fair and reasonable pricing mechanism to allow the prime contractor to establish firm pricing option on the first four lots of production (FY18-FY21). This pricing mechanism was reviewed and vetted by the MDA and NCCA at Milestone C and was implemented to protect the government from annual foreign currency fluctuations. BAE is the prime contractor and IVECO Defense is the main supplier.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The LAV Modification & Sustainment Program funds important vehicle modifications, support equipment and tools and other projects that increase LAV reliability and readiness while simultaneously reducing operations and support costs. The LAV Modification and Sustainment Team is a multi-disciplinary integrated project team that employs subject matter experts in engineering, logistics, contracting and financial management to manage modification projects.
The LAV Reset Program will address the Family of Light Armored Vehicles (FOLAV) automotive system obsolescence and reduced performance due to increased Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW). The Reset Program will improve fleet reliability and availability by addressing the three sub-systems (power pack, driveline, and steering) that specifically account for 95 percent of total system downtime. The program also fields a modern driver's instrument panel and LAV-25 Slip Ring. The LAV Reset Program is an ACAT IV(M) program.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $36.652M LAV Reset: $36.652M funded the procurement and fielding of 60 Reset kits and supporting efforts such as logistics support, special tools & support equipment for depots, and required government and contractor support.
FY 2020: $60.734M LAV Reset: $51.686M funds the procurement and fielding of 60 Reset kits and supporting efforts such as all required logistics support, special tools and support equipment required for fielding, Engineering, Manufacturing and Development (EMD) vehicle refurbishment, refurbish STRYKER differentials, instructor and key personnel new equipment training and required government and contractor support.
LAV Modification and Sustainment (MOD): $9.048M funds the procurement and fielding of 237 new intercom systems that resolve current operational deficiencies and will interface with the USMC tactical communication modernization (TCM) compliant radios. The TCM requirement is mandated by the National Security Administration (NSA) and must be achieved by 2024.
FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation: $41.988M
LAV Reset: Funding in this program has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
LAV Modification and Sustainment (MOD): $41.988M will fund the procurement and fielding of 441 new intercom systems, 167 tactical communication modernization (TCM) radios that resolve current operational deficiencies and will interface with the USMC (TCM) compliant radios, and 60 Electrical System Modification (ESM) kits. The TCM requirement is mandated by the National Security Administration (NSA) and must be achieved by 2024. The $32.940M increase between FY20 and FY21 is due to the increased procurement of 441 replacement intercom systems and associated engineering support. The FY21 request also includes the first procurement of 167 Tactical Communication Modernization radios (TCM), 60 Electrical System Modernization (ESM) kits and associated engineering support.

proc:Name.footnote: Funding in FY21 for LAV Reset has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: The increase between initial and reorder lead times increases from FY19 to FY20 to preserve the delivery schedule. The maintenance depot cannot induct FY20-funded kits until the FY19 deliveries are complete.

proc:ProcQuantity.footnote: The increase between initial and reorder lead times between FY19 to FY20 is required to preserve the delivery schedule. The maintenance depot cannot induct FY20-funded kits until the FY19 deliveries are complete.

proc:Name.footnote: FY21 increase of $0.628 is for production verification test of intercom kits procured in FY20.
FY21 $0.704M increase is for engineering support (Cost Element 4.2) that directly supports a new effort (procurement of an electrical system modernization kit).

FY21 unit cost increase is due to the LAV-C2 (command and control) and LAV-M (mortar) variants being procured which have a more complex intercom and a higher unit cost than FY20 buy of LAV-25, LAV-L (Logistics), LAV-R (Recovery) and LAV-AT (Anti-Tank).

FY21 increase of $18.591M is related to unit price increases due to variant mix and complexity of radio units required in those variants. For example, the LAV-C2 (command and control) variant requires more radios. Tactical Communication Modernization (TCM) radios will be compliant to National Security Administration (NSA) requirements by 2024.

FY21 increase of $2.367M is due to 1st year procurement of 60 ESM-Electrical System Modernization (Alternator/Distributor and slip ring for LAV-25's). Unit prices fluctuate because the LAV-25 requires a slip ring which is not required in the other variants.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: LW155 (also known as the M777A2 howitzer) provides all weather, day/night direct, reinforcing, and general support fires to maneuver forces as well as direct support artillery. It is a joint program between the Marine Corps and Army, which is additionally supporting various foreign military purchases of the weapon system. The LW155 was first fielded by the Marine Corps in April 2005 and completed fielding in April 2013. The Army has fielded the system to its Stryker Brigades and Fires Brigades and completed fielding to its Infantry Brigades in September 2018. The LW155 is being significantly utilized in the Middle East in support of Operation Inherent Resolve. This budget line supports system updates to maintain and increase performance and lethality. M777A2 is the prominent weapon of the Marine indirect fires triad and currently the only cannon in the Service. Modernization efforts to include extended range will keep the M777 relevant to the concept of operations (distributed units operating with increased dispersion) envisioned in the Marine Operating Concept.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $24.858M ($24.852M Active; $0.006M Reserve)
FY 2019 funding continued the installation of modification kits; such as the Improved Power Conditioning Control Module (I-PCCM), Mission Computer (MSC-R), and Chief of Section Display (CSD-R) ($.401M). Additionally, funding supported the procurement of Chrome Cannon tubes ($3.710M) and Software Defined Radios, cables, and brackets ($20.747M). Software Defined Radio modification enables more secure radio communication and facilitates new encryption protocol interoperability between artillery and supported forces. The new radio will provide the ability to perform voice and data functions over the same radio which increases operational flexibility for firing units. The FY19 column of the FY20 request included additional funding for Internal Navigation Unit (INU) Recapitalization. However, the INU Recap funding was included in and approved as part of the Omnibus 2019 Reprogramming Request and, therefore, is no longer reflected on the exhibit.
FY 2020: $25.065M ($25.059M Active; $0.006M Reserve)
FY 2020 funding provides for continued procurement of components such as the final lot of chrome cannon tubes (QTY 165) that will outfit the entire USMC howitzer fleet ($24.993M). Chrome cannon tubes increase safety, accuracy, and longevity of the howitzer by eliminating propellant residue inside the cannon tubes. Propellant residue causes spiral wear, which reduces the muzzle velocity of the howitzer, and fuze malfunctions of projectiles. Reduced muzzle velocity leads to projectiles impacting short of their intended targets. FY20 funding also continues other efforts such as supporting integration and installation of previously procured hardware modification kits ($0.072M).
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $0.059M ($0.053M Active; $0.006M Reserve)
FY 2021 funding will support the retrofitting of previously procured hardware modifications such as software defined radios and chrome cannon tubes ($0.059M). The chrome cannon tubes retrofits will address safety concerns while retrofitting of the software defined radio will facilitate new encryption protocols to provide continued communication between artillery and supported forces.
Net funding decrease of $25.006 from FY20 to FY21 reflects the completion of the procurement of chrome cannon tubes for the howitzer fleet.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 1.1) Hardware/electronic obsolescence and improvement ECP Retrofits

proc:Name.footnote: FY18 & FY19 supports the fleet procurement of Software Defined Radios and associated brackets and cables. Radios will be procured using an existing Navy contract. The new Software Defined Radio will provide the ability to perform voice and data functions, which increases operational flexibility for firing, artillery unit. Deliveries are scheduled into the beginning of FY20.
Unit Cost is approximately $151K per tube. Funding from FY17-FY20 will outfit the fleet. Chrome Cannon Tubes are procured via OGA at Watervliet Arsenal in New York.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 2.2) Hardware/electronic obsolescence and improvement ECP retrofits

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This program maintains and modernizes the Marine Corps' Long Range Precision Fire (LRPF) by building a more lethal force capability for sea control and land based targets. Funding procures launchers, missiles, training equipment, and associated support to ensure mission critical readiness and capability on the battlefield in support of the National Defense Strategy (NDS) and Commandant Planning Guidance. The two primary launchers are:
1) The High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS) is a C-130 transportable, wheeled, indirect fire, rocket/missile launcher capable of firing all rockets and missiles in the current and future Multiple Launch Rocket System (MLRS) Family of Munitions (MFOM). A HIMARS system includes one launcher, two Re-Supply Systems (RSS), HIMARS Support Kit and the MFOM. The HIMARS provides Joint lethality in contested environments to the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) with 24 hour ground-based, responsive General Support/General Support Reinforcing (GS/GSR) indirect fires which accurately engage targets at long range, (60+km), with high volumes of lethal fire under all weather conditions throughout all phases of combat operations ashore, to include irregular warfare, distributed operations and anti-ship missions. HIMARS Launchers are being procured to support the reactivation of the HIMARS 5th Battalion, 10th Marines with IOC in FY21. HIMARS is also capable of firing the Reduced Range Practice Rocket (RRPR) for tactical training, classroom training and handling exercises.
2) The Remotely Operated Ground Unit Expeditionary-Fires (ROGUE-F) is the launcher vehicle for the NMESIS/GBASM system. Ground Based Anti-Ship Missile (GBASM) will procure long term and short term solutions for an Anti-Ship Missile (ASM) capability in support of the Marine Corps Expeditionary Advanced Base Operations (EABO) and the National Defense Strategy approach to build a more lethal Joint Force. The GBASM project will procure a USMC system while leveraging other Service-developed missiles to provide a ground based anti-access/area denial, anti-ship capability.
Missile procurement details are held at a higher classification.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $130.981M
HIMARS is fielded to both the Active ($127.913M) and Reserve ($3.068M) components. FY19 baseline funding supports the re-activation of 5th Battalion 10th Marine Regiment (5/10) as a HIMARS Battalion. Funding is required for the procurement of HIMARS systems and support equipment for the new battalion and an associated increase in the total munitions requirement for rockets. Support funds provide maintenance vehicles, tool kits, training pods, test equipment, modification kits (long range communications, blue force tracker), shelters, install kits, spares and initial issue provisioning in various quantities to support 5th Battalion 10th Marines fielding.
GMLRS Alternative Warhead (AW) and RRPRs are being procured, noting unit costs are dependent on total quantities procured amongst the Army, Marine Corps and Foreign Military Sales (FMS) organizations in contract award.
FY 2020: $95.686M
Beginning in FY20 the USMC is accounting for base costs and ancillary support items separately to better align with the Army's budget structure. Funding will continue the procurement of HIMARS launchers and communications equipment in support of the activation of 5/10. FY20 peculiar support equipment will include universal fire control systems (UFCS), project management administration, and production engineering for HIMARS. In addition, ancillary support items will be funded including; carrier, engineering services, system engineering, production engineering, fielding, government testing, and launcher peculiar support equipment. FY20 Peculiar Support Equipment increase accounts for the procurement of HIMARS maintenance vehicles, tool kits, training pods, test equipment, modification kits (long range communications, blue force tracker), shelters, install kits, spares and initial issue provisioning in various quantities to support 5th Battalion 10th Marines IOC in FY21.
The RRPR quantity increase in FY 2020 will support the additional annual training requirement for 5/10. RRPR unit prices are provided by the Army.
The decrease of $35.295M from FY 2019 to FY2020 is due to realignment of the Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System (GMLRS) procurement budget (both active and reserve costs) to a separate Procurement, Marine Corps budget line item: 3025 - Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System (GMLRS). All GMLRS budgetary data prior to FY 2020 will reside in LI: - 2212 Artillery Weapon System (HIMARS).
FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation Request: $174.687
Funding procures launchers, carriers, and equipment to support continued expansion of USMC launcher capacity and practice rockets. FY21 peculiar support equipment includes HIMARS Re-supply Vehicle and VHF communications suite, HIMARS launcher VHF communications suite, launcher HF On-The-Move antennas, and initial issue provisioning to support 5th Battalion 10th Marines IOC in FY21.
Missile procurement details are held at a higher classification.
OCO: FY 2021 OCO Appropriation Request: N/A

proc:Name.footnote: From FY20 to FY21, there is a unit cost decrease per launcher since the Universal Fire Control System (UFCS) is not included in the FY21 - FY23 costs. The UFCS will be provided as GFE from existing inventory. The USMC is accounting for HIMARS Launcher base costs and ancillary support items separately to better align with the Army's budget structure.
Unit Cost Increase from FY20 to FY21 accounts for price inflation.
Decrease of $15.156 from FY20-FY21 is related to the procurement of less quantities of peculiar support equipment.
Missile procurement details are held at a higher classification level.
FY21 unit cost matches the Army's Budget Exhibit estimate.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 2.1.7) M31 Guided Multiple Launch Rocket Systems

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Family of Infantry Weapons Systems (FIWS) provides for continuous monitoring, assessment of and implementation of Joint Service and USMC unique system modifications for individual and crew-served weapons. This includes efforts such as: improving weapon capability, operation, maintainability, supportability, service life, ergonomics, and safety enhancements. FIWS also supports replacement of principle end items (PEI) due to combat losses, wash-outs, and increases in units required, as well as continuing product improvement and modernization of various weapon systems and their support equipment. Gunners Protection Kit (GPK) for mounted weapons systems procurement was also funded in FIWS through FY19.
Gunners Protection Kit (GPK) supports the Tube-launched, Optically Tracked, Wire-guided (TOW) Objective Gunners Protection Kit Version 2.0 (TOGPK 2.0) which is the planned upgrade and replacement for the TOW Gunners Protection Kit (TGPK) currently in use with TOW High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle variants. TOGPK 2.0 affords the TOW gunners protection from small arms fire and Improvised Explosive Device fragmentation. TOGPK 2.0 addresses user concerns regarding limited workspace and TOW slew as well as improved operator visibility. The Reducible Height Gunners Protection Kit (RHGPK) enables Joint Light Tactical Vehicles (JLTV), Medium/Heavy Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) and Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) to be transported in the lower vehicle stowage areas of Landing Platform/Dock (LPD 17) and Landing Helicopter Dock class ships. GPK was previously funded in the Family of Infantry Weapons (FIWS) and was given its own MCPC designation beginning in FY20.
Company and Battalion Mortars provides procurement, modification, and sustainment of mortars and mortar fire control systems to enable access to immediate indirect fires in support of mounted and dismounted forces to the company and battalion level. This initiative sustains the new lightweight company and battalion mortar capability and more than 50 mortar components, incorporates component product improvements and modifications such as improved sights and aiming devices, software upgrades to the Mortar Fire Control Application (MFCA) and hardware refresh/upgrades for the Lightweight Hand-held Mortar Ballistic Computer (LHMBC) capability.
Escalation of Force - Equipment (EoF-E) funding supports type-classification, testing and procurement of new advancements and technologies to provide an increased capability over existing or outdated equipment currently or associated in the Escalation of Force-Mission Modules (EoF-MMs). EoF-MMs provide commanders with an improved ability to respond to situations with varying levels of non-lethal force by way of modular capability sets that can be tailored and scaled to fit missions down to the platoon and squad level.
Ocular Interruption (OI) is the replacement of the 'Dazzling Laser' program for the LA-9/P and the GLARE-MOUT 532P-M (Mini Green) laser. OI is a non-damaging dazzling system that will be used in Escalation of Force-Missions to provide a non-lethal, force protection capability to warn and visually suppress targeted personnel at ranges from 10 to 500 meters.
Family of Incident Response Systems (FIRS) supports Countering Weapons of Mass Destruction (CWMD) and Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear (CBRN) mission areas by providing first response protection, detection, identification, and decontamination equipment to the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) and the Chemical Biological Incident Response Force (CBIRF).
Family of Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear Systems (FCBRNS) provides CBRN protection, detection/ identification, hazard modeling and simulation, and decontamination equipment required by the general purpose force to train and operate in a CBRN environment or support Counter Weapons of Mass Destruction (CWMD) to the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF). FCBRNS allows the Marine Corps to survive, fight and sustain itself in contaminated environments, and gives pause to our enemies when planning the use of CBRN weapons.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $44.937M
Family of Infantry Weapons Systems - $29.056 supported the continuous monitoring, assessment of and implementation of Joint Service and USMC unique system modfications. This includes efforts such as: improve weapon capability, operation, maintainability, supportability, service life, ergonomics, and safety enhancements. Funds support procurement and fielding of M27 Infantry Automatic Rifles (IAR), Modular Handgun Systems (MHS), M320A1 Grenade Launchers, Tow Objective Gunner Protection Kit 2.0 (TOGPK 2.0), and M4 Carbines.
The procurement of additional M27s increases the lethality of Marine Corps' ground combat element while conducting a range of military operations. The M27 is currently used by Marine infantry units and has proven to be highly reliable, giving Marine ground forces the ability to provide firepower superiority and effective suppression as needed. The Modular Handgun System is being purchased to replace the legacy M9, M9A1, M45A1, and M007 pistols with a more affordable and efficient pistol for maintenance. The MHS also provides modularity and greater shooter ergonomics over the current models, which will allow for more accurate fire for military personnel of different sizes. Additionally, the M110 SASS PIP replaces the Compact Semi Auto Sniper System (CSASS) stated in the FY20 request. Through market research and discussion with industry, it was determined that a much better capability (specifically in range and lethality) than CSASS could be procured for a similar cost. This effort entails an engineering change proposal (ECP) to the existing M110 SASS currently in USMC inventory. The M320A1 Grenade Launcher will replace the M203 in Marine Infantry and Infantry-like units. Due to its side breach, the M320A1 will allow for the use of more capable 40mm grenades for counter-defilade, breaching and non-lethal applications. The TOGPK 2.0 increases the protection level (survivability), and increases the traverse capability (lethality) of mounted weapons systems over legacy GPKs for gunners in Marine Corps vehicles. M4 Carbines are being procured to support the Small Arms strategy of divesting the Ground Combat Element of M16A4s. Funding also supports principle end items (PEI), as well as continuing product improvement and modernization of sniper and special purpose weapons, and support equipment. Additionally funding also supports various program/acquisition support activities, such as ammunition costs related to those production verification activities.
Family of Incident Response Systems (FIRS) - $1.042M supported the annual modernization of the Unified Command Suite (UCS) and engineering, programmatic, and logistics support for the Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Tactical Triage Kit (TTK). The legacy UCS, which is CBIRF's primary command and control vehicle, would face obsolescence if scheduled modernizations of its satellite communications and land mobile radio systems were not applied in FY19.
Company and Battalion Mortars - $2.266M procured Advanced Video Borescopes providing improved mortar cannon inspection and diagnostic capability and the M224A1 60mm Mortar System Handle and Firing Mechanism (HFM) Redesign providing improved quick-reaction aiming and firing ability.
Escalation of Force Equipment (EoF-E) - $0.228M procured Escalation of Force Mission Module upgraded components such as the Improved Voice Translation Device and the dazzling laser capability.
Ocular Interruption (OI) - $12.345M procured 1,049 OI systems. These new laser dazzling systems are "non-damaging" systems used in Escalation of Force Missions to provide a non-lethal, force protection capability to warn and visually suppress targeted personnel out to 500 meters. These systems are replacing the legacy LA-9/P and GLARE-MOUT 532P-M (Mini Green) systems, which have been deemed inherently dangerous by the Navy Laser Safety Review Board. In addition, parts kits will be procured to complete the initial provisioning for these systems in accordance with the Depot Maintenance Float Activity (DMFA) support strategy.
FY 2020: $31.945M
Family of Infantry Weapons Systems - $17.022M will support the continuous monitoring, assessment of and implementation of Joint Service and USMC unique system modifications. This includes efforts such as: improve weapon capability, operation, maintainability, supportability, service life, ergonomics, and safety enhancements.
The funding decrease from FY19 to FY20 of $12.034M is due to the establishment of a separate program for the Gunners Protection Kit (GPK). Funding supports procurement of Semi-Automatic Sniper System (SASS) Product Improvement Program (PIP), M320A1 Grenade Launchers, and Small Arms Suppressors. The SASS PIP will update the M110 with enhanced shooter ergonomics, increased ballistic potential, and increased operational availability time. The engineering change proposal (ECP) will improve the sniper's ability to rapidly engage multiple, moving targets with greater range and lethality. The M320A1 Grenade Launcher will replace the M203 in Marine Corps units. Due to its side breach, the M320A1 will allow for the use of more capable 40mm grenades for counter-defilade, breaching and non-lethal applications. Suppressors will be procured in order to improve communication on the battlefield, as well as reduce detection by a threat through reduced audible and visible signatures. Suppressors will also support the effort to reduce Marines' hearing loss. Funding also supports principle end items (PEI), as well as continuing product improvement and modernization of sniper and special purpose weapons, and support equipment. Additionally, funding also supports various program/acquisition support activities, such as ammunition costs related to those production verification activities.
Gunners Protection Kit (GPK) - $11.365M procures TOW Objective Gunner Protection Kits 2.0 (TOGPK 2.0), covers, and Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP). Additional cost elements were added in FY20 to account for the IIP and covers once more accurate cost data was available. FY20 IIP includes the procurement of additional hearing protection for the gunner when employing the TOW missile. Production support cost element funds logistics, safety, and fielding travel support costs. TOGPK 2.0 provides enhanced survivability and ballistic protection to the gunner when compared to existing gunner protection kits. This requirement was funded under Family of Infantry Weapons Systems prior to FY20. Reducible Height Gunner Protection Kit (RHGPK) will begin procurement in FY21.
Company and Battalion Mortars - $3.018M supports component and assembly upgrades to the inventory of 60mm and 81mm mortar systems, mortar system inspection and maintenance equipment, and mortar fire control systems; ammunition costs related to mortar production verification activities, as required; Advanced Video Borescopes; and hardware for mortar fire control systems.
Escalation of Force Equipment (EoF-E) - $0.000M - The USMC terminated the Escalation of Force Equipment program in FY20 in order to better align with the National Defense Strategy.
Ocular Interruption (OI) - $0.000M - The procurement of Ocular Interruption units was completed in FY19.
Family of Incident Response Systems (FIRS) - $0.540M will be used to support the annual modernization of the Unified Command Suite (UCS). The legacy UCS, which is CBIRF's primary command and control vehicle, faces obsolescence if scheduled modernizations of its satellite communications and land mobile radio systems are not applied in FY20. The FY20 request for FIRS represents the UCS modernization costs only. The decrease of $.502M from FY19 to FY20 is due to engineering, programmatic, and logistics support provided for the Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Tactitical Triage Kit (TTK) in FY19 that is not a requirement in FY20.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation: $24.867M
Family of Infantry Weapons Systems - $8.075M supports procurement and fielding of the M320A1 Grenade Launcher Module (GLM), the M110 Semi-Automatic Sniper System Product Improvement Program (SASS PIP), and the Advanced Sniper Rifle (ASR). The M320A1 GLM replaces the M203A2 in Marine Corps units. Due to its side breach, the M320A1 allows for the use of advanced 40mm ammunition for counter-defilade, breaching and non-lethal applications, and also offers improved accuracy and (if using advanced ammunition) range over the legacy system. The SASS PIP will update the M110 with enhanced shooter ergonomics, increased ballistic potential, and increased operational availability time. The engineering change proposal (ECP) will improve the sniper's ability to rapidly engage multiple, moving targets with greater range and lethality. ASR will replace all current bolt-action sniper rifles in the Marine Corps. It is a multi-caliber system featuring extended range, greater lethality and a wider variety of special purpose ammunition than current systems. All of these programs are modernization efforts vital to maintaining parity with near peer competitors. This modernization effort is driven by the Close Combat Lethality Task Force and Marine Corps investments to develop a 5th Generation Fighter, and is in alignment with the National Defense Strategy. The funding also supports the continuous monitoring, assessment of and implementation of Joint Service and USMC unique system modifications. This includes efforts such as: improve weapon capability, operation, maintainability, supportability, service life, ergonomics, and safety enhancements. Funding also supports principle end items, as well as ammunition costs related to production verification and fielding activities. The funding decrease from FY20 to FY21 of $8.947M reflects Marine Corps funding priorities.
Family of Incident Response Systems (FIRS) - $0.556M will be used to support the annual modernization of the Unified Command Suite (UCS). The legacy UCS, which is CBIRF's primary command and control vehicle, faces obsolescence if scheduled modernizations of its satellite communications and land mobile radio systems are not applied in FY21. The increase of $.016M from FY20 to FY21 is due to scheduled engineering changes and upgrades to the UCS Block II to include the modernization of the SIPR Laptop and Serial Port Server.
Family of Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear (FCBRN) Systems - $0.813M will be used to procure 64 Radiological Detection Systems as replacement for obsolescent equipment. The increase of $.813M from FY20 to FY21 is due to FY21 being the first year of PMC funds for this MCPC.
Gunners Protection Kit (GPK) - $11.949M will procure Reducible Height Gunners Protection Kits (RHGPK), covers, and Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP). In addition, it funds logistics, safety, and fielding travel support costs. RHGPK will be reducible in height to enable Joint Light Tactical Vehicles (JLTV) to be transported in the lower vehicle stowage areas of Landing Platform/Dock (LPD 17) and Landing Helicopter Dock class ships and to enable Medium/Heavy Tactical Vehicle Replacement and Logistics Vehicle System Replacement to be transported in the main vehicle stowage decks of LPD 17 class ships. TOGPK 2.0 and RHGPK provide enhanced survivability and ballistic protection to the gunner when compared to existing gunner protection kits. The increase of $0.584M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the transition from TOGPK 2.0 to RHGPK.
Company and Battalion Mortars - $3.474 will support the procurement of Mortar Fire Control Application (MFCA) hardware; M671A1 Mortar Sights; and 60mm and 81mm Mortar System SL-3, as required. The MFCA Mortar Fire Control Application (MFCA) will reside on hardware from the Target Handoff System (THS) program of record and will allow users to perform aero-ballistic calculations for the USMC inventory of 60mm and 81mm mortar systems and 120mm mortar systems. M671A1 Mortar Sights support the US Marine Corps' intent to divest of tritium devices. The 60mm and 81mm Mortar System SL-3 provides replacement items to offset fair wear and tear loss. All of these improvements will help to modernize the 30-plus-year-old mortar systems and allow for extended life and performance of the system for the warfighter. The increase of $0.456M from FY20 to FY21 is in support of the procurement of the MFCA hardware.

proc:Name.footnote: The increase of $0.456M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the procurement of the MFCA hardware.
IAR Accessories include SL-3, ancillary equipment, and spare parts

M320A1: There will be a new Army contract for the FY20 - FY23 procurement. The increase in unit cost from FY19 to FY20 is based on the estimated impact of lower quantities with the expected stepladder pricing on the new Army contract that is being negotiated.

The increase of $.813M from FY20 to FY21 is due to FY21 being the first year of PMC funding for FCBRN to procure 64 Radiological Detection Systems.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Provides weapons and combat vehicle improvements in the areas of survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control. Additionally, Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) and upgrades address current and future reliability, sustainability, maintainability, and obsolescence issues to ensure mission readiness and effectiveness on the battlefield.
M1A1 MOD KIT: The M1A1 Mod Kit line sustains and improves the technology of the M1A1 tank and Armored Vehicle Launched Bridge (AVLB) to provide the MAGTF with the most relevant armor protected firepower, shock effect and maneuver platforms. Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control. Additionally, funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support these platforms.
Assault Bridging Modernization Program: Replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) maneuver. This program will establish commonality across the DoD fleet, eliminates obsolescence and diminishing manufacturing sources and materiel shortfall issues, while increasing the operational effectiveness and readiness of the MAGTF.
IRV: The Improved Recovery Vehicle (also known as the M88A2 Hercules) is the Marine Air-Ground Task Force's heavy lift, recovery, and battlefield maintenance asset in support of Marine Corps mobile assets (ie. ACV, AAV, LAV, ARV) whose organic recovery capability is exceeded by the vehicle weight. This line is designed to sustain and improve the technology of the IRV. Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control. Additionally, funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support the IRV.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $22.904M.
FY 2019 M1A1 MOD KIT $14.971 (Active $12.580M; Reserves $2.391M): These funds support modifications to the M1A1 Abrams tank (Active and Reserve components) to increase capabilities in the operational attributes of survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control. Funds support the procurement of efforts such as, Improved Side Armor (ISA), Gunner's Primary Sight Lower Panel (GPSLP), and Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM). ISA is a modification that significantly increases the survivability of the M1A1 tank. GPSLP is a modification to the tank's fire control system that enables the tank to fire two new types of ammunition being developed by the U.S. Army, increasing the lethality of the vehicle. TCM supports the procurement of new tactical radios to replace the obsolete AN/PRC 119 that is currently fielded.
FY 2019 Assault Bridging Modernization $5.700M: These funds support the procurement of 1 Test Article for the Assault Bridge which replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of MAGTF maneuver.
FY 2019 IRV $2.233M (Active $2.022M; Reserves $0.211M): These funds support the continued procurement of modification kits and associated systems technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform. Additionally, this funding supports modifications to tools and test equipment unique to the product office's portfolio of combat vehicles, such as the Direct Support Electrical Systems Test Set (DSESTS) and echeloned tool kits.
FY 2020: $22.760M
FY 2020 M1A1 MOD KIT $14.439 (Active $12.641M; Reserves $1.798M): These funds continue to support modifications to the M1A1 Abrams tank (Active and Reserve components) to increase capabilities in the operational attributes of survivability, lethality, mobility and command and control. Funds in support of survivability efforts allow for the procurement of Improved Side Armor (ISA) which significantly increases the survivability of the M1A1 tank. Funds in support of lethality efforts procure a new Gunner's Primary Sight Lower Panel (GPSLP). This modification to the tank's fire control system will enable the tank to fire two new types of ammunition being developed by the U.S. Army, increasing the lethality of the vehicle. Funds for the command and control effort procure communication systems as part of the Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM) effort. TCM procures new tactical radios to replace the obsolete AN/PRC 119 that is currently fielded. Funds for installation kits support the capabilities efforts of survivability, lethality, and command and control. These funds procure the cables, mounting hardware, installation material, and labor for the Abrams Integrated Display and Targeting System (AIDATS), ISA, and TCM installation process. The decrease from FY19 to FY20 is attributed to the reduction in level of effort for Command and Control which consists of Tactical Communication Modernization (TCM).
FY 2020 Assault Bridging Modernization $5.700M: These funds support the procurement of 1 Production Article for the Assault Bridge which replaces the legacy M60 armored vehicle and launching system of the current AVLB with the chassis of an M1A1 main battle tank, configured with a modern launching system, to support the launch and recovery of assault bridging in support of MAGTF maneuver.
FY 2020 IRV $2.621M (Active $2.406M; Reserves $0.215M): These funds will support the continued procurement of modification kits and associated systems technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform. Funding increase from FY19 to FY20 of $.298M will support modifications to tools and test equipment unique to the product office's portfolio of combat vehicles, such as the Direct Support Electrical Systems Test Set (DSESTS) and echeloned tool kits.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $3.067M
FY 2021 M1A1 MOD KIT $0.000M: The net decrease of $14.439M from FY20 to FY21 is a result of service decision to transition the M1A1 program to full sustainment and stop modernization.
FY 2021 IRV $3.067 (Active $2.848M; Reserves $0.219M): These funds will continue to procure modification kits and associated system technical support addressing modernization, sustainment, and obsolescence mitigation for the IRV platform. This line is designed to sustain and improve the technology of the IRV. Funding supports the procurement, fielding, and testing of critical operational and safety related modifications used to enhance and maintain platform characteristics, such as reliability-availability-maintainability and in operationally relevant attributes relating to survivability, lethality, mobility, and command and control. Funding also supports items such as miscellaneous tools and test items that support the IRV.Funding increase from FY20 to FY21 of $0.446M will support the integration on WIN 10 operating systems into the DSESTS, Electronic Maintenance Support System (EMSS) with combined application platform/software loader verification, and the completion of Exterior Stowage Modification Kits.
Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
OCO: N/A

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Ground Based Air Defense supports the Low Altitude Air Defense (LAAD) Battalion's mission of Short Range Air Defense (SHORAD) and provides the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) to include; Bases, Posts and Stations, the necessary Force Protection to defeat the full spectrum of threats associated with the Marine Corps Low-Altitude Air Defense mission, to include hostile aerial threats from Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS). With the proliferation of both military and commercial UAS platforms, the program is pursuing and acquiring more lethal and survivable GBAD Marine Air Defense Integrated System (MADIS) platforms; such as JLTV's with armored protection and better maneuverability than a High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV), providing increased Counter-UAS capabilities now and continually spiraling out increasing capability for the foreseeable future.
Marine Air Defense Integrated System Family of Systems (MADIS FoS): The MADIS FoS provides the Marine Corps with an organic, upgradable, and state of the art capability to protect MAGTF maneuver forces, installations and other designated defended assets from Fixed/Rotary Wing (FW/RW) aircraft and Unmanned Aircraft Systems. The MAGTF is at increased risk of lethal air attack and fires coordination from next generation aircraft as well as significant advances from small UAS (sUAS) threats due to their rapid development and proliferation by the commercial sector. To address these threats, the MADIS FoS consists of mission tailored variants designed for sustained operations ashore, afloat, and aboard installations.
The MADIS FoS includes Advanced Man Portable Air Defense (A-MANPADS) platform which provides close-in, low altitude, surface-to-air fires and command and control in defense of the MAGTF. The MADIS Increment 1 (Inc 1) will be accomplished with the procurement and installation of Government Furnished C-UAS equipment on a Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) beginning in FY20. MADIS Increment 2 will focus on extended range for the Inc 1 system as well as kinetic and non-kinetic capability supporting increased lethality. The Installations MADIS (I-MADIS) detects, tracks, and enables identification of sUAS operating above and in close proximity to an installation. The I-MADIS will begin procurement in FY20.
Medium Range Intercept Capability (Inc 3): The MRIC will provide the MAGTF Commander the ability to defend fixed/semi-fixed and other designated defended assets against cruise missiles, mortars, and precision guided missiles from a ground based air defense platform. MRIC is designed as a system-of systems and will be integrated with Marine Corps organic Command and Control (C2) and Joint Integrated Air Missile Defense (IAMD) architecture. The program will enhance the MAGTF's ground based air defense capability to rapidly prosecute aerial threats and expand layered defense to the MAGTF and supported Naval Forces. The MRIC will begin procurement in FY22 and will be comprised of missiles launchers, intercept missiles, and a Command and Control (C2) system.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $18.334M
-Funds provided for the initial procurement of 203 Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) Mode V Belt Packs, required cables, adapters, pouches, and technical manual updates, as well as associated support. IFF is the military designation of the Air Traffic Control (ATC) system that is used to identify and track military aircraft; and identify and defeat hostile UAS and aircraft. Due to the negotiation of a lower unit price under a new contract, the program was able to procure additional IFF Mode V Belt Packs.
FY 2020: $147.606M
Ground Based Air Defense-MADIS FoS $13.165M - Funds the second and final procurement of a total of 156 Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) Mode V belt packs and cables. IFF is the military designation of the Air Traffic Control (ATC) System that is used to identify and track military aircraft; and identify and defeat hostile UAS and aircraft. $0.646M Funds the procurement of QTY 4 Virtual Stinger Trainers (VST). VST is designed to enhance the training of Stinger Gunners by immersing them in a virtual environment to conduct Stinger engagements. The USMC will support the LAAD mission using the VST to introduce Marines at the Air Defense School House (ADSH) to the fundamentals of Stinger engagements and reinforce those fundamentals through repetition. $127.932M - Funds provide for low rate initial production (LRIP) of Marine Air Defense Integrated System Increment (MADIS Inc 1) JLTV systems, an increase from 0 to 26 vehicles. (26) LRIP systems are required to support concurrent engineering tests as well as Operational Assessment. $3.103M - Funds provide for the initial procurement of the Installations-MADIS (I-MADIS), to support critical infrastructure at bases, posts or stations, an increase from 0 to 1. $2.065M - Funds provide for the initial procurement of 26 Night Sights to replace equipment reaching obsolescence. The Night Sight will enable Marines to perform target acquisition during day or night, during reduced visibility conditions and when engaging low observable targets. $0.695M - Funds the required support to the I-MADIS system. This includes required fielding support, integrated logistics, and site surveys.
FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation Request: $18.920M
Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
Ground Based Air Defense-MADIS FoS $14.230M - Will fund MADIS Inc 1 Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) technical and production labor support which includes engineering, integration, cyber security, safety, information assurance, and software support. This support is required to fully integrate (26) vehicle kits onto the JLTV and ensure the system meets operational requirements. $3.538M - Will fund the procurement of one I-MADIS. I-MADIS supports critical infrastructure at bases, posts or stations. $1.152M - Will fund required support to the I-MADIS system. This includes required fielding support, integrated logistics, and site survey support.
The decrease of $128.686M from FY20 to FY21 is due to a change in major components of the MADIS Inc 1 requiring additional integration, engineering, developmental and operational testing prior to MS C in 4QFY21. The program continues to leverage existing efforts through the Army to minimize development costs and maintain schedule.

proc:Name.footnote: Due to the negotiation of a lower unit price under a new contract, the program was able to procure additional IFF Mode 5 Belt Packs in FY19.

Marine Air Defense Integrated System Increment 1 (MADIS Inc 1) is the procurement and installation of Government Furnished Equipment on a Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) in order to mitigate the risk of attacks from UAS and FW/RW aircraft. GFE Components include Fire Control Optics, EOIR Optics, turrets, drone on drone defeat capability, Modi, Mobile Vehicle Power Amplifier (MVPA), SkyView, C2 components, and a radar. Decrease from FY20 request to FY21 request is due to a change in major components of the MADIS Inc 1 requiring additional integration, engineering, developmental and operational testing prior to MS C in 4QFY21. The program continues to leverage existing efforts through the Army to minimize development costs and maintain schedule.

The increase in unit cost between FY20 and FY21 is due to I-MADIS component integration labor is phased to align with the delivery schedule for the various components that create the I-MADIS capability. FY21 CE 1.1.3 includes integration costs supporting the FY20 procurement for those long-lead items delivering in FY21 as well as a certain portion of the FY21 procurement's integration costs for non-long lead items tied to the FY21 buy.
