The decrease from the FY20 request to the FY21 submission is due to the finalization of the requirements and acquisition strategy. Increase from FY20 to FY21 is due to the ramp up of logistics support required for the C2 integration efforts.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 2.6) GBAD Prior Years Cumulative Support Funding

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Javelin provides the United States Army and the United States Marine Corps (USMC) with a man-portable fire-and-forget medium-range anti-armor missile with enhanced situational awareness and direct-fire effects that are able to defeat armored vehicles, fortifications, and soft targets in full spectrum operations. Javelin has a high kill rate against a variety of targets at extended ranges under adverse environments caused by day/night, weather, battlefield obscurants, and multiple counter-measure conditions. The system's soft launch feature permits firing from a fighting position or from an enclosure, and the modular design allows for the evolution of both software and hardware upgrades to meet changing threats and requirements. The system consists of a reusable Command Launch Unit (CLU) with a built-in-test (BIT) along with a modular missile encased in a disposable launch tube assembly, and includes training devices for tactical and classroom exercises. Javelin's fire-and-forget technology allows the gunner to fire without the need to track targets while providing enhanced lethality through the use of a tandem warhead that is able to defeat all current armor threats. This system is effective against both stationary and moving targets and provides defensive capability against attacking/hovering helicopters. The performance improvements in the current production of Javelin Block I CLUs include an increased target identification range, increased surveillance time, and an external interface for video output. The performance improvements in the current production of Javelin Block I missiles include an increased probability of hit/kill at 2500m, improved warhead lethality, and reduced time of flight. The CLU is being used as a stand-alone surveillance and target acquisition asset. The Army is the lead for this joint program with the USMC.
[P5 / Guided Missiles]: The unit cost per missile is determined by the combined procurement quantities of 850 missiles per year ordered by multiple services including the Army, USMC, and Foreign Military Sales (FMS). Missile procurement quantities are accurate across the Five Year Defense Plan (FYDP).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $3.106M (Active $2.939M, Reserve $0.167M) Funding supports the procurement of 11 Javelin missiles to replenish inventory due to end of life service conditions. Funding also provides for engineering and logistics support of the Javelin system, the updating of reserve equipment, and program management support.
FY 2020: $20.207M (Active $20.025M, Reserve $0.182M) Funding supports the procurement of 97 Javelin missiles to replenish inventory due to end of life service conditions. Funding also provides for engineering and logistics support of the Javelin system, updating of reserve equipment, and program management support.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $19.888M (Active $19.703M, Reserve $0.185M) Funding supports the procurement of 98 Javelin missiles to replenish inventory due to end of life service conditions. Funding also provides for engineering and logistics support of the Javelin system, updating of reserve equipment, and program management support.
The funding decrease of $0.319M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 results in the reduction of engineering and logistics support required for Javelin missiles to meet warfighter requirements.

proc:Name.footnote: The unit cost per missile through FY 2022 is based on the current Government Estimate for the procurement of the Javelin Spiral II F-Model missile variant. Starting in FY 2023, the unit cost decreases due to modernization efforts in the production and procurement of the new G-Model missile variant.

Javelin Joint Venture (JJV) includes Raytheon in Tucson, Arizona and Lockheed Martin in Orlando, Florida. Procuring Contracting Office (PCO) location is the Aviation and Missile Command (AMCOM) Redstone Arsenal, Alabama. Funded Sole Source (SS) / Firm Fixed Price (FFP).
The recurring missile surcharge is calculated based on the total cost of missile procurements per year.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Family of Anti-Armor Weapon Systems (FOAAWS)
The solution to the Follow on to SMAW (FOTS) capability requirement is a Family of Marine-portable Rocket Systems. This Family of Systems is composed of separate lightweight, short-range, and fire-and-forget weapons. The Family of Systems will be deployed to Marine Infantry Squads and Combat Engineer Battalions across the spectrum of conflict, under all environmental conditions, to neutralize or destroy a variety of ground targets including personnel, thin-skinned vehicles, and positions. The Family of Systems include the SMAW MK-153 Mod 0, SMAW MK-153 Mod 2, and the Multi-purpose Anti-Armor Weapon System (MAAWS) M3A1.
SMAW Mod 2 integrated a laser range finder and thermal weapon sight onto the improved SMAW launcher. The improved system is a lighter, more accurate, easier to maintain, and more reliable replacement to the SMAW Mod 0 launcher.
The MAAWS M3A1 is a multipurpose, man-portable, line-of-sight, reloadable, recoilless, anti-armor and anti-personnel weapon system. It is a revision of the 84mm Carl Gustaf (M3) man-portable, recoilless rifle produced by Saab Bofors Dynamics. This system will enable the Marine Infantry Squads and Combat Engineer Battalions to engage in offensive and defensive operations with anti-armor, anti-personnel, anti-material, and assault capabilities. The MAAWS consists of the M3A1 Carl Gustaf Recoilless Rifle, Fire Control System and MeOpta red dot back up sight. Munitions include two Sub-caliber Adapter Training Devices and a suite of 84mm ammunition with greater capabilities than the SMAW Mod 2 system. The suite of 84mm ammunition provides obscuration, illumination, personnel denial, armored vehicle denial and penetration, bunker and hardened facility penetration, and soft target destruction capabilities to meet various mission requirements.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $13.590M The FY 2019 baseline request of $13.590M funded the procurement of 215 Multi-purpose Anti-Armor Weapon System M3A1s.
FY 2020: $21.913M The FY 2020 baseline request will fund the procurement of 342 Multi-purpose Anti-Armor Weapon System M3A1 as a follow on capability to SMAW MOD 2 per Joint Force 2025 guidance and Close Combat Lethality Task Force concepts and objectives.
Increase of $8.323M funding from FY19 to FY20 directly funds procurement of 127 additional Multi-purpose Anti-Armor Weapon Systems M3A1 to supporting the Initial Operational Capability by 2QFY21. The FY20 MAAWS M3A1 quantity and unit cost increase is due to inflation and no change in the step-ladder pricing.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $21.891M
The FY 2021 baseline request supports the following: $15.996 will fund the procurement of 256 Multi-purpose Anti-Armor Weapon System M3A1 as a follow on capability to SMAW MOD 2 per Joint Force 2025 and Close Combat Lethality Task Force concepts and objectives.
Additionally, $2.983M funds Product Improvement upgrades to the rifle and the Fire Control System due to deficiencies identified during user evaluation of Sight Range Performance and Squad Integration requirements. The Sight Range Performance Testing identified deficiencies in the Fire Control System to recognize relevant targets at the range of 1,000 meters with and without night vision optics. Squad Integration Testing identified deficiencies in how the M3A1 and the 84mm ammunition is carried by Marines and how compatible the M3A1 will be with parachute rigging.
$0.770 funds one Fire Control System Spare Kit per M3A1 MAAWS System and $1.218 funds one 7.62mm and one 20mm SubCal Adaptors for the M3A1 MAAWS System. Sub Cal Adapters is a training system that simulates back blast. Funds in the amount of $.924M will provide Engineering, Logistics, and Program Management Services.
The decrease in MAAWS unit cost from FY20 to FY21 is due to a configuration change to the Reflex (Red Dot) sight.

proc:Name.footnote: The M3A1 Multi-purpose Anti-Armor Weapon System (MAAWS) procurement will continue throughout the FYDP, to fulfill its requirement as a follow on capability to SMAW MOD 2 per Force 2025 and Close Combat Lethality Task Force (CCLTF)concepts and objectives. The decrease in MAAWS unit cost from FY20 to FY21 is due to a configuration change to the Reflex (Red Dot) sight.

proc:ProcQuantity.footnote: The manufacturer is producing for both the Army and USMC. This delivery schedule reflects the Marine Corps planned deliveries in support of Marine Corps fielding plans.
The manufacturer is producing for both the Army and USMC. This delivery schedule reflects the Marine Corps planned deliveries in support of Marine Corps fielding plans.

proc:Name.footnote: Footnote (2): Product Improvement funding in FY21 funds upgrades to the rifle and the Fire Control System due to deficiencies identified during Sight Range Performance Testing, Squad Integration Testing and Ruggedization Testing.
The Spare Kits/Accessories funding includes procuring one Fire Control System (FCS) Spare Kit per M3A1 MAAWS System from FY21 - FY25. This includes spare lenses, batteries, and eye piece.
The Sub-Cal Adaptors funding includes procuring one 7.62mm and one 20mm Sub-Cal Adaptors (SCA) per M3A1 MAAWS System From FY21 - FY25.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 2.1) Technical, Engineering and Program Management Services

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The M41A7 Saber weapon system is a combat proven system that provides long-range, lethal anti-armor precision assault capability for the United States Marine Corps Infantry, Tank, and Light Armored Reconnaissance Battalions across modern operational environments. The M41A7 is the replacement for the M220 Tube-launched, Optically-tracked, Wire/Wireless-guided (TOW) 2 weapon system. Global Positioning System (GPS)-based location detection and an altitude determination subsystem generate a 10-digit grid coordinate of a target's position, and superior surveillance capability enables the warfighter to identify targets at long range and engage with TOW missiles or other weapon systems.
TOW missiles (BGM-71 Series) are the munition for the M41A7 system. The TOW missile is a highly lethal, cost effective, interoperable, multi-purpose anti-armor round that is used in either direct-fire or "fly-over, shoot down" mode against field fortifications and structures. In its current configuration, the combination of the M41A7 and the TOW missile provides the capability to defeat armored vehicles, bunkers, and buildings at extended ranges in all battlefield conditions.
The M41A7 is mounted from a variety of combat vehicle systems such as the Joint Lightweight Tactical Vehicle (JLTV), High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV), Mine Resistant Ambush Protected Vehicle (MRAP), and Light Armored Vehicle - Anti-Tank (LAV-AT), as well as having the capability for ground mounted operations.
Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command identified the Spike Non Line of Sight (NLOS) as the preferred weapon system to satisfy an MARSOC Urgent Universal Needs Statement, tracking number 18024UA. Organic Precision Strike (Medium) will meet the Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command (MARSOC) requirement for a lethal precision capability by procuring the Spike NLOS system to support current combat operations.
[P5 / Guided Missiles]: The Government Estimate for the TOW missile unit cost is determined by the weighted average of multiple missile variant unit costs, and vary annually due to different missile variants being procured.
[P5 / Spike NLOS]: Spike NLOS is a multi-purpose, electro-optical (EO), Man-in-the-loop (MITL) missile system with a real-time wireless data link for ranges between 1km and 32 km. It is manufactured by the Israeli company Rafael Advanced Defense Systems and is being delivered to US Special Forces via Lockheed Martin in partnership with Rafael. The Spike NLOS system is in operational use by the United States Special Operations Command (USSOCOM), Spain, the United Kingdom, South Korea, and Columbia, and is a possible replacement for aging Saber/TOW systems and offers to modernize the infantry to meet the requirements identified in the Marine Corps Operating Concept. The Spike NLOS launcher and High Explosive Anti-Tank (HEAT) and Penetrator Blast Fragmentation (PBF) missiles match or exceed the capabilities of the Saber/TOW systems in range and effects, which would enable small units to achieve a greater tactical edge to counter threats in complex and compartmentalized terrain. Capability / Shortfall: MARSOCs require the ability to strike stationary and mobile point targets in real time out to the limits of their ability to positively identify targets with organic ground and airborne assets while minimizing collateral damage. Potential target sets include personnel in the open or under light cover, light frame or single layer brick buildings, and unarmored or lightly armored vehicles (moving and stationary), to include Vehicle-Borne Improvised Explosive Devices (VBIEDs) or High Value Targets (HVTs) moving at speeds up to 45mph
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $48.945M (Active $48.759M, Reserve $0.186M) Funding supports the procurement of 704 TOW 2A Practice missiles to replenish inventory and support training requirements. Funding also provides for engineering, logistics, and program management efforts associated with the refurbishing and retrofitting of missiles in order to extend their service life; for reserve equipment support and for product improvement upgrades for the Saber System.
FY 2020: $60.501M (Active $60.309M, Reserve $0.192M) Funding supports the procurement of 565 TOW 2A Practice missiles to replenish inventory and support training requirements. Funding also provides for engineering, logistics, and program management efforts associated with the refurbishing and retrofitting of missiles in order to extend their service life; for reserve equipment support; and for product improvement upgrades for the Saber System.
$21.950M will procure three Spike NLOS missile systems for Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command (MARSOC), with a future capability for expansion to additional systems. The estimated project cost of one MARSOC Spike NLOS system is $7.317M, which includes the missile launch/guidance system, an associated vehicle or adaptation of an existing vehicle, an inventory of 10 missiles, and initial training and logistics support.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $34.985M ($34.792M Active; $0.193M Reserve) Funding supports the procurement of 515 TOW 2A Practice missiles to replenish inventory and support training requirements. Funding also provides for engineering, logistics, and program management efforts associated with the refurbishing and retrofitting of missiles in order to extend their service life; for reserve equipment support; and for product improvement upgrades for the Saber System.
The decrease of $25.516 between FY 2020 and FY 2021 reflects the fulfillment of the MARSOC Spike NLOS missile system requirement, the procurement of 50 less missiles and decreased engineering and program support necessary to meet Warfighter requirements for the TOW 2A Practice missile variant.

proc:Name.footnote: Missile unit costs are based on current Government Estimates for the procurement of the TOW 2A Practice missile variant; the increased cost per missile beginning in FY 2022 reflects current budget estimates that lead to lower procurement quantities.

Raytheon in Tucson, Arizona is currently the only industry source that is both equipped and qualified to produce TOW missiles. Procuring Contracting Office (PCO) location is the Aviation and Missile Command (AMCOM) Redstone Arsenal, Alabama. Funded Sole Source (SS) / Fixed Price Incentive Fee (FPIF). Multi-year contracts do not follow the Administrative Lead Time (ALT) shown for annual year contracts.

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: FY 2020 Base procurement dollars support the fourth year of a five-year (FY17-21) multi-year contract. 10 U.S. Code #2431 and DoD FM Reg. Vol 2B, Ch 4 mandate Production Rates be defined in terms of budget year.

FY 2021 Base procurement dollars support the fifth year of a five-year (FY17-21) multi-year contract. 10 U.S. Code #2431 and DoD FM Reg. Vol 2B, Ch 4 mandate Production Rates be defined in terms of budget year.

proc:Name.footnote: The recurring missile surcharge is calculated based on the total cost of missile procurements per year.
The funding decrease of $21.950M between FY 2020 and FY 2021 reflects the fulfillment of the MARSOC Spike NLOS missile system requirement.
Lockheed Martin in Dallas, Texas is the manufacturing source for the FY 2020 Spike NLOS missile systems required for MARSOC.

The Missile Engineering Support cost element was split from the overall Saber Engineering Support due to the need to track TOW missile-specific engineering support costs that are not utilized by the Saber Launcher system.

The Missile Program Support cost element includes USMC Program Management Office (PMO) Support for Saber Product Improvement, and was split from overall Saber Program Support due to the need to track TOW missile-specific program support costs that are not utilized by the Saber Launcher system.

Saber Launcher Support consolidates Saber Maintenance and Support Equipment, Saber Subsystems/Components, and Saber Programmatic and Engineering Support. The funding decrease in FY 2020 and out is the result of reduced tasking as the Saber Launcher system is transferred between programs.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System (GMLRS) rockets are surface-to-surface artillery rockets fired from the High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS) launchers. GMLRS rockets provide 24/7, all-weather precision fires to engage both area and point targets at short, medium, and long ranges. In order to align with the National Defense Strategy and continuously deliver performance with affordability and speed, the Marine Corps procures its GMLRS rockets in concert with Army via the Precision Fires Rocket and Missile project office. The GMLRS program is critical to sustaining a Joint Force military advantage and maintaining a favorable regional balance of power in the theaters in which HIMARS deploys.
There are three variants of the GMLRS; Unitary (U); Alternative Warhead (AW); and Dual Purpose Improved Conventional Munition (DPICM). GMLRS-U utilizes a 200-pound high explosive warhead to engage point targets with limited collateral damage. GMLRS-AW was developed as a non-cluster munition replacement for DPICM that is used to engage area and imprecisely located targets. The GMLRS-AW rocket is 90% common with the Unitary variant. GMLRS-U and GMLRS-AW are currently in full rate production.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Prior to FY 2020 Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System (GMLRS) was budgeted out of the Artillery Weapons System (HIMARS) line item. (LI:2212)
GMLRS costs are driven by total U.S. Army, Marine Corps, and Foreign Military Sales (FMS) buys and follows a buy-to-budget procurement approach.
FY 2020: $27.846M ($24.718M Active; Reserves $3.128M) FY 2020 funding will support the procurement of GMLRS Alternative Warhead (AW) for active and reserve components (Active Quantity: 174, Reserves Quantity: 18).
Tactical GMLRS Hardware unit costs are dependent on total quantities negotiated by the Army Contracting Command-Redstone with Lockheed Martin and procured for the Army, Marine Corps and Foreign Military Sales (FMS) organizations.
FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation Request: $133.689M ($130.495M Active; Reserves $3.194M) FY 2021 Baseline funding will support the procurement of GMLRS Alternative Warhead (AW) for active and reserve components (Active Quantity: 930, Reserves Quantity: 22).
The Marine Corps does not have sufficient GMLRS inventory to address it's designated operational requirements to service longer range targets with minimal collateral damage. The baseline increase of $105.843M from FY2020 to FY2021 supports the build up of missile capacity to address this shortfall including a realignment from 155mm DPICM replacement procurement to GMLRS-AW procurement in order to achieve minimum GMLRS-AW global inventory levels. These increases are in alignment with the Commandant's Planning Guidance and the National Defense Strategy.
Tactical GMLRS Hardware unit costs are dependent on total quantities negotiated by the Army Contracting Command-Redstone with Lockheed Martin and procured for the Army, Marine Corps and Foreign Military Sales (FMS) organizations. The Marine Corps Tactical GMLRS Hardware unit cost does not include the Reduced Range Practice Rocket.
OCO: FY 2020 OCO: $16.919M Funds will support the replenishment of 120 GMLRS munitions expended in efforts involving contingency operations, Operation Freedom's Sentinel-Afghanistan (OFS-A).
FY 2021 OCO Appropriation Request: $17.456M Funds will support the replenishment of 120 GMLRS munitions expended in efforts involving contingency operations, Operation Freedom's Sentinel-Afghanistan (OFS-A).

proc:Name.footnote: The unit cost and quantity for FY21 is an estimate from the Army based on GMLRS variant type, quantity, and total dollars identified from all services procuring GMLRS. This includes the Marine Corps, Army and five FMS countries. The actual unit cost will be determined upon contract award. These increases are in alignment with the Commandant's Planning Guidance and the National Defense Strategy.

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: Lockheed Martin is currently the industry source that is both facilitized and qualified to produce GMLRS rocket. FY21 annual production contract will be a base year contract with multiple option years.

proc:Name.footnote: The unit cost and quantity for FY21 is an estimate from the Army based on GMLRS variant type, quantity, and total dollars identified from all services procuring GMLRS. This includes the Marine Corps, Army and five FMS countries. The actual unit cost will be determined upon contract award. These increases are in alignment with the Commandant's Planning Guidance and the National Defense Strategy.

proc:LineItem.proc:LineItemTitle: Common Aviation Command and Control System (CAC2S)
proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Common Aviation Command and Control System (CAC2S) - A coordinated modernization effort to replace the existing aviation command and control equipment of the Marine Air Command and Control System (MACCS) and to provide the Aviation Combat Element (ACE) with the necessary hardware, software, equipment, and facilities to effectively command, control, and coordinate aviation operations. The CAC2S system will accomplish the MACCS missions with a suite of operationally scalable modules to support the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF), Joint, and Coalition Forces. The CAC2S integrates the functions of aviation command and control into an interoperable system that will support the core competencies of all Marine Corps warfighting concepts. The CAC2S, in conjunction with the MACCS organic sensors (AN/TPS-63, AN/TPS-59, and AN/TPS-80 (Ground/Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR)) and weapon system Composite Tracking Network (CTN) will provide enhanced air control, improved situational awareness, sensor integration (G/ATOR and AN/TPS-59), full Tactical Data Link integration, airspace and battle planning and command functionality as well as sensor netting integration (Composite Tracking Network (CTN)). CAC2S, with these organic MACCS programs, support the tenets of Expeditionary Maneuver Warfare and fosters joint interoperability. CAC2S Increment I replaces legacy aviation command and control systems in the following Marine aviation agencies: Direct Air Support Center (DASC), Tactical Air Command Center (TACC), and Tactical Air Operations Center (TAOC).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019 ($32.587M):
Funds procured tactical voice/data radios associated with the CAC2S MRQ-13 Communications System (CS) refresh/upgrade. The CS was originally fielded in FY 2006 and has been sustained and repurposed to provide CAC2S operators access to tactical radios required to communicate with aircraft and external agencies. The CS is a High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV) mounted shelter containing voice over internet protocol (VoIP) networking/intercom components and tactical radios that enables remote communications access and control from laptop computers within the CAC2S operations facility/tent. The seventy-seven (77) CS vehicles associated with CAC2S currently retain 2006 era radios. These obsolete radios must be replaced to meet NSA crypto modernization mandates and enable CAC2S to maintain voice/data interoperability with joint forces. FY 2019 funds made available through the FY 2018 Should Cost initiative allowed accelerated procurement of tactical radios for the CS refresh/upgrade to occur beginning 1 year ahead of schedule. Accelerated procurement of the tactical radios increases CS interoperability, reliability and sustainability and enable CAC2S to meet NSA crypto modernization mandates as the legacy/obsolete CS radios and networking components are replaced with modern, readily supportable communications equipment. All required AN/PRC-160 radios were procured to support all 77 CS units, and 47% of the required AN/PRC-158 radios were procured which will enable the program to outfit 36 CS units. The FY 2019 budget also supports the procurement of the Multi-function Information Distribution System (MIDS) Block II upgrade required to comply with DoD frequency remapping and NSA crypto modernization mandates by FY 2020.
FY 2020 ($30.812M):
In FY 2020, CAC2S will continue with the procurement of radios and voice networking/intercom components associated with the AN/MRQ-13 Communications System (CS) refresh/upgrade. The CS upgrade/refresh consists of the procurement of 2 variants of tactical radios and radio auxiliary support equipment, and various voice networking/intercom components which will replace the current obsolete voice/data communications components with modernized equipment that is more reliable, readily supportable and cyber-secure. In FY 2020, CAC2S will procure all required AN/PRC-158 Radios to upgrade all quantity 77 AN/MRQ-13 CS units. The funding will also be utilized to initiate the procurement of voice over internet protocol (VoIP) networking/intercom components and continue to procure auxiliary radio support equipment. Funding in FY 2020 will also continue to support AN/TSQ-297 CAC2S Full Deployment Unit (FDU) fielding and associated, on-site new equipment training (NET) that is provided with CAC2S deliveries to the operating forces. Supports installation of engineering changes that require integration upon initial delivery of the production systems.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation ($35.057M):
Funds will complete the procurement of the CAC2S MRQ-13 Communications System (CS) refresh/upgrade. FY 2021 funding will continue the procurement of the required voice over internet protocol (VoIP) networking/intercom components and radio auxiliary support equipment required to interface with the tactical radios. These upgraded CS units will provide CAC2S improved voice/data networks and interoperability with joint forces and will eliminate obsolescence issues associated with the legacy VoIP components. FY 2021 was increased by $2.006M from the FY 2020 request to the FY 2021 request. This will support the integration of the CS voice communications components.
The $4.245M increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is to support the procurement of voice communications components and voice over internet protocol (VoIP) networking/intercom components required to complete the refresh/upgrade of the AN/MRQ-13 CS.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: Common Aviation Command and Control System (CAC2S)

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: Total System AAO = 50 as reflected on the P5. 4 PY refurbished assets not reflected on P5a.

proc:Name.footnote: The CAC2S (V)1 variant is fielded to Tactical Air Operations Centers (TAOC), Early Warning & Control (E/WC) detachments and Direct Air Support Centers (DASC) agencies.

The AN/TSQ-297(V)2 variant is equipped with a tent-based operations facility providing 176 operator workstations. The CAC2S (V)2 variant is fielded to each Marine Aircraft Wing's Tactical Air Command Center (TACC).

The AN/TSQ-297(V)3 variant is operationally the same as the (V)1 variant, but is not equipped with tactical vehicles and tents. The CAC2S (V)3 variant is fielded to the supporting establishment and Military Occupational Specialty producing schools.

The CS upgrade/refresh consists of 2 variants of tactical radios, voice over internet protocol (VoIP) networking/intercom components, and radio auxiliary support equipment. The CS upgrade replaces 2006 era, obsolete voice/data communications components with modernized equipment that is more reliable, readily supportable and cyber-secure, enabling integration with CAC2S networks and interoperability with joint forces. The AN/MRQ-13 CS refresh/upgrade components improve CS interoperability, reliability, and sustainability while enabling CAC2S to meet NSA crypto modernization mandates as the legacy/obsolete CS radios and networking components are replaced with modern, readily supportable communications equipment. FY20 funding will complete the procurement of all required AN/PRC 158 Radio Support Equipment and AN/PRC-158 Radios to upgrade all seventy-seven (77) AN/MRQ-13 CS units. The $9.576M increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 supports the procurement of voice communications components and voice over internet protocol (VoIP) networking/intercom components required to complete the refresh/upgrade of the seventy-seven (77) CS vehicles.
Global Positioning System - Miniature Precision Lightweight GPS Receiver (PLGR) Engine - Selective Availability Anti-spoofing Module (SAASM) (GPS - MPE-S).

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 2.1.2) GPS - MPE-S (See ACRN defined in P5 Remarks)

proc:Name.footnote: MIDS radios provide the primary means to exchange Tactical Data Link (TDL-J) air battlespace information among joint and coalition aviation command and control agencies and aircraft.
A reduction of $2.798M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the completion of fielding of all CAC2S Full Deployment Units (FDUs) in FY 2020.
A reduction of $2.533M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the completion of NET in FY 2020 as result of the AN/TSQ-297 CAC2S FDU being fully fielded in FY 2021.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Repair and Test Equipment Budget Line Item provides repair and test equipment consisting of more than 200 different items required to support the operation and maintenance of USMC ground based weapon systems and major end items. Repair and test equipment includes items such as tool kits, shop sets, manual and automatic test equipment, as well as meteorology and calibration equipment. The following acquisition programs fall under the repair and test equipment budget line: General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS); Automatic Test Systems (ATS), Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP), and Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Logistics Support Systems (MLS2).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $45.446M (ACTIVE:$45.446M, RESERVE:$0.000M)
General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS) $13.329M: The GPT&TS budget procured a wide variety of portable tool kits, large tool shop sets (mounted on vehicles or trailers or contained within 20-ft shelters), handheld electronic test equipment, handheld mechanical test equipment, and large mechanical test equipment contained in shelters or buildings. All of these items are commercial off the shelf or modified commercial off the shelf type equipment that are required to support the field maintenance effort of USMC ground equipment and weapon systems located within USMC expeditionary battalions and squadrons. FY19 funding includes the procurement of a new technology of Additive Manufacturing (also known as 3D printing) to enhance our existing fabrication capability using fielded machine shops. FY19 funding procured portable electronic test sets such as Radio Test Sets, Microwave Radio and Radar Test Sets, Microwave Signal Generators, Data Network Testers. The Microwave Signal Generators and Data Network Testers were added to the FY19 effort due to urgent need to support readiness issues with microwave radios such as Very Small Aperture Terminal(VSAT). Microwave Radio Test Set unit price change on contract awarded September 2019 reflects increase in required capability (frequency range doubled, digital test types quadrupled, etc.) to keep pace with the latest generation of SATCOM systems this equipment supports. FY19 funding from Fluid Analyzers was redirected to critical priority Microwave Comm and Radar Test Set program (Cost Element 2.4). FY19 funding provided for test routines for large mechanical test stands and associated equipment necessary to test vehicle components. In addition, funding procured engineering, logistics, system software support, and cyber security efforts for the entire portfolio of GPT&TS items.
Automatic Test Systems (ATS) $9.748M: Funding supported procurement of the Circuit Card Assembly (CCA) Test Station modernized replacement system as well as Engineer Change Proposal (ECP) kits to enhance capability and mitigate against obsolescence for the General Purpose Automatic Test System (GPATS), Technical Manual publication, and Application Program Sets (APS) production that enable ATS to test multiple Marine Corps ground systems, such as the VSAT APS. ATS consists of both hardware and software components that provide mobile and automatic testing on Line Replaceable Units (LRU) and CCA in order to improve weapon system readiness, provide an organic maintenance solution, and decrease life cycle costs.
Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP) $11.916M: Funding procured two lightened Shop Equipment, Calibration (SEC), previously known as Expeditionary Calibration Facilities. These shops are designed for expeditionary deployments and use in austere environments to support MAGTF deployed operations and will provide warfighters with a lighter, smaller expeditionary calibration capability. Funding will also procure various calibration equipment. Various calibration equipment must be replaced/upgraded over time in order to support and calibrate all the different test equipment used by various maintenance personnel working on USMC ground military equipment.
MAGTF Logistics Support Systems (MLS2) $10.453M: Funding procured Electronic Maintenance Support Systems (EMSS) to address AAO shortfalls. FY19 funding procured items such as Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment, operating software that comprises the EMSS and technical support. EMSS includes Built-In-Test/Built- In-Test Equipment (BIT/BITE) interfaces and Software Defined Test Instrument (SDTI) that enables capabilities such as storing and viewing Interactive Electronic Technical Manuals (IETMs), Computer Based Training (CBT), and other maintenance applications. EMSS also has the capability to connect to the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) and access sites like Global Combat Support System - Marine Corps (GCSS-MC) in order to facilitate maintenance and supply transactions, thereby improving readiness. EMSS connected to the MCEN were demonstrated to provide maintainers a time savings of upwards of 15% per task and 40 minutes per day based on their average workload. Electronic Maintenance Device (EMD) hardware was broken into two separate cost elements, "EMD Hardware" and "EMD Hardware CF20". This reflects two separate procurements off of two separate USMC contracts. The EMD acquisition strategy was updated for FY19 and FY20 procurements due to an Army contract protest. As a result of the current Army contract protest, "EMD Hardware" was procured off an existing in-house blanket purchase agreement (BPA) contract, and "EMD Hardware CF20" was procured off a new in-house BPA that awarded 4QFY19. The EMD acquisition strategy change allowed the USMC to field additional systems sooner in order to reduce AAO shortages and improve maintenance capabilities for ground weapon systems. FY19 EMSS Hardware CF20 unit cost and quantities have been updated to reflect contract award that occurred 4QFY19 which allowed the program to procure additional quantities. Operating software is no longer required due to a USMC enterprise transition from an end-device subscription model to an end-user subscription model. Funding re-directed to fund additional technical support requirements (See Cost Element 1.3 for details).
FY 2020: $55.156M (ACTIVE:$55.156M, RESERVE:$0M)
General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS) $23.753M: The GPT&TS budget procures a wide variety of portable tool kits, large tool shop sets (mounted on vehicles or trailers or contained within 20ft shelters), handheld electronic test equipment, handheld mechanical test equipment, and large mechanical test equipment contained in shelters or buildings. All of these items are commercial off the shelf or modified commercial off the shelf type equipment that are required to support the field maintenance effort of USMC ground equipment and weapon systems located within USMC expeditionary battalions and squadrons. FY20 funding continues the procurement of the new expeditionary Additive Manufacturing (3D printing) machine shops and starts the procurement of the new Tactical Fabrication Kits for use at the Battalion level. The unit cost change to the Expeditionary Fabrication capability reflects advances in 3D printer technologies that now allow us to provide increased support to Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) operations, necessitating increased cyber security and other capabilities (mills & lathes), and 1st article testing in addition to production. The $10.424M increase from FY19 to FY20 is primarily a result of new Additive Manufacturing (3D printing) and Fire Bottle Refill Shop capabilities. This funding also addresses the need to continue procurement efforts of additional portable electronic test sets such as Microwave Comm and Radar Test Sets, Microwave Signal Generators, Data Network Testers, and increased quantities for the Fire Bottle Refill Shop (contained in a trailer mounted 20-ft container). Funding also procures items such as Fluid Analyzers, engine and transmission dynamometers and fuel test stands, as well as engineering, logistics, system software support, and cyber security efforts for the entire portfolio of GPT&TS items. Increased support in FY20 aligns to the procurement and fielding plan for equipment such as X-FAB, TACFAB and multiple test sets. The change between the FY19 request and the FY20 request for the Fluid Analysis Test Set, Tier I (formerly known as Operator Fluid Analysis Test Set) reflects unit cost increase to support the capability to test for metal particles at the operational level. Unit cost change for Fluid Analysis Test Set, Tier II (formerly known as Technicians Fluid Analysis Test Set) due to new cyber security requirements dictating new instrument controller and software.
Automatic Test Systems (ATS) $9.046M: Funding supports procurement of the Circuit Card Assembly (CCA) Test Station modernized replacement system as well as Engineer Change Proposal (ECP) modernization kits to the ATS Family of Systems such as General Purpose Automatic Test System (GPATS), Ground Radio Maintenance Automatic Test System (GRMATS), and Application Program Sets (APS). These ECPs will enhance organic maintenance capabilities and mitigate against obsolescence. ATS consists of both hardware and software components that provides mobile and automatic testing on Principle End Items (PEI), Line Replaceable Units (LRU), and Shop Repairable Units (SRU) in order to improve weapon system readiness, provide an organic maintenance solution, and decrease life cycle costs of supported weapon systems. The $0.702M decrease from FY19 to FY20 aligns to the procurement plan for Automatic Test Equipment.
Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP) $11.817M: Funding procures two lightened Shop Equipment, Calibration (SEC), previously known as Expeditionary Calibration Facilities. These shops are designed for expeditionary deployments and use in austere environments to support MAGTF deployed operations. These shops will provide warfighters with a lighter, smaller, and expeditionary calibration capability. Funding will also procure various calibration equipment. Various calibration equipment, controllers (work stations), and software must be replaced/upgraded over time in order to support and calibrate all the different test equipment used by various maintenance personnel working on USMC ground military equipment.
MAGTF Logistics Support Systems (MLS2) $10.540M: Funding procures Electronic Maintenance Support Systems (EMSS) to address AAO shortfalls. FY20 funding will procure items such as Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment, operating software that comprises the EMSS, and technical support. EMSS will emulate and/or interface with test equipment and enables capabilities such as storing and viewing Interactive Electronic Technical Manuals (IETMs), Computer Based Training (CBT), and other maintenance applications. EMSS also has the capability to connect to the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) and access sites like Global Combat Support System - Marine Corps (GCSS-MC) in order to facilitate maintenance and supply transactions thereby improving readiness. EMSS connected to the MCEN was demonstrated to provide maintainers a time savings of upwards of 15% per task and 40 minutes per day based on their average workload. Electronic Maintenance Device (EMD) hardware was broken into two separate cost elements, "EMD Hardware" and "EMD Hardware CF20". This reflects two separate procurements off of two separate USMC contracts. The EMD acquisition strategy was updated for FY19 and FY20 procurements due to an Army contract protest. As a result of the current Army contract protest, "EMD Hardware" was procured off an existing in-house blanket purchase agreement (BPA) contract, and "EMD Hardware CF20" was procured off a new in-house BPA that will be awarded 4QFY19. The EMD acquisition strategy change allowed the USMC to field additional systems sooner in order to reduce AAO shortages and improve maintenance capabilities for ground weapon systems. FY20 EMSS Hardware CF20 unit cost and quantities have been updated to reflect contract award that occurred 4QFY19. Operating software is no longer required due to a USMC enterprise transition from an end-device subscription model to an end-user subscription model. Funding re-directed to additional technical support requirements (See Cost Element 1.3 for details). The technical support increase from FY19 to FY20 funds additional requirements such as technical support for increased EMD fielded quantities, cyber security requirements for network connected systems, enhanced diagnostic software, and to merge EMD and Vehicle Automate Diagnostic System (VADS) capabilities which will decrease system lifecycle costs and logistics footprint.
FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation Request: $24.405M (ACTIVE:$24.405M, RESERVE:$0M)
General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS) $4.609M: The $19.144M decrease from FY20 to FY21 reflects completed procurements for portable electronic test sets such as Microwave Comm and Radar Test Sets, Microwave Signal Generators, Data Network Testers, engine and transmission dynamometers, fuel test stands, and aligns to the procurement plan for Fluid Analysis Test Sets and Hydraulic Component Testers as well as aligns to the procurement plan for X-FAB. FY21 funding continues the procurement of X-FAB Additive Manufacturing Shop (also known as 3D printing), TAC-FAB 3D printer kits, fire bottle refill shop, various test program sets, and fluid analyzers. FY21 funding will also procure engineering, logistics, system software support, and cyber security efforts for the entire portfolio of GPT&TS items. The GPT&TS budget will procure a variety of portable tool kits, large tool shop sets (mounted on vehicles or trailers or contained within 20ft shelters), handheld electronic test equipment, handheld mechanical test equipment, and large mechanical test equipment contained in shelters or buildings. All of these items are commercial off the shelf or modified commercial off the shelf type equipment that are required to support the field maintenance effort of USMC ground equipment and weapon systems.
Automatic Test Systems (ATS) $4.602M: The $4.444M decrease from FY20 to FY21 aligns to the procurement plan for the CCA Test Station and to the reduced requirement for Automated Test Systems engineering, software and logistics support in FY21. Funding will support procurement of automatic test equipment such as the Circuit Card Assembly (CCA) Test Station modernized replacement system and Ground-Radio Hand-Held Organizational Systems Tester (GHOST), a portable radio tester for organization maintenance to test existing and future ground tactical radio systems, as well as Engineer Change Proposal (ECP) modernization kits to the ATS Family of Systems such as General Purpose Automatic Test System (GPATS), and Application Program Sets (APS). These ECPs will enhance organic maintenance capabilities and mitigate against obsolescence. ATS consists of both hardware and software components that provides mobile and automatic testing on Principle End Items (PEI), Line Replaceable Units (LRU), and Shop Repairable Units (SRU) in order to improve weapon system readiness, provide an organic maintenance solution, and decrease life cycle costs of supported weapon systems.
Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP) $2.861M: The $8.956M decrease from FY20 to FY21 is a result of the completed procurement of two Shop Equipment, Calibration (SEC) shelter systems. Funding will procure various calibration equipment. Calibration equipment (standards) must be replaced/upgraded over time in order to support and calibrate all the different test equipment used by various maintenance personnel working on USMC ground military equipment.
MAGTF Logistics Support Systems (MLS2) $12.333M: The $1.793M increase from FY20 to FY21 enables additional AAO shortfall purchases as well as technical support to include EMD fielded quantities, cyber security requirements for network connected systems, enhanced diagnostic software, and to merge EMD and Vehicle Automate Diagnostic System (VADS) capabilities which will decrease system lifecycle costs and logistics footprint. Funding will continue to procure Electronic Maintenance Support Systems (EMSS) to address AAO shortfalls as well as procure items such as Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment, operating software that comprises the EMSS, and technical support. EMSS will emulate and/or interface with test equipment and enables capabilities such as storing and viewing Interactive Electronic Technical Manuals (IETMs), Computer Based Training (CBT), and other maintenance applications. EMSS also has the capability to connect to the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) and access sites like Global Combat Support System - Marine Corps (GCSS-MC) in order to facilitate maintenance and supply transactions thereby improving readiness.
Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
