proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Identity Dominance System-Marine Corps (IDS-MC) is a multi-modal (fingerprint, iris, and face) biometric collection system that provides the USMC a reliable and effective capability to collect, share, match, access, verify and store identity information. IDS-MC will enable the Marine to collect appropriate biometric, biographical and reference information on an individual and match this locally developed information with pre-existing information available to the expeditionary force. The system will display match results with linkage to the respective individual's biographical and reference information as well as help analyze the response, update records as appropriate, create reports and disseminate updated information. The primary mission of IDS-MC is to provide the Marine Corps with the means to identify persons encountered in the battle space. While IDS-MC is not an intelligence analysis system, it does provide identification information in support of military intelligence and law enforcement operations by providing positive identification of persons of interest. IDS-MC is an enabler in the areas of detainee management and questioning, base access, counterintelligence screening, border control, law enforcement, displaced persons' management and aiding in humanitarian assistance missions. IDS-MC supports the tactical application of identity dominance and fully supports a forward presence, crisis response and contingency response capability.
The Expeditionary Forensic Exploitation Capability (EFEC) is a multi-modal (fingerprint, DNA, document, cellular, media, chemical, and fire arm) forensic collection system that provides the United States Marine Corps (USMC) a reliable and effective capability to recognize, protect, collect, analyze, store and share forensic information. This organic Marine Corps forensic capability supports deployed Marine Forces with agile, ruggedized, and scalable expeditionary forensics that are compatible and fully integrated with joint, other service, and interagency laboratories, yet also tailored to the unique operating requirements of the maritime domain. Maritime applications include the ability to support Marine Expeditionary Units with an at sea forensic exploitation capability to conduct vessel boarding and ship search operations. EFEC supports the Information Environment through sensitive forensic testing and analysis that positively identifies personnel and trace chemicals/elements; forensically exploits document and media; and scientifically links identities and networks to places, events, and activities. EFEC increment 2 will provide a transformative capability that integrates Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning to enable intelligence operations, force protection, intelligence, targeting, and law enforcement activities.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Prior to FY19, IDS-MC funding is included in BLI 6438, Physical Security Equipment.
FY 2019: $0.971M
Identity Dominance System-MC (IDS-MC): $0.971M to initiate procurement of the hardware and software for IDS-MC Increment 2 in accordance with a MS C/Full Rate Production procurement decision. Realignment of effort from BLI 6438 to 4652 in FY19 and beyond reflects USMC Program Management Office (PMO) reorganization to improve support of USMC Operating Forces (OPFOR).
FY 2020: $4.945M
Identity Dominance System-MC (IDS-MC): $4.945M will procure system Hardware and Software for IDS-MC Increment 2. IDS-MC Increment 2 is a multi-modal identity system that provides the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) the ability to collect, match, store, and share biometric data in support of operations. The IDS-MC program strategy is evolutionary, structured to deliver capabilities incrementally, recognizing the need for future capability improvements.
FY 2021 Baseline Appropriation Request: $1.006M
Identity Dominance System-MC (IDS-MC): $1.006M will complete procurement of system hardware and software for IDS-MC Increment 2. This will also finish a three-year procurement. IDS-MC Increment 2 is a multi-modal identity system that provides the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) the ability to collect, match, store, and share biometric data in support of operations. The decrease of $3.939M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the completion of the IDS-MC Increment 2 procurement.
OCO: FY21 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: $4.200M
Expeditionary Forensic Exploitation Capability (EFEC): $4.200M supports the incremental reset of legacy and obsolete EFEC equipment in direct support of Operation Freedom's Sentinel and Operation Inherent Resolve. Funding procures EFEC forensic equipment and associated software, COTS exploitation devices, chemical detection systems and peripherals that enable forensic exploitation.

proc:Name.footnote: IDS-MC: The decrease of $0.925M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the completion of the IDS-MC Increment 2 procurement.
IDS-MC: The decrease of $3.014M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the completion of the IDS-MC Increment 2 procurement.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Funding supports the procurement of communication and electrical items such as cameras, reproduction equipment, laptops, software, satellite dishes, and items/upgrades with a unit cost under $5M in support of the Marine Corps.
Combat Camera Systems (CCS) - Provides imagery acquisition and visual information production capabilities to the Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) Fleet Marine Force (FMF) units, supporting establishments and training commands. Equipment fielded is used to acquire still and video visual information, produce and disseminate communication products to support the MAGTF, Department of Defense (DoD), and Joint Forces. Procurements are centrally managed and are non-developmental, Commercial/Government Off-the-Shelf (COTS/GOTS) equipment. Combat Camera and Public Affairs Occupational Fields (OccField) transitioned into the COMMSTRAT OccField in 2018, with an increase to overall structure, personnel, equipment and a need for an increased capability to support the information environment being identified. In support of this Combat Camera System (CCS) and Public Affairs Systems (PAS) will transition to a single program of record by FY22 and will be referred to as Digital Media Systems (DMS). DMS will continue with already established sustainment efforts to support currently fielded equipment through its lifecycle as research, procurement, testing and integration of future equipment sets are being solidified. DMS will provide a capability to acquire and produce still/video visual information products, research and plan communication initiatives, produce and disseminate communication products, and assess the effects of communication initiatives within the information environment in various formats. As efforts continue components from CCS and PAS legacy systems will serve as a baseline for future equipment. A Requirement Memorandum was signed and received July 2019 in support of DMS
Public Affairs System (PAS) - Provides the capability to support research and plan communication initiatives, acquire still and video visual information, produce and disseminate communication products, and assess the effects of communication initiatives within the information environment. Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) Marines enable commanders at all levels across the range of military operations to engage domestic and foreign publics whose trust, confidence, and understanding are mission critical. The program uses a continued evolutionary approach to acquisitions while leveraging commercial industry-standard non-developmental items to provide the best value to Marine Corps efforts within the information environment. Combat Camera and Public Affairs Occupational Fields (OccField) transitioned into the COMMSTRAT OccField in 2018, with an increase to overall structure, personnel, equipment and a need for an increased capability to support the information environment being identified. In support of this Combat Camera System (CCS) and Public Affairs Systems (PAS) will transition to a single program of record by FY22 and will be referred to as Digital Media Systems (DMS). DMS will continue with already established sustainment efforts to support currently fielded equipment through its lifecycle as research, procurement, testing and integration of future equipment sets are being solidified. DMS will provide a capability to acquire and produce still/video visual information products, research and plan communication initiatives, produce and disseminate communication products, and assess the effects of communication initiatives within the information environment in various formats. A Requirement Memorandum was signed and received July 2019 in support of DMS. As efforts continue components from CCS and PAS legacy systems will serve as a baseline for future equipment.
Marine Civil Information Management System (MARCIMS) - MARCIMS is a system of systems comprised of people, process and technology that operates in the full Joint, Interagency, Intergovernmental, and Multinational (JIIM) environment. It is a force multiplier which allows the Commander to leverage the process of Planning, Collection, Consolidation, Analysis, Production, and sharing of civil information to support the visualization and understanding of the civil environment to the military Commander's decision making process. Program name has changed from Civil Affairs Capability Set and Civil Affairs Information Data Processing System (CIMDPS).
Military Information Support Operations (MISO) Family of Systems (FOS), which consists of the Fly-Away Broadcast System (FABS)variants are heavy, medium and light, Next-Generation Loud Speaker (NGLS), Radio-In-A-Box (RIAB), and Marine Corps SOF Integration Node (MSIN), provides the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Commander the ability to plan, develop, deliver and assess messages and actions to influence select foreign groups and promote themes to change those groups' attitudes and reduce civilian interference, minimize collateral damage, and increase the population's support for MAGTF operations. The MISO was established in response to multiple Marine Requirements Oversight Council Memorandums, and the approval of a MISO Organizational and Operational (O&O) Concept, 16 June 2015. MISO capabilities are critical to the success of the MAGTF mission, enabling commanders to shape the information environment, counter enemy propaganda, misinformation, disinformation, and adversarial narratives.
The Signature Management (SIGMAN) capability will support MAGTF Operations with a baseline capability to include blue-force electromagnetic signature monitoring, assessment and projection. SIGMAN will be utilized by the Marine Corps Information Operations Center (MCIOC) SIGMAN platoon to provide commanders the ability to understand their own forces electrometric signatures and the ability to disrupt or deceive adversary units. Prior to FY21, SIGMAN was funded within the Military Information Support Operations (MISO) Family of Systems (FOS) portfolio.
Safety: Risk Management Information (RMI) initiative to deploy a Department of Navy (DON)-wide, web based solution facilitating unit-level Safety Program management and provides aggregate reporting, analysis, and tracking of all hazards and reportable mishaps. IAW 2011 Federal Cloud Computing Strategy and guidance by the DON Chief Information Officer, RMI will involve the fielding of an overarching, single site safety portal or architecture critical for complying with OSD safety reporting requirements and for allowing seamless on-demand access to the pool of existing safety and safety-related databases.
MAGTF Logistics Support Systems (MLS2) - Transportation Systems Portfolio (TSP) are the current and future LOG IT capabilities used primarily to provide logistics support to the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) from garrison, operating bases, the sea base, and during expeditionary operations ashore. TSP enables tactical and operational level Life Cycle Management (LCM) and Command and Control (C2). MLS2s provides the MAGTF the capability to capitalize on Naval Logistics Integration and interoperate with joint and coalition logistics partners and providers. MLS2 provides the Information Technology (IT) systems essential for transportation and distribution operations in accordance with US Transportation Command's (USTRANSCOM) Defense Transportation Regulation (DTR). The systems identified provide the data and interfaces required to provide end-to-end (E2E) integration of distribution support to expedite the flow of equipment and supplies for the Operating Forces. Includes: (1) synchronizing storage activities, distribution nodes, and transportation modes in the logistics chain, (2) integrating organic Service, DoD and commercial providers and transportation systems, (3) maximizing in-transit visibility capabilities to track, trace, and expedite equipment and supplies, and (4) placing advocates to support force deployment, sustainment, and retrograde operations.
Enterprise Logistics Support Systems (ELS2) - Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) devices encompass a variety of read and write data storage technologies that are used to improve accuracy, timeliness, and handling. These technologies are key in and provide near-real time Total Asset Visibility data used to influence critical decisions by Operational Commanders. RFID enhances our force in readiness by coordinating, synchronizing and automatically transferring data by means of Active Radio Frequency Identification (aRFID), as well as the software required to create and manage the devices, collect the information and integrate that information with other logistics data. These devices can be interrogated using a variety of means, including fixed infrastructures and portable systems. The information obtained from those interrogations is provided electronically to various Automated Information Systems (AIS) in accordance with US Transportation Command's (USTRANSCOM) Defense Transportation Regulation (DTR). The RFID project provides procurement and life cycle management of the current RFID Infrastructures, and provides RFID Hardware and Software under the Joint Army Product Lead Automated Movement and Identification Solutions (PL AMIS) Procurement Office. Prior to FY18, RFID was funded within the MLS2 portfolio.
Combat Optics - This program encompasses all optical systems providing handheld, helmet, and weapon-mounted optic systems such as various thermal, low light image intensifier (I2) - to include night vision goggles (NVGs), magnified optical, laser range-finding, illuminating, short wave infrared (SWIR), and pointer functionalities. Thermal imagers can be used not only for target detection and engagement with Marine Corps individual and crew-served weapons, they can be used for all-weather surveillance as well. Combat Optics allow the dismounted Marine the ability to acquire, locate, identify, and engage targets during daylight and limited visibility conditions, and perform navigation and manual tasks during limited visibility conditions utilizing ambient or covert illumination. The SBNVG is a capability that will be provided to each Marine Rifle Team and will enable the ability to detect, recognize, and engage targets during limited visibility, thereby increasing lethality and the probability of mission success particularly in extremely low light levels, weather, and obscurants. The Squad Combat Optic (SCO) is a variable-power rifle sight designed for use with all infantry service rifles. The SCO will replace the current Rifle Common Optic (RCO) and provides combat Marines an enhanced targeting capability to identify and engage daylight and near low-light targets during close quarters combat out to the maximum effective range of the M27 Infantry Automatic Rifle. Both the SBNVG and SCO are critical for Marine survivability and lethality in ground combat element missions. The program coordinates with United States Uniformed Services on optic, thermal, and night vision technologies.
Manpower Operations Systems (MOS) is a portfolio of enterprise IT systems and modules that support manpower business operations for the Total Force (active and reserve). The investment in the portfolio improves dataflow and increases reliability, functionality, and accuracy of data while reducing the manpower required to operate and maintain these systems/operations. Development is partially driven by regulatory and policy changes mandated by Congress, DOD, Department of the Navy (DON), and United States Marine Corps (USMC). These systems support all five tiers of Manpower: 1) Individual Marine, 2)Small Unit Leader; 3) Unit, 4) Installation Personnel Administration Center (IPAC)/Disbursing Echelon, and 5) Headquarters Marine Corps (HQMC) Manpower and Reserve Affairs (M&RA)/Defense Finance and Accounting Service. The MOS portfolio provides support in functional areas such as permanent change of station assignments, retention, mobilization, manpower planning, line of duty determination, personnel accountability, individual augmentation, personnel records management and maintenance, management of case incidents, civilian professional development planning, pay entitlement determinations, promotion and performance evaluations and self-service/visibility of personnel data. MOS programs interface with other systems to provide manpower data and web services functionality for pay and personnel transactions between systems. Systems in the portfolio include the Web-enabled Manpower Assignment Support System (WebMASS), Automated Performance Evaluation System (APES), Total Force Retention System (TFRS), Optical Digital Imaging - Records Management System (ODI-RMS), Marine Corps Force Augmentation System (MCFAPS), Secure Personnel Accountability (SPA) and the Requirements, Transition and Manpower Management System (RTAMMS). The current systems have become obsolete and are unable to maintain an acceptable Cyber Security posture. Modernization efforts will involve business process and application reengineering, with a focus on redefining the Human Resource Development Process (HRDP) to deliver a portfolio of streamlined capabilities on a modern and secure platform.
Test, Evaluation,& Engineer Environment (TEEE)- Marine Corps Tactical Systems Support Activity (MCTSSA) provides the only Marine Corps operationally relevant, Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Command, Control, Communications, Computers, and Intelligence (C4I) architecture environment for enterprise-level testing, engineering, analysis, troubleshooting, and solutions. This environment, designated as a Special Purpose Processing Node (SPPN), provides Link-16 Tactical Data Link Networks for air-to-air, ship and shore targeting and messaging, validated at MCTSSA before Marine/Navy use in theater. Funding procures annual equipment required to recapitalize and modernize the MAGTF environment. Equipment includes, but is not limited to, Communications Backbone, Network Backbone, Tactical Cloud Integration Backbone, Test and Engineer Tool/Data Collection Hardware/Software, and Computers. Equipment supports testing for all phases in programs' acquisition lifecycle. The environment is essential to operating forces support for fielded C4I systems, as well as evaluating USMC and Joint C4I systems in a controlled, repeatable, and re-configurable manner that reduces program risk and identifies significant deficiencies prior to fielding to the operating forces. More than forty Marine Corps C4I programs and systems rely on MCTSSA support. Purchased equipment is sustained with Operations & Maintenance (O&M) funding.
Item Unique Identification (IUID) - Provides the necessary hardware to exploit an IUID enabled ground fleet inventory of equipment and material. This capability will allow for the identification and tracking of tangible items by using the Unique Item Identifiers (UIIs) used globally as a common key. IUID will improve logistics functions for operational commanders, program managers, equipment accountability managers, maintainers and force planners, as well as, ensure accurate systems valuation to support a clean financial audit.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATIONS PROGRAM (MCIOP) provides MAGTF commanders and the Marine Corps a responsive and effective full-spectrum Information Operations (IO) planning and psychological operations delivery capability by means of deployable support teams and comprehensive general support IO reach-back capability in order to integrate IO across the range of military operations within the physical, informational and cognitive dimensions of the information environment in a Service, Joint or Coalition setting. Transitioned from BLIs 4631 and 4635 in FY19.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $67.314M ($67.266M Active; $.048M Reserve)
Combat Camera Systems (CCS) $2.264M - In FY19 funding supported the procurement of Expeditionary Deployable Production Systems (EDPS) which equips Marines with a high-powered computing and processing capability to edit, store, retrieve, and transfer operational imagery in multiple formats. Increase of $0.708M from FY18 to FY19 supported the procurement of Tactical Imagery Production Suite (TIPS) components and initial support. TIPS enables extensively trained COMCAM documentation and production teams with increased capability to acquire, process, develop, reproduce, archive, distribute in hardcopy or multiple electronic formats digital still and motion media products as primary suppliers of operational imagery reinforcing distributive operations. TIPS also provided support for initially fielded systems to support the five to seven year refresh lifecycle. Due to the OccField change, in FY23, the Combat Camera System (CCS) and Public Affairs Systems (PAS) Program of Record will modernize into Digital Media System (DMS). These increases and changes result in the demand for more equipment and capabilities to support both the legacy CCS and PAS programs as well as DMS.
Public Affairs System (PAS) $2.427M ($2.379M Active; $0.048M Reserves) - Funding provided in support of the AAO increase for Public Affairs Contend Creation Systems (PACCS) Next Generation of digital camera system in order to support equipment modernization and obsolescence life cycle. PACCS provides image and video acquisition and editing capabilities for active and reserve component commands. Funding procured 2 Public Affairs Live Media Engagement System (PALMES) and modernization of currently fielded PALMES. PALMES provides MAGTF and Supporting Establishment commanders the capability to transmit approved Public Affairs products, such as high resolution video and to conduct live television and media interviews via satellite. The Combat Camera and Public Affairs MOSes modernized into the Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) MOS. Due to this Occupational Field change, in FY23, the Combat Camera Systems and Public Affairs Systems Programs of Record will modernize into Digital Media Systems (DMS). Due to this change, the PACCS nomenclature will change to the Photo Editing System Light (PESL).
Marine Civil Information Management System (MARCIMS) $0.296M - Funding supported the procurement of mobile devices, mobile devices management licenses, and peripherals as part of the MARCIMS refresh cycle. MARCIMS mobile devices are refreshed every two years. This capability supports real-world operations and overseas contingencies requiring a civil military presence, such as humanitarian assistance and disaster relief operations.
Military Information Support Operations (MISO) Family of Systems (FOS) $2.976M - Procured the MISO equipment such as Next-Generation Loud Speaker (NGLS), Radio-In-A-Box (RIAB), and Marine Corps SOF Integration Node (MSIN) and initial support, which provides the MAGTF Commander the capability to conduct planned operations to convey selected information and indicators to foreign adversary, neutral and friendly target audiences to influence their emotions, motives, objective reasoning, providing an operational advantage. FY19 also funded Signature Management (SIGMAN) equipment to provide a capability to include Own-force signature monitoring and assessment, Electromagnetic signature masking and projection, and physical decoys.
Combat Optics - $57.739M - FY19 funding completed the procurement of the Sniper Range Finder (SRF), and continued the procurement of both the Squad Thermal System (STS) and the Squad Binocular Night Vision Goggle (SBNVG) capability. The SRF enables the scout sniper and infantry squad leader to determine range out to the maximum effective range of Marine Corps weapons. The STS provides an individual thermal imaging capability of the Marine Rifle Squad and the Marine Reconnaissance Team while engaging in offensive and defensive operations. The STS will be employed as a weapon mounted clip-on thermal sight that can be used in conjunction with the AN/PVQ-31 A/B RCO, and also serves as a lightweight, pocket-sized hand-held thermal imager. This will enable fire team leaders and reconnaissance team leaders to detect and recognize potential targets, danger areas, and items of interest. Marines will be able to employ the STS during most atmospheric and lighting conditions, including total darkness. The Squad Binocular Night Vision Goggle (SBNVG) is a helmet-mounted or handheld, battery-operated Night Vision Goggle (NVG) capability that combines the capabilities of Image-Intensification (I2) and Thermal Imaging. The SBNVG will be provided to each Marine Rifle Team and will enable the ability to detect, recognize, and engage targets during limited visibility, thereby increasing lethality and the probability of mission success (particularly in extremely low light levels, weather, and obscurants).
Manpower Operations Systems (MOS) - $0.246M FY19 funding supported procurement of IT hardware, software and fielding support for the systems in the MOS portfolio.
TEST, EVALUATION, & ENGINEERING ENVIRONMENT - EQUIPMENT & TECHNICAL SERVICES (T&E) - $0.748M purchases centrally managed/itemized equipment that supports modernization and expansion of the MAGTF Systems Integration Environment at MCTSSA. This includes, but is not limited to, Communications Backbone, Network Backbone, Tactical Cloud Integration Backbone, Test and Engineer Tool/Data Collection Hardware/Software, and Computers. Equipment supports testing for all phases in the acquisition lifecycle.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATIONS PROGRAM (MCIOP) - FY19 $0.382M Funds supported a variety of efforts related to the Marine Corps Information Operations Center(MCIOC). Combined Unit Exercise (CUX) expansion: the CUX is currently being certified as the sole Joint Information Operations (IO) exercise in the Department of Defense. This funding was used to purchase additional non-Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) computer assets to be be operated on a closed, exercise-only network. Voice Over Internet Protocol (VOIP) Transition: Servers and telephones; the MCIOC currently utilizes Secure Terminal Equipment (STE) telephones for non-secure telephone calls. The STE telephones were originally envisioned to provide an additional secure voice capability no longer meeting mission requirements. The transition to VOIP telephones will provided a more user-friendly telephone capability centrally configured by network administrators to maintain Operational Security. Lifecycle Open Source Intelligence System (OSIS) and Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System (JWICS) replacement systems: The MCIOC is responsible for purchasing our own computer assets and equipment for the OSIS and JWICS networks. This funding line was allocated towards replacement systems as existing systems reach the end of their service life.
Enterprise Logistics Support Systems (ELS2) - FY19 $0.236M funding supported the installs and continued purchase of Iridium Modems and Field Data Units for the transition of aRFID dial up to Marine Corps to PL AMIS Army. This effort provides in-transit visibility (ITV) for cargo shipments throughout the world. Additionally, this provides commanders with an overall strategic picture of the current status of their shipments.
FY 2020: $80.349M ($80.300M Active; $0.049 Reserve)
Combat Camera Systems (CCS) - $3.463M: In FY20 funding supports the procurement of TIPS refresh, and additional Expeditionary Deployable Production Systems (EDPS) components which equips Marines with a high-powered computing and processing capability to edit, store, retrieve, and transfer operational imagery in multiple formats. The Occupational Field modernization resulted in an increase to structure, personnel, and capability to support concepts of employment in the Information Environment. The Combat Camera and Public Affairs OccFields transitioned into Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) OccField in 2018. Due to this transition Combat Camera Systems and Public Affairs Systems Program of Record will transition into Digital Media System (DMS) by FY22. These increases and changes result in the demand for more equipment and capabilities to support both the legacy CCS and PAS programs as well as DMS.
Public Affairs System (PAS) - $0.691M ($0.642M Active; $0.049M Reserves): Funding provides for the continued procurement of Public Affairs Content Creation System (PACCS) Next Generation of digital camera system in order to support equipment modernization and obsolescence life cycle. PACCS Next Generation had a nomenclature change to Visual Information Acquisition System this system provides image and video acquisition and editing capabilities for active and reserve component commands. Funding procures one PALMES spare and continues modernization efforts of currently fielded PALMES. PALMES provides MAGTF and Supporting Establishment commanders the capability to transmit approved Public Affairs products, such as high-resolution video and to conduct live television and media interviews via satellite. The Combat Camera and Public Affairs OccFields transitioned into Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) OccField in 2018. Due to this transition change Combat Camera Systems and Public Affairs Systems Program of Record will transition into Digital Media System (DMS) by FY22.
Military Information Support Operations (MISO) Family of Systems (FOS) - $6.289M Increase of $3.313M from FY19 to FY20 supports the procurement of long lead items for the Fly-Away Broadcast System (FABS) variants Heavy, medium, light under a phased AAO procurement approach and the continuing procurement of MISO equipment such as Next-Generation Loud Speaker (NGLS), Radio-In-A-Box (RIAB), and Marine Corps SOF Integration Node (MSIN) and initial support, which provides the MAGTF Commander the capability to conduct planned operations to convey selected information and indicators to foreign adversary, neutral and friendly target audiences to influence their emotions, motives, objective reasoning, providing an operational advantage. FY20 also funds procurement of Signature Management (SIGMAN) commercial off-the-shelf equipment to provide a capability to include Own-force signature monitoring and assessment, Electromagnetic signature masking and projection, and physical decoys.
TEST, EVALUATION, & ENGINEERING ENVIRONMENT - EQUIPMENT & TECHNICAL SERVICES (T&E) - $0.903M funding buys centrally managed/itemized equipment that supports modernization and expansion of the MAGTF Systems Integration Environment at MCTSSA. This includes, but is not limited to, Communications Backbone, Network Backbone, Tactical Cloud Integration Backbone, Test and Engineer Tool/Data Collection Hardware/Software, and Computers. Equipment supports testing for all phases in the acquisition lifecycle. The increase of $0.155M from FY19 to FY20 allows MCTSSA to incorporate upgrades to critical lab network infrastructure which will replicate representative MAGTF architectures, implement a deployed cloud testing environment, modernize MCEN Planning Yard infrastructure, support a collaborative enterprise effort to test, and engineer the MCEN from a performance, security, and resiliency aspect. It also provides improvements to our Naval Integration infrastructure which will enhance our ability to provide enterprise-level tactical and garrison networking/software application support, as well as modernize the virtualization stacks of Consolidated Afloat Network and Enterprise Services (CANES), Integrated Shipboard Network System (ISNS), and Automated Digital Network System (ADNS).
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATIONS PROGRAM (MCIOP) - FY20 $0.371M funding refurbishes MCIOC's A/V system. Funding refreshes classified VTC capability to better support the growing operational requirements of deployed teams and updates the infrastructure to better support the Deputy Commandant for Information's requirement to coordinate operations in the Information Environment across the Marine Corps.
Enterprise Logistics Support Systems (ELS2) - $0.210M: FY20 funding supports the installs and continued purchase of Iridium Modems and Field Data Units for the transition of aRFID dial up to Marine Corps to PL AMIS Army. This effort provides in-transit visibility (ITV) for cargo shipments throughout the world. Additionally, this provides commanders with an overall strategic picture of the current status of their shipments.
Combat Optics - $68.422M: funding procures three major warfighting capabilities, the Squad BNVG (SBNVG), Squad Thermal System (STS), and Squad Common Optic (SCO). The SBNVG is a helmet-mounted or handheld, battery-operated Night Vision Goggle (NVG) that combines the capabilities of Image-Intensification (I2) and Thermal Imaging. The SBNVG is a capability that will be provided to each Marine Rifle Team and will enable the ability to detect, recognize, and engage targets during limited visibility, thereby increasing lethality and the probability of mission success particularly in extremely low light levels, weather, and obscurants. The increase of funding for SBNVG in FY20 provides this enhanced warfighting capability to additional infantry battalions in support of fielding priorities. FY20 funding procures the entire Squad Thermal System (STS) AAO. The STS provides an individual thermal imaging capability to the Marine Rifle Squad and the Marine Reconnaissance Team while engaging in offensive and defensive operations. The STS will be employed as a weapon mounted clip-on thermal sight that can be used in conjunction with the AN/PVQ-31 A/B and M7 Rifle Combat Optics (RCO), and also serves as a lightweight, pocket-sized hand-held thermal imager. FY20 funding supports initial procurement of the Squad Common Optic (SCO) which replaces the Rifle Combat Optic (RCO) with a variable-powered rifle sight designed for use with all 5.56mm service rifles. It will provide the Marine with an enhanced targeting capability to identify and engage daylight and near low-light targets during close quarters combat and throughout the maximum effective range of the weapon system.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $69.725M ($69.690 Active; $0.035 Reserve)
The reduction of $10.624M from FY20 to FY21 is primarily due to completion of procurements for the Combat Camera Systems TIPS refresh cycle, Rifle Combat Optics Modernization, and Squad Thermal systems achieving AAO requirements.
Combat Optics - $50.492M: a decrease of $17.930M from FY20 to FY21 is due to STS completion of the AAO procurement in FY20. FY21 funding will support two major procurement efforts, $34.183M for the continued procurement of the Squad Binocular Night Vision Goggle (SBNVG) and $15.876M for the continued procurement of the Squad Common Optic (SCO).
Combat Camera Systems (CCS) $0.429M: a decrease of $3.034M from FY20 to FY21 realigns funds to support higher priority Marine Corps efforts, shifting program focus to audiovisual communication requirements. $0.429M will procure DMS equipment sets for the COMMSTRAT community to acquire and produce still/video visual information products, research and plan communication initiatives, produce and disseminate communication products, and assess the effects of communication initiatives within the information environment. Equipment sets will replace systems for the Expeditionary Combat Photography and Video systems which enable Marines with still and video imagery capability in day or low-light conditions, imagery processing and storage, and production and transfer capability in support of audiovisual communication requirements. The Combat Camera and Public Affairs OccFields transitioned into Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) OccField in 2018. Due to this transition change Combat Camera Systems and Public Affairs Systems Program of Record will transition into Digital Media System (DMS) by FY22.
Public Affairs System (PAS) - $0.694M ($0.659M Active: $0.035M Reserve): an increase of $0.003M from FY20 to FY21 is due to continued procurement of DMS equipment. Funds will be for the procurement of a hardware/software solution to support research and plan communication initiatives, assess the effects of communication initiatives within the information environment, and provide software to work with PALMES transmission capability to refresh the Public Affairs Laptop (PAL). The PAL is provided to research the information environment, conduct media and social media engagements, and review communications products. The Combat Camera and Public Affairs OccFields transitioned into Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) OccField in 2018. Due to this transition change Combat Camera Systems and Public Affairs Systems Program of Record will transition into Digital Media System (DMS) by FY22.
Marine Civil Information Management System (MARCIMS)- $0.302; Increase of $0.302 from FY20 to FY21 supports the procurement of mobile devices, mobile devices management licenses, and peripherals as part of the MARCIMS refresh cycle of every-other-year. This capability supports real-world operations and overseas contingencies that require a civil military presence, such as humanitarian assistance and disaster relief operations.
Military Information Support Operations (MISO) Family of Systems (FOS) - $4.987M; Decrease of $1.302 from FY20 to FY21 reflects the transition of Signature Management (SIGMAN) funding out of the MISO budget and into a separate funding profile. FY21 funds will support the continued AAO phased procurement of Fly-Away Broadcast System (FABS) variants heavy, medium, and light as well as MISO equipment such as Radio-In-A-Box (RIAB), and Marine Corps SOF Integration Node (MSIN). This will allow for influence to select foreign groups and promote themes to change those groups' attitudes and reduce civilian interference, minimize collateral damage, and increase the population's support for MAGTF operations.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATIONS PROGRAM (MCIOP) - FY21 $0.378M; The increase of $0.007M from FY20 to FY21 will be due to the support of real-time Information Operations (IO). Funding will support command post systems enhancements specific to the information environment. PAI enhancements include additional licenses for PAI analysis tools which will assist in operationalizing the MIGs and their ability to monitor, assess, and evaluate social networks. These enhancements will support the growing operational requirements of deployed teams and enable coordination of operations in the information environment; specific enhancements include command and control of the information environment. (C2IE), the Joint Information Operations Range (JIOR), and publically available information analysis.
Signature Management (SIGMAN) - $5.716M; The increase of $1.916M from FY20 ($3.800M under MISO) to FY21 will reflect the initial procurement of electromagnetic signature emitter devices and SIGMAN equipment toward the Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) along with associated support. Funding will provide for the continued procurement of the commercial off-the-shelf equipment to provide the initial capability to include blue-force electromagnetic signature monitoring and assessment. SIGMAN will be utilized by the Marine Corps Information Operations Center (MCIOC) SIGMAN platoon to provide commanders with the ability to understand their own forces' electromagnetic signatures and the ability to disrupt or deceive adversary units. Prior to FY21, SIGMAN was funded within the Military Information Support Operations (MISO) Family of Systems (FOS) portfolio.
Enterprise Logistics Support Systems (ELS2) - $0.755M; The increase of $0.545M from FY20 will support the installation and continued purchase of Iridium Modems and Field Data Units for the transition of aRFID dial up to Marine Corps to PL AMIS Army. Additionally, this increase in funding supports automation enhancements. This effort provides in-transit visibility (ITV) for cargo shipments throughout the world. Additionally, this system provides commanders with an overall strategic picture of the current status of their shipments.
TEST, EVALUATION, & ENGINEERING ENVIRONMENT - EQUIPMENT & TECHNICAL SERVICES (T&E) - $5.972M; The $5.069M increase from FY20 to FY21 will provide the following: $2.9M for recapitalization of current end-of-service/end-of-life equipment, $2.4M of MCEN planning yard equipment to include Enterprise Level interoperability and rollout of virtualization architecture in the environment, which will also recapitalize existing test facility's use of "Infrastructure as a Service," and $0.700M for required MAGTF Afloat and Naval equipment. More than (40) Marine Corps C4I programs and systems rely on Marine Corps Tactical Systems Support Activity (MCTSSA) support and their ability to conduct relevant and able testing, evaluation, and engineering solutions. MCTSSA provides the only Marine Corps organic, operationally relevant, MAGTF Command, Control, Communications, Computers, and Intelligence (C4I) architecture for enterprise-level testing, engineering, analysis, troubleshooting, and solutions.

proc:Name.footnote: CCS - Funding will procure DMS equipment sets for the COMMSTRAT community to acquire and produce still/video visual information products, research and plan communication initiatives, produce and disseminate communication products, and assess the effects of communication initiatives within the information environment in various formats. The overall decrease of $3.034M reflects the realignment of funding to higher priority Marine Corps efforts and a shifting program focus to audiovisual communications requirements.

CCS: Tactical Imagery Production System Version 3 (TIPS V3) is a system which enables extensively trained COMMSTRAT documentation and production teams with increased capability to acquire, process, develop, reproduce, archive, distribute in hardcopy or varying electronic formats of visual information products. TIPS V3 is the primary deployable asset that provides the still, motion, reproduction and temporary storage equipment set; initially fielded in 2014 with a proposed lifecycle of 7-10 years. These sets require earlier fielded assets to have components refreshed to ensure asset is serviceable until scheduled refresh of entire system is completed.
CCS: Funding supports the procurement of EDPS components.

The Combat Camera and Public Affairs OccFields transitioned into Communication Strategy and Operations (COMMSTRAT) OccField in 2018. Due to this transition change Combat Camera Systems and Public Affairs Systems Program of Record will transition into Digital Media System (DMS) by FY22. Due to this change, the PACCS refresh nomenclature will change to the Visual Information Acquisition System (VIAS). Funds will be for the procurement of a hardware/software solution to support research and plan communication initiatives, assess the effects of communication initiatives within the information environment and provide software to work with PALMES transmission capability to refresh the Public Affairs Laptop (PAL).

MARCIMS - The increase of $0.302 from FY20 to FY21 to support the procurement of mobile devices, mobile device management licenses, and peripherals as part of the MARCIMS refresh cycle of every-other-year. This capability supports real-world operations and overseas contingencies that require a civil military presence, such as humanitarian assistance and disaster relief operations.
The increase of $0.545M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the initial procurement of electromagnetic signature emitter devices and SIGMAN equipment toward the approved AAO along with associated support.

Combat Optics: RCO modernization will conclude with the fielding of the SCO in FY21. The unit cost increase is based on the most recent pricing estimate from the source of supply for this equipment and the increase in quantity does not meet the next step ladder pricing increment.

Combat Optics: Unit cost for STS in FY20 is based on cost estimate provided by Army's program office based on the step ladder pricing construct and the Army planned quantity. Program is procuring on Army contract.
Annual production rates for the Squad Thermal System are estimates of the manufacturing capacity for the entire inter-service contract, of which the Marine Corps is a small component.
Combat Optics: Unit price on the SCO is projected to increase 3% per year.
Contract will be competively awarded. Annual production rates for SCO production is based on RFI responses and market research
Combat Optics: Unit price based on firm fixed priced MCSC contract. The increase of $4.932M represents the purchase of additional end items in FY21.
SBNVG MCSC Contract: Production rates are based on full and open contract award.
SBNVG Hardware costs in FY20-FY21 increase due to initial production and increases again in FY24 due to additional items needed prior to contract closeout.
The $5.069M increase is due to the recapitalization of EOS/EOL equipment, hardware procurement to support a virtualization architecture, and additional MAGTF afloat and Naval equipment.

FABS provides the ability to plan, develop, deliver and assess messages and actions to influence select foreign groups and promote themes to change those groups' attitudes and reduce civilian interference, minimize collateral damage, and increase the population's support for MAGTF operations.

SIGMAN equipment $3.800M decrease from FY20 to FY21 for the continued procurement of SIGMAN components for signature monitoring and assessment, EM signature masking and projection, and physical decoys. The total $3.800M transitioned to Cost Element 11.1 (See Footnote 13).

MISO: MISO Equipment increase of $0.293 from FY20 to FY21 reflects the procurement of items such as Radio-In-A-Box (RIAB), and Marine Corps SOF Integration Node (MSIN), which provides the MAGTF Commander the ability to plan, develop, deliver and assess messages and actions to influence select foreign groups and promote themes to change those groups' attitudes and reduce civilian interference, minimize collateral damage, and increase the population's support for MAGTF operations.

MCIOP: The increase of $0.007M from FY20 to FY21 reflects will support command post systems enhancements specific to the information environment. PAI enhancements include additional licenses for PAI analysis tools.
SIGMAN: In FY2021, Signature Management (SIGMAN) received its own cost element, previously funded in FY2020 under Military Information Support Operations (MISO) Family of Systems (FOS).

SIGMAN: Total Increase of $5.466M from FY20 to FY21. In FY20 SIGMAN was under Cost Element 9.2 for $3.800M. SIGMAN transitioned to Cost Element 11.1 in FY 21 and the total increase was $1.666M (Difference between CE9.2 and 11.1) reflecting the procurement of electromagnetic signature emitter devices and SIGMAN equipment toward the Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO).
SIGMAN: Increase of $0.250M from FY2020 ($0M under MISO) to FY2021 reflects associated support for FY21 planned procurements.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Joint Cooperative Target Identification-Ground (JCTI-G): The JCTI-G program will address four of the 26 capability gaps identified in the validated Combat ID - Friendly Force Tracker (CID-FFT) Joint Capabilities Document (JCD). A Jun 2010 JFCOM-led Analysis of Alternatives (AoA) concluded, and the USMC concurred, that pursuit of a new material solution and introduction of a new system would not be cost effective. This conclusion was based upon both cost and ability to address the four defined capability gaps in Combat Identification specific to reducing fratricide of U.S. and coalition forces. The AoA evaluated the currently Fielded and Planned Capability Improvements (FPCI) resident within funded projects and existing programs of records across all Services and determined that the most affordable alternative would leverage the FPCI programs by allocating the CID-FFT requirements and funding capability improvements within these existing programs. The AoA further concluded that, in addition to significant cost avoidance, leveraging the FPCI to meet the CID-FFT requirements, as opposed to establishing a new program of record material solution, would have greater impact and achieve a higher percentage of CID-FFT JCD capability gap closure by 2016. In support of a Jan 2010 Memorandum of Understanding between the Vice Chief of Staff of the Army and Assistant Commandant of the Marine Corps (which documents the Army and Marine Corps agreement to support closure of the Fires on Dismounts fratricide mitigation gap), the USMC refocused the program in June 2011 to begin allocation of CID-FFT JCD requirements to the USMC FPCI programs to meet this valid Joint Capabilities Integration and Development System (JCIDS) requirement. Having no previous CID-FFT requirement, these FPCI programs have neither planned for nor been resourced to support the additional requirements of the CID-FFT JCD. As a result of these events, this effort will ensure requirements allocation, traceability, and validation within 24 USMC FPCI programs in accordance with the CID-FFT JCD and JCIDS processes and provide resource funding as well as augment the workforce to support the additional unanticipated requirements being levied on FPCI programs. Additionally, it will support aggregation of a time-phased schedule of USMC CID-FFT capabilities and future interoperability engineering/testing between FPCI systems and related modernization efforts necessary to minimize costs and measure attainment of CID-FFT JCD capability gap closure by 2016. The AoA recommendation, accepted by the Services and OSD, is to maintain and enhance the full range of FPCI programs to meet the requirements and mitigate CID-FFT capability gaps identified in the CID-FFT JCD. The intent is to reduce fratricide, uphold the DOD and USMC position on JCTI-G, remain consistent with the AoA recommendations, comply with the purpose of JCTI-G appropriations, and support capability gap closure in accordance with the AoA and OSD led OIPT findings.
Composite Tracking Network (CTN) - The Composite Tracking Network (CTN) system distributes composite tracking data to Command and Control (C2) and weapon systems participating in a Cooperative Engagement Capability (CEC) network. The system will significantly contribute to real-time situational awareness. The program received ACAT III designation in Nov 2001 and is an instantiation of the USN CEC Program. The program is USMC led with US Navy and US Army cooperation. AAO: 10 systems plus 4 spares. The 12 April 1995 Mission Need Statement (MNS) No. AAS 48 for the Common Aviation Command and Control System (CAC2S) established the Marine Corps' need to upgrade its existing air defense architecture with capabilities to support improved situational awareness (SA) and advanced engagement concepts. The Composite Tracking Network (CTN) program was initiated to address this capability gap. The CTN system (AN/MSQ-143A(V)1) is an integration effort consisting of an AN/USG-4B and other Marine-unique components. All Marine-unique components are Government Furnished Equipment (GFE) with the exception of the shelter and mast. The components include: Vehicle - M1152A-1 (GFE Marine Corps Systems Command (MCSC), Trailer - M102 LTT-MCC (GFE MCSC), 10 KW Generator - MEP 803 (GFE MCSC), Tactical Radio - AN/MRC103 (GFE MCSC), Global Positioning System - DAGR (GFE MCSC), Environmental Control Unit - BOO03 (GFE MCSC), Shelter - S788 (COTS NSWC Crane), and Antenna Mast - TEAMS EXL 195/26-5.4 (COTS Naval Surface Warfare Center Crane). The CTN system interfaces with the AN/TPS-59 radar, the AN/TPS-80 Ground/Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR), and the CAC2S to provide the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) and Joint Task Force Commanders a ground based sensor netting solution that correlates sensor measurement data (target velocity and position) from local and remote radars that interface in the CEC network. This data will effectively increase Situational Awareness by providing accurate, composite, and real-time surveillance tracks, reduce ground-to-air and air-to-air fratricide, enable air and surface Integrated fire control (IFC), and extend the air defensive capability of forces in the littorals. Procurement of Common Array Block - Expeditionary (CAB-E) to replace obsolete Compact Solid State Antenna (CSSA).
Marine Air Command and Control (MACCS) - MACCS Family of Systems (FoS) is organized into tactical agencies and operational facilities, each having different functions, tasks, and equipment suites. These agencies are fielded and supported by squadrons within the Marine Air Control Group (MACG) in support of the Aviation Combat Element (ACE). The tactical agencies are: the Tactical Air Command Center (TACC), the Tactical Air Operations Center (TAOC), and the Direct Air Support Center (DASC). The core MACCS systems consist of: The AN/TYQ-23 Tactical Air Operations Module (TAOM); AN/TYQ-101 Communications Data Link System (CDLS); AN/MRQ-12(V)4 Communications Interface System (CIS); AN/TYQ-87(V)2 Sector Anti Air Warfare Facility; AN/UYQ-3B Direct Air Support Central/Airborne System (DASC/AS); and the AN/MSQ-124 Air Defense Communications Platform (ADCP). The MACCS FoS program office ensures that the TACC, TAOC, and DASC systems remain ready, relevant, and capable until Full Operational Capability (FOC) of Common Aviation Command and Control System (CAC2S).
Remote Video Viewing Terminal (RVVT) - RVVT provides the MAGTF the ability to receive, transmit, view, and manipulate full motion video and the associated metadata. RVVT also supports the ability to establish mesh and other advanced communications networks. The program consists of Video Down-Link (VDL) products such as the VideoScout Mobile Configuration 2 (VS-MC/2), VideoScout Mobile Configuration 3 (VS-MC/3), and Man Portable Video Down-Link (MPVDL) that allow for the viewing and exploitation of Full Motion Video (FMV) from Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) assets. VDL systems are mission critical for the coordination of direct and indirect fires and the prevention of fratricide. These systems provide the warfighter with video and metadata from all USMC manned and unmanned aircraft such as the Raven B, Puma, Micro-UAS, Shadow, Predator, Fire Scout, and Litening Pod on P-3, AV8-B, and F/A-18. Data is displayed to Forward Observers (FO), Joint Fires Observers (JFO), Joint Terminal Attack Coordinators (JTAC), and Forward Air Controller (FAC).
Theater Battle Management Core System (TBMCS) - Joint Force mandated Air War planning tool for the generation, dissemination, and execution of the Air Tasking Order (ATO). TBMCS is an Air Force led program, which provides the automated tools necessary to manage tactical air operations, execute area air defense and airspace management in the tactical area of operation, and coordinate operations with components of other military services. TBMCS is located at the Tactical Air Command Center (TACC), with remotes located throughout the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF). It is scalable, allowing for joint, coalition, and service specific operations. It was an Air Force-led evolutionary acquisition joint ACAT III program. The USAF now seeks a replacement for TBMCS by applying a Mid-tier acquisition approach (Section 804 of the FY 2016 NDAA). Its original solution, the Command and Control Air Operation System (C2AOS), has transitioned to the TBMCS Replacement. In order to prevent TBMCS legacy system hardware obsolescence and enable the ability to host the new TBMCS Replacement being delivered by the Air Force, the Marine Corps will align with the Air Force in its system development and procurement. This will keep Marine Aviation relevant and operational in a joint theater and maintain its ability to plan and manage Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Air Operations.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019 ($15.647):
Composite Tracking Network (CTN) $4.455M - Funds supported the procurement of three (3) Common Array Block - Expeditionary (CAB-E) antennas to replace the obsolete Compact Solid State Antenna (CSSA). This procurement is delayed to FY 2020 due to Navy experiencing a one year slip in the delivery of CAB systems. Funding was reallocated to support ECPs that addressed the upgrade of vital CTN components. CTN supported the Technical Refresh of CTN TEMPEST Laptops and the signal data processor-Sierra (SDP-S).
Marine Air Command and Control (MACCS) $0.050M - Funds supported the physical transition of Multifunctional Information Distribution System (MIDS) systems to be integrated into the Common Aviation Command and Control System (CAC2S) Full Deployment Units (FDU). MIDS are Link 16 Low Volume Terminals (LVT), which are required to support command, control, communications, computing and intelligence (C4I) as a part of CAC2S Full Deployment Units (0206335M).
Theater Battle Management Core System (TBMCS) $1.477M - Funding continued efforts such as on-site fielding representatives to support updated software and hardware fielding and the incremental procurement of new hardware for TBMCS to maintain cyber security accreditation as well as associated New Equipment Training (NET) in support of Maintenance Release Version 7 (MR7V).
Remote Video Viewing Terminal (RVVT) $9.665M - Funds procured hardware and ancillary equipment for the integration of the Full Motion Video capability into a user supported viewing platform.
FY 2020 ($17.408M):
Composite Tracking Network (CTN) $10.070M - Funds are to support the procurement of five (5) Common Array Block - Expeditionary (CAB-E) antennas and associated Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP). The CAB-E is replacing CTN's current obsolete Compact Solid State Antenna (CSSA). CTN will support NET and fielding for the signal data processor-Sierra SDP-S upgrades.
Marine Air Command and Control (MACCS) $0.000M - Funding has been decreased from $0.050 to $0.000 due to the program sun setting and no longer being funded.
Theater Battle Management Core System (TBMCS) $1.464M - In FY 2020 TBMCS will continue to support the incremental procurement of new hardware for TBMCS to sustain its cyber security accreditation. Funds will also be utilized to provide on-site fielding representatives to support the program's fielding of its annual Maintenance Releases which includes upgraded hardware, updated software, and support for New Equipment Training (NET).
Remote Video Viewing Terminal (RVVT) - $5.874M - Funds are being used to procure hardware to conduct a refresh of the battery and power management components of the Full Motion Video (FMV) capability. Decrease of $3.791M from FY 2019 to FY 2020 is due to the completion of procurement of battery cables.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation ($15.611M):
Composite Tracking Network (CTN) $14.301M - Funds will support the procurement of six (6) Common Array Block - Expeditionary (CAB-E) antennas and associated Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP), NET, and fielding. The CAB-E will replace the aging Compact Solid State Antenna (CSSA). The increase of $4.231 from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to additional quantity of (1) CAB-E antenna as well as full CAB-E IIP procurement in FY 2021, to support delivering systems.
Theater Battle Management Core System (TBMCS) $1.290M - Funding will continue efforts such as on-site fielding representatives to support updated software and hardware fielding and the incremental procurement of new hardware for TBMCS to maintain cyber security accreditation as well as associated NET in support of annual Maintenance Releases. The decrease of $0.171M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to a reduction of on-site fielding support in lieu of the development of a TBMCS Command & Control Replacement.
Remote Video Viewing Terminal (RVVT) - $0.020 - Funds will be used to continue procurement of FMV components for the battery and power management components of the FMV capability. Decrease of $5.854M is due to the completion of the hardware refresh supporting Full Motion Video (FMV) integration with viewing platforms.

proc:Name.footnote: FY 2019 Funds were to support the procurement of three (3) Common Array Block - Expeditionary (CAB-E) antennas to replace the obsolete Compact Solid State Antenna (CSSA). This procurement is delayed to FY 2020 due to Navy experiencing a one year slip in the delivery of CAB systems. Funding reallocated to support CTN tech refresh efforts and a priority DoD ATR. Planned procurement quantity of fourteen (14) (qty 10 plus 4 spares) remains unchanged. $1.527 increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is to procure Common Array Block - Expeditionary antennas to replace its aging Compact Solid State Antenna (CSSA).

$2.638 increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is to support an increase in scope for CAB-E Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP) to support the ramp up of CAB-E production and fielding in FY 2021. IIP is used to provision initial spares and repair parts for the new CAB-E production antennas, by identifying, selecting, and acquiring initial support items required for CAB-E.
$0.052M increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to ECPs associated with the integration of the Common Array Block - Expeditionary (CAB-E) antenna into CTN.

NET and Fielding supports CTN ECPs to modernize and align with the Navy Cooperative Engagement Capability (CEC). In FY 2020 CTN will support NET and fielding for the signal data processor-Sierra SDP-S upgrades. $0.14M Increase in fielding and New equipment Training (NET) cost from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to implementation of CAB-E and removal of CSSA.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Long Range Radar (AN/TPS-59) - The AN/TPS-59A(V)3 is a transportable, three dimensional, tactical radar system that provides the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) with long-range surveillance. It is the MAGTF's only ground based long range sensor that provides the capability to detect and report Air Breathing Targets (ABT) and track Theater Ballistic Missiles (TBM). The AN/TPS-59A(V)3 Radar System is connected to the Common Aviation Command and Control Systems (CAC2S). It provides the air defense controllers data and may be used autonomously to conduct Ground Control Intercept, tactical en-route Air Traffic Control (ATC), or TBM alert operations via the Joint Integrated Air Missile Defense (IAMD) encrypted Link-16. The USMC extended the AN/TPS-59 service life through 2035; therefore, in order to maintain its operational relevance on the battlefield, a number of readiness, obsolescence and modernization efforts will be required.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $6.694M
AN/TPS-59: $6.694M (Active: $2.312M, Reserve: $4.382M) - FY19 funding completes procurement of Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) Antenna; supports procurement of Digital Receiver and Exciter (DREX) logistics and training products such as Engineering Design Model (EDM) technical manuals and product data, and Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) such as Array Drive assembly and installation.
FY 2020: $0.329M
AN/TPS-59: $0.329M (Active: $0.329M) - Decrease of $6.365M from FY19 to FY20 reflects USMC decision to defer all modernization except the Identify Friend or Foe (IFF) Mode 5/S level 1 upgrade and upgrades specifically to prevent system obsolescence. $0.329M will support procurement and integration of ECP upgrades with multiple components and various unit costs to mitigate obsolescence and end-of life/end-of-sale issues.
FY2021 Base Appropriation Request: $0.000M
AN/TPS-59: $0.000M - Decrease of $0.329M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the Marine Corps concerted effort to modernize in accordance with the National Defense Strategy (NDS)/Defense Planning Guidance (DPG).

proc:Name.footnote: AN/TPS-59 ECP upgrades are comprised of multiple components with various unit costs to mitigate obsolescence and end-of life/end-of-sale issues. Decrease of $0.329M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the Marine Corps concerted effort to modernize in accordance with the National Defense Strategy (NDS)/Defense Planning Guidance (DPG).

proc:Item.proc:Name: 1.2) AN/TPS-59 DREX Logistics and Training Data

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Ground/Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR AN/TPS-80) - The Ground/Air Task Oriented Radar is a multi-role, ground-based, expeditionary radar that replaces five legacy radar systems for the Marine Air Ground Task Force. It satisfies the Marine Air Command and Control System (G/ATOR Block 1) and the Ground Counter Fire/Counter Battery (G/ATOR Block 2) capabilities. The G/ATOR replaces the AN/TPS-63 and complements the AN/TPS-59 long range radar and will provide mobile, multi-functional, three-dimensional surveillance of air breathing targets, detection of cruise missiles and Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS), and the cueing of air defense weapons. The G/ATOR contributes to the extension of Sea Shield/Sea Strike through surveillance and detection of enemy air threats not seen by Navy sensors in the littorals by participating in a cooperative engagement network of sensors and shooters; G/ATOR enables Integrated Fire Control (IFC) and provides engage/fire on remote capability. G/ATOR surveillance coverage with IFC will provide unprecedented reach, volume, and precision in the execution of Operational Maneuver From The Sea allowing Naval forces to project and sustain power deep inland. Prior year funding and quantities for the G/ATOR program can be found in BLI 4650 - Radar Systems.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019 $220.416M ($94.506M Active; $125.910M Reserves) AN/TPS-80 G/ATOR - FY19 funded the initial Full Rate Production (FRP) Lot of six (6) G/ATOR systems and provided logistic/program support associated with the procurement of systems, hardware, program management and logistics required for G/ATOR fielding related activities. The FY19 Active/Reserve breakdown cited here represents current funding levels post a realignment that is not yet reflected in the Secondary Distribution table on Pg 1.
FY 2020 $273.022M ($151.175M Active; $121.847M Reserves) AN/TPS-80 G/ATOR - FY20 funding procures eight (8) G/ATOR systems and provide logistic/program support associated with the procurement of systems, hardware, program management and logistics required for G/ATOR fielding related activities. The FY20 column of the FY21 submit has been updated based upon the award of G/ATOR's FRP Contract. The contract is Firm Fixed Price (FFP) with contractor Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM) embedded in the cost of the contract. The systems unit price savings reduces the total cost of 8 systems. The cost savings has been applied towards a one-time Diminishing Manufacture Sources/Non-Reccurring Engineering and Communication Equipment Group (CEG) Shelter Integration requirement covering known diminishing manufacturing sources/material shortages (DMS/MS) issues, the procurement of CEG shelters, the procurement of Power Equipment Group (PEG) Pallets, an increase to Logistics Support and Engineering Change Orders (ECO's) supporting Pallet Communications Support Processor (PCSP) and GB2 Hardware improvements with a focus on reducing Radar Emplacement/Displacement time.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request $284.283M ($284.283M Active; $0.0M Reserves) AN/TPS-80 G/ATOR - FY21 funding will procure eight (8) G/ATOR systems and provide logistic/program support associated with the procurement of systems, hardware, program management, and logistics required for G/ATOR fielding related activities. The increase in funding from FY20 to FY21 primarily reflects the procurement of Gallium Nitride (GaN) Retrofit Kits to modify three (3) Gallium Arnside (GaAS) LRIP Radars to the GaN configuration, the initiation of radar decoys procurement and the initiation of Depot stand-up activities, specifically, the procurement of the tooling for the G/ATOR Depot at Tobyhanna Army Depot.

proc:Name.footnote: System Unit Cost for FY19 changed from $29.839M to $31.477M based on G/ATOR FRP Contract Award. System Unit Cost for FY20 changed from $29.835M to $28.160M based on G/ATOR FRP Contract Award. System Unit Cost increase $0.269M ($28.160M to $28.429M) from FY20 to FY21 is due to inflation.
