SEPM is part of the System Unit Cost.

ECO funding addresses corrective actions from DT1E/IOT&E testing, as well as user community feedback to improve Human Systems Integration (HSI). ECO funding also reduces the number of material/electronic obsolesce issues and ultimately improves future Marine Forces readiness. FY19/20 ECOs include the Radome and Antenna Support Electronics Covers, GB2 IFF Removal/Manual Alignment, Pallet Communications Support Processor (PCSP) and GB2 Hardware improvements with a focus on reducing Radar Emplacement/Displacement time. The FY20 Active ECOs increase $0.734M from the FY20 request to the FY21 request to accelerate the Warfighter's desired improvements in Radar Emplacement/Displacement time. FY21 ECOs will continue Pallet Communications Support Processor (PCSP) and GB2 Hardware improvements efforts focusing on reducing Radar Emplacement/Displacement time.

ECO funding addresses corrective actions from DT1E/IOT&E testing, as well as user community feedback to improve Human Systems Integration (HSI). ECO funding also reduces the number of material/electronic obsolesce issues and ultimately improves future Marine Forces readiness. FY19/20 ECOs include the Radome and Antenna Support Electronics Covers, GB2 IFF Removal/Manual Alignment, Pallet Communications Support Processor (PCSP) and GB2 Hardware improvements with a focus on reducing Radar Emplacement/Displacement time. The FY20 Reserve ECOs increase $0.352M from the FY20 request to the FY21 request to accelerate the Warfighter's desired improvements in Radar Emplacement/Displacement time.

DMS/NRE & CEG Shelter Integration (Active) is a one-time purchase in FY20 covering all known diminishing manufacturing sources/material shortages (DMS/MS) issues. This is an update from the FY20 request.
DMS/NRE & CEG Shelter Integration is a one-time purchase in FY20 covering all known diminishing manufacturing sources/material shortages (DMS/MS) issues. This is an update from the FY20 request.

Funding supports Depot Facilitization (tooling) for Line Replaceable Unit (LRU) Repair and Inspect and Repair Only As Necessary (IROAN) activities at Tobyhanna Army Depot. FY21 begins the IROAN portion of the Depot Facilitization effort.

This requirement is derived from Change 4 of G/ATOR Block 2 Capabilities Development Document. The CEG Shelter is comprised of an S-788 Shelter on an up-armored HMMWV, providing the G/ATOR system with operator interfaces and communications processing. The CEG Shelter is an integral component of the G/ATOR System and supports external Command and Control voice and digital communications to CAC2S, CTN, and AFATDS. The FY20 $3.794M increase from the FY20 request to the FY21 request reflects the purchase, assembly and integration of GFE components for ten (10) vice eight (8) CEG Shelters in order to meet the needs of the GB2 user community. These CEG Shelters will include a significant design change to improve Environmental, Electromagnetic and Noise mitigation. FY21 decreases $1.845M from FY20 in the FY21 submit as it produces a total of eight (8) CEG Shelters.

GaN Retrofit Kits support the modification of six (6) total GaAS LRIP Systems to the GaN configuration with completion expected in FY23. The first three (3) Mod kits, $17M, will be installed in FY22 (LRIP Tech Refresh) and the second three (3) Mod kits, $17M, will be installed in FY23 (LRIP Tech Refresh). FY21 is the appropriate time to begin procurement of the first three GaN Retrofit Kits as the initial LRIP system will have over 6 years in service meeting Depot IROAN criteria.

This is a new item for Full Rate Production that was not in the FY20 request. Power Equipment Group (PEG) Pallets are primarily composed of Government Furnished Equipment thus they are now being assembled and integrated by Tobyhanna Army Depot vice the Prime Contractor.

Radar Decoys are hardware that ensures our forces possess the capabilities required to mitigate threats thus increasing the survivability of the radar system against anti-radiation missiles in a Peer, Near-Peer Competitive environment.
With G/ATOR being post FRP, program management support completely migrated from RDT&E to PMC funding in FY19.

G/ATOR's product support strategy employs a combination of Contractor Logistics Support (CLS) and Interim Contactor Logistics Support (ICLS) while the program begins to migrate towards an organic maintenance strategy during the Full Rate Production phase supporting all G/ATOR's. Contractor Logistics Support/Interim Contactor Logistics Support (CLS/ICLS) will continue to partially support fifteen (15) fielded G/ATOR LRIP systems and 2 FRP Systems in FY21 to include their maintenance and repair prior to fielding. Additionally, funding will be used to capture necessary usage data in preparation for organic logistics support, complete provisioning requirements, update the Interactive Electronic Training Manual (ITEM) for new software builds and to prepare and conduct several New Equipment Training (NET) events in FY21. These additional CLS efforts will continue through the Production and Deployment phase of the G/ATOR System. FY20 column $3.372M increase from the FY20 request to the FY21 request reflects the negotiated/planned Logistics costs for Fielded Systems Repair and Maintenance, CLS for Pre-Fielded Systems, New Equipment Training and Prime Contractor Logistic Planning support.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Global Combat Support System - Marine Corps/Logistics Chain Management (GCSS-MC/LCM) Family of Systems (FoS) serves as the primary technology enabler for the Marine Corps Logistics Modernization strategy. GCSS-MC/LCM provides the backbone for all logistics information required by Marine Forces and the Supporting Establishment. The core for GCSS-MC/LCM Increment 1 is a modern, commercial-off-the-shelf enterprise resource planning software (Oracle e-Business Suite). The Increment 1 design focused on enabling the warfighter to operate while deployed with reach back to Garrison from the battlefield. Increment 1 replaced 5 legacy supply and maintenance information technology systems and currently supports ~22,000 users world-wide. The focus of future functions will be enhancing capabilities in the areas of warehousing, distribution, logistics planning, decision support, depot maintenance, and integration with emerging technologies to improve asset visibility.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2020: $4.484M Funding continues to support the ongoing need for technology refresh of hardware and software in support of the sustainment of GCSS-MC/LCM Increment 1. The funding increase from FY2019 to FY2020 of $4.484M is in support of expanding the fielding of Warehousing Automated Information Technology hardware beyond the major logistics hubs, Supply Management Units (SMU), Repairable Issue Points (RIP), and Initial Issue Points (IIP) to the 140 operating force units' warehouses and storage sites across all three Marine Expeditionary Forces (MEF). This expansion to using units is a significant increase to the quantities in service. It will also support improvements to inventory management and asset visibility for USMC ground forces. Specifically, efficiency will be realized and come in the form of data accuracy through bar code availability instead of manual data input and in the ability to conduct annual rapid inventory management of install base items throughout the MEFs.
FY2021 Base Appropriation Request: $1.587M Funding will continue to support the ongoing need for technology refresh of hardware and software for the major logistics hubs in support of the sustainment of GCSS-MC/LCM Increment 1. Funding decrease from FY2020 to FY2021 of $2.897M is due to the completion of the initial procurement of Warehouse Automated Information Technology Hardware beyond the major logistics hubs.

proc:P5Item.proc:Name: Global Combat Support System Marine Corps (GCSS-MC)

proc:Name.footnote: Funding increase from FY2019 to FY2020 of $3.297M expands the fielding of Warehousing Automated Information Technology hardware beyond major logistics sites to the operating force's warehouses and storage sites. Funding decrease from FY2020 to FY2021 of $2.989M supports the completion of the initial procurement of Warehouse Automated Information Technology beyond the major logistics hubs.
Funding increase from FY2020 to FY2021 of $0.350M supports the Automated Data Entry Software procurement.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Fire Support System (FSS) provides the United States Marine Corps (USMC) critical operational and logistics capabilities in artillery weapons, fire direction, loitering munitions, and targeting systems. FSS provides the systems needed to create a fully networked sensor to shooter kill chain for the USMC Ground Combat Element. Key systems included are:
Fire Support Mods (FSM): FSM supports a set of Joint Service and Marine Corps unique efforts to address critical operational capabilities in artillery weapons, fire direction control systems, loitering munitions, and targeting / Intelligence Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) systems. Key programs include: Improved Position and Azimuth Determining Systems (IPADS), Joint Terminal Attack Controller Laser Target Designator (JTAC LTD), Organic Precision Fires (OPF), Global Positioning System Survey Replacement (GPSSR), Marine Artillery Survey Set (MASS), the Modeled Meteorological Information Manager (MMIM), Lethal Miniature Aerial Missile System (LMAMS).
Common Laser Range Finder (CLRF): The CLRF Integrated Capability (CLRF IC) integrates laser targeting capabilities to provide lightweight man portable targeting systems consistent with Strategy & Vision 2025 and the Commandant's Planning Guidance. The CLRF IC strategy includes replacement of the AN/PEQ-13, the AN/PEQ-17, and the AN/PEQ-25 into a single hand held targeting system, the Next Generation Hand Held Targeting System (NGHTS). This strategy will result in two affordable systems, a target locating system for the Joint fires observer, and a laser designator for the JTAC that will support operational targeting requirements well into the 2030 timeframe as well as provide significant reductions in weight and power requirements.
Family of Target Acquisition Systems (FTAS) - The FTAS provides the MAGTF the capability to locate, identify, and attack enemy indirect fire weapons systems and observe and direct friendly artillery fire. The FTAS consists of the AN/TPQ-46 Firefinder Radar, the AN/TPQ-49 Lightweight Counter Mortar Radar, AN/TPQ-54 Lightweight Counter Mortar Radar, Ground Counter Fire Sensor (GCFS), and the AN/TSQ-267 Target Acquisition System. The FTAS is critical in the execution of counterfire and the integration of target acquisition information enabling attack by MAGTF assets. The FTAS also provides artillery firing units the ability to conduct artillery registration and other friendly fire missions. The FTAS encompasses the equipment required to support target acquisition within the target acquisition platoon and is resident in the headquarters battery of each artillery regiment. The program will initiate development of replacement sensor systems and continue to address system issues that arise due to Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortage (DMSMS) items within the FTAS.
Target Hand-Off System (THS): The THS addresses a Marine Corps operational requirement for a lightweight, handheld, and digital target acquisition engagement coordination system. The THS is interoperable with all video downlink, Fire Support platforms, and Target Locating Devices designed for the Forward Air Controllers (FACs), Forward Observers (FOs), Fire Support Teams (FSTs), Firepower Control Teams (FCTs), Tactical Air Control Parties (TACPs), and Reconnaissance Teams. The THS provides the ability to integrate video and sensor information to quickly acquire and digitally prosecute targets in day, night, and near-all-weather visibility conditions in order to conduct precise and rapid indirect surface fire support, Naval Surface Fire Support (NSFS), and Close Air Support (CAS).
AFATDS FoS consists of three programs: AFATDS, Back Up Computer (BUCS) and Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS). The AFATDS automates the fire planning, tactical/technical fire direction, and fire support coordination required to facilitate sea control/denial and support maneuver from the sea and subsequent operations ashore. AFATDS integrates all supporting arms assets with the Marine Air-Ground Task Force, such as mortars, cannon artillery, rockets and missiles, close air support, and naval surface fires support systems. BUCS is a handheld computer system designed to provide a backup to the AFATDS in computing ballistic firing solutions, as well as provide survey and meteorological functions in support of the fires mission. The MTS is an artillery C2 platform dedicated to housing AFATDS and other fire support systems. It is a lightweight multipurpose shelter mounted on a lightweight utility vehicle. MTS enhances the capabilities and survivability of the fire support element by enabling rapid emplacement and displacement, and supports communications on the move. The MTS supports operations in all environmental conditions, day or night, while protecting the AFATDS and BUCS.
Lethal Miniature Aerial Missile System (LMAMS): LMAMS is a loitering, precision-guided missile that is man-portable, single-use, and organic at the small unit level. LMAMS provides precise lethal fires beyond reach of organic direct-fire weapon systems and performs target attack against personnel in the open or in defilade as well as soft-skinned vehicles during offensive, defensive, stability, and civil support operations. LMAMS provides precision lethality, while minimizing collateral damage in complex and cluttered operational areas.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $62.548M
FSM - $3.898M Funding provided support for modernization and upgrades to currently fielded systems. These systems are fielded to both the active ($2.839M) and reserve ($1.059M) components.
FTAS - $2.867M Funding procured ECP Modification Kits and will continued to address DMSMS issues within the FTAS. These kits are fielded to both the active ($2.574M) and reserve ($0.293M) components.
AFATDS - $12.521M Funds continued to procure a modernized, common shelter that will fulfill the requirements of the Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS) and the Target Processing Set (TPS).
THS - $23.893M Procures VHF (very high frequency) radios required to support digital transmission of targeting and fires data. Funds also procure THS end user devices to support a scheduled hardware refresh.
CLRF - $13.786M Funding will procure and field CLRF Integrated Capability (IC), full rate production systems to replace the current capability with enhanced targeting abilities and reduced system weight. Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) will be conducted to increase operational availability and increase system longevity.
FY 2020: $35.488M
FSM - $4.299M Funding continues to provide support for modernization and upgrades to currently fielded systems to include procuring IPADS replacements on a cycle. These systems are fielded to both the active ($3.603M) and reserve ($0.696M) components. The increase of $0.401M from FY19 to FY20 will support the procurement of additional IPADS replacement systems.
FTAS - $2.943M (Active $2.645M/Reserve $.298M) Funding procures ECP Modification Kits and will continue to address diminishing manufacturing sources and material shortages issues within the FTAS. These kits are fielded to both the active ($2.645M) and reserve ($0.298M) components. Increase of $0.076M from FY19 funding is due to an increase in the number of kits procured during FY20.
AFATDS - $12.852M Funds continue to procure a modernized, common shelter that will fulfill the requirements of the Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS) and the Target Processing Set (TPS). The funding increase from FY19 to FY20 of $2.6M for the MTS shelters is to procure an additional 23 shelters. Funding decrease from FY19 to FY20 of $2.38M for Hardware Refresh is due to the procurement of new tablet devices which have a lower unit cost than the laptops procured in FY19. Overall increase in AFATDS from FY19 to FY20 is $0.331M.
THS - $2.439M Funds will be used to complete refresh of the necessary cabling to support fielding of new VHF radios. A decrease of $21.454M from FY19 to FY20 is due to the completion of the VHF radio procurement required to support the digital transmission of fires data.
CLRF - $12.955M Funds will be used to implement ECPs on post Full Rate Production (FRP) CLRF systems to implement capability enhancements and a life cycle extension plan that will extend the service life of the system an additional ten years. The ECP will include a refresh of obsolete components, replace the digital magnetic compass and Input/Output card which will improve usability, and allow digital image export. A decrease of $0.831M from FY19 to FY20 is due to the completion of the procurement of CLRF IC systems. The ECP in FY19 and FY20 accomplishes updates to the digital magnetic compass and short wave infrared duty cycle as well as image export. It will be implemented into production in FY19 starting at system number 700 and will be retrofitted into the first 700 systems in FY20.
LMAMS - $0.0M A decrease of $5.583M from FY19 to FY20 is due to the completion of the procurement of 100 Lethal Miniature Aerial Missile System (LMAMS) All-up-Rounds (AUR) in FY19.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $24.934M ($23.918M Active; $1.016M Reserve)
FSM - $4.424M Funding will provide support for modernization and upgrades to currently fielded systems. This includes procuring IPADS replacements on a cycle. These systems are fielded to both the active ($3.711M) and reserve ($0.713M) components. The increase of $0.125M from FY20 to FY21 will support the procurement of additional IPADS replacement systems.
FTAS - $3.002M Funding will procure ECP Modification Kits and continue to address diminishing manufacturing sources and material shortage issues within the FTAS. These kits are fielded to both the active ($2.699M) and reserve ($0.303M) components. Increase of $0.059M from FY20 to FY21 is due to increased costs of ECP Modification Kits.
AFATDS - $14.067M Funds will continue to procure a modernized, common shelter fulfilling the requirements of the hardware refresh including the Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS) and the Target Processing Set (TPS). The funding increase from FY20 to FY21 of $1.215M procures additional MTS shelters and hardware to support AFATDS user interface for cyber security Trusted Platform Module (TPM) 2.0.
THS - $2.487M Funds will be used to complete procurement of modem cables required to support elimination of the Taclink modem which reduces the weight and cableing of the system. The increase of $0.048M from FY20 to FY21 will support the completion of the cable procurement in FY 21.
CLRF - $0.954M Funding will be used to complete the fielding process of CLRF IC. The decrease of $12.001M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the completion of the procurement of the CLRF IC in FY 20.
OCO: FY 2019 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO): $5.583M LMAMS - $5.583M Funding procures 100 LMAMS AURs.

proc:Name.footnote: CLRF: The ECP in FY19 and FY20 accomplishes updates to the digital magnetic compass and short wave infrared duty cycle as well as image export. It will be implemented into production in FY19 starting at system number 700 and will be retrofitted into the first 700 systems in FY20. The decrease of $11.362M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the completion of the procurement of the CLRF IC.
FY21 Lightweight Counter Mortar Radar (LCMR) Tech Refresh will be an estimated 15 systems.
FY21 increase procures additional MTS shelters.
FY21 the hardware refresh is to support the AFATDS new user interface.
This ancillary hardware components are to support the Mobile Tactical Shelter cables, raceways, and other infrastructure enhancements.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This budget line item includes Military Intelligence Program (MIP) funds for Marine Corps Intelligence capabilities necessary to support the employment of intelligence, reconnaissance, surveillance (ISR), and target acquisition resources integral to delivering decision advantage at the speed of operational relevance outlined in the 2018 National Defense Strategy. Marine Corps intelligence capabilities are divided into three functional areas organized along intelligence processes: Sensing (Persistent ISR), Analysis (Distributed Common Ground/Surface System Marine Corps (DCGS-MC)), and Dissemination (Intelligence Dissemination and Utilization (IDU)). This project funds the Sensing and Dissemination portfolios while the Analysis portfolio is budgeted under the DCGS-MC PE/BLI.
PERSISTENT INTELLIGENCE, SURVEILLANCE AND RECONNAISSANCE (PISR) GROUND SYSTEMS: PISR is a comprehensive strategy that synchronizes organic and external ISR assets in support of Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) operations. This capability involves sensing the operational environment through a variety of systems, from satellites overhead to reconnaissance Marines on the ground. PISR incorporates terrestrial sensing capability from the following ground collection systems.
Terrestrial Collection provides a tactical ground sensor Family of Systems (FoS) that are organic to the MAGTF and facilitate near-real time PISR sensing to MAGTF decision makers and users. Sensors are networked to the maximum extent possible to enable the sharing of standard data and information to support all six Marine Corps warfighting functions (C2, Intelligence, Operations, Protection, Fires, and Maneuver) with both targeting and battlespace awareness. An array of sensor delivery methods, and a variety of sensor characteristics enable the MAGTF to sense air (low altitude), land (surface, underground), sea (surface and subsurface), environmental effects (weather), and man-made objects (e.g. inside buildings) to determine threat location, disposition, movement and direction. The Terrestrial Collection portfolio includes, but not limited to, Ground Based Operational Surveillance System (GBOSS), MAGTF Secondary Imagery Dissemination System (MSIDS), and Tactical Remote Sensor System (TRSS). GBOSS is an expeditionary, ground-based, self-contained, multi-spectral sensor-oriented, persistent surveillance system used to observe, collect, detect, identify, classify, track, and report on contacts, objects of interest, and assessed threats twenty-four hours a day utilizing a fused video and sensor data display. MSIDS provides organic tactical digital imagery collection, transmission and receiving capability to the MAGTF Commander. TRSS provides all-weather direction, location determination, targeting, and tactical indications and warning of enemy activity in the MAGTF Commander's Area of Interest.
Counter Intelligence and Human Intelligence (CI/HUMINT) Equipment Program (CIHEP) provides each Marine CI/HUMINT Company within the Marine Corps Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance Enterprise (MCISRE) with an integrated, standardized, and interoperable suite of information and communication systems. The CIHEP program provides specialized equipment that is lightweight, modular, and tailorable, in deployable packages to conduct full spectrum, tactical CI and HUMINT activities, to include Technical Surveillance Countermeasures (TSCM) operations. TSCM operations use techniques to detect, neutralize, and exploit hostile technical surveillance technologies and hazards that permit the unauthorized access to or removal of information. CI/HUMINT elements are generally task-organized in support of a MAGTF or other supported commanders, providing them the capability to rapidly collect, process, and disseminate counterintelligence and human intelligence information in support of military planning and operations. CIHEP is comprised of ten modules of commercial and government off the-shelf equipment. Different components are selected for refresh each year in order to maintain current capabilities and ensure interoperability and standardization with related systems. This results in an equipment suite that enhances the operating force's CI/HUMINT capabilities, while maintaining interoperability within the USMC and joint CI/HUMINT communities. The modularity of the CIHEP program allows Marines to perform a variety of missions in support of commanders, while carrying only those items necessary to accomplish the mission. CIHEP provides state- of-the-art mission critical information protection capabilities, as well as the ability to detect, identify, and locate specific technical threats.
Tactical Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) Collection System (TSCS) provides rapidly deployable capability that is the only tactical signals collection capability in the MAGTF in both man packable and vehicular configurations, and provides collections capabilities needed to develop intelligence. The TSCS Family of Systems (FoS) incorporates the Radio Reconnaissance Equipment Program (RREP) and Team Portable Collection Systems - Multi-Platform Capable (TPCS-MPC) programs into a single program, providing a modular and scalable suite of equipment that exploits information from more technically advanced target sets. The TSCS FoS has an incremental acquisition strategy, providing technical refresh for legacy TPCS-MPC and RREP systems as the systems become obsolete and/or require technology insertions to maintain pace with our adversaries. The prioritization of capabilities included in each increment is based on obsolescence and required capability upgrades against advanced target sets. Fluctuations within the funding profile is due to different components being refreshed each year.
Communication Emitter Sensing and Attacking System (CESAS) is the sole USMC high power, man-packable, team portable and ground mobile electronic warfare (EW) asset. CESAS supports the MAGTF commander in the execution of his EW operations and information operations, by detecting, denying, and disrupting hostile communication emitters across a broad range of communication frequencies. CESAS covers the high frequency (HF), very high frequency (VHF), and ultra high frequency (UHF) frequency ranges against enemy emitters using modern modulation schemes. CESAS allows flexible employment to conduct EW while on the move or in a stationary position, thus optimizing the commander's ability to employ this asset for the greatest success of the mission. CESAS uses an incremental acquisition strategy, providing technical refresh for legacy systems as the systems become obsolete and/or require technology insertions to maintain pace with our adversaries.
PROCESSING, EXPLOITATION, ANALYSIS AND PRODUCTION SYSTEMS: Processing, exploitation, analysis, and production actions of the Intelligence process enables Marines to understand the all-source information/data revealed by PISR. The Distributed Common Ground System - Marine Corps (DCGS-MC) Enterprise (BLI 4767) will serve as the Marine Corps ISR Enterprise (MCISRE) backbone, migrating select capabilities into a single, integrated, net-centric baseline via clearly defined capability drops. The Intelligence Analysis System (IAS) FoS (All-Source) and the Technical Control Analysis Center (TCAC) FoS (Signal Intelligence (SIGINT)) transition to Project 2268 DCGS-MC beginning FY20.
INTELLIGENCE DISSEMINATION AND UTILIZATION (IDU) SYSTEMS: The IDU capability set performs the dissemination and integration functions of the Intelligence process. Dissemination connects the Intelligence product to the Commander who "operationalizes" these products through informed decisions.
The Intelligence Broadcast Receiver (IBR) acquisition program is a family of terminals that conform to the Department of Defense (DoD) Integrated Broadcast Service (IBS) objectives of interoperability and commonality to receive and process near-real time multi-intelligence data. The IBR family of terminals provide MAGTF Commanders with the only direct access to IBS data via UHF satellite communications (SATCOM) broadcast channels. The IBR program is an evolving, multi-service architecture designed to keep pace with Commanders' targeting and information requirements and conforms to the DoD IBS objectives of interoperability and commonality, which is currently accomplished using the universal serial bus (USB) Embedded National Tactical Receiver (ENTR). The ENTR Version 4 (V4) will supplement and replace the USB ENTR which is no longer in production and obsolete due to the National Security Agency (NSA) cryptographic modernization mandate starting in 2024. The ENTR V4 provides a 50% weight reduction and doubles the life expectancy of the battery compared to the USB ENTR. Additionally, the IBR program is researching technology to meet the existing transceiver requirement identified in the Joint Tactical Terminal Joint Operational Requirements Document (JORD). The IBR family of terminals receive Blue Force Tracker data, which is a key element in developing and maintaining situational awareness as it relates to the common threat/common operating picture. The IBR provides near-real time (NRT) strategic, theater, and tactical sensor-to-shooter connectivity as well as NRT Theater Missile Defense indications and warnings. Additionally, the IBR provides connectivity to IBS Common Interactive Broadcast and IBS Alternative Path.
Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System (JWICS) is the Top Secret Sensitive/ Compartmented Information (TS/SCI) portion of the Defense Information System Network and Intelligence Community (IC) Information Technology (IT) Enterprises. JWICS uses advanced networking technologies that permit point-to-point or multi-point information exchange involving voice, text, graphics, data, and video teleconferencing. It provides an SCI platform for data exchange of timely, current, and actionable intelligence from other services and agencies in support of Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) units deployed around the world. Connectivity through both JWICS and NSANet significantly enhance the detail, timeliness, and quality of intelligence support that intelligence organizations provide to Marine operating forces.
Sensitive Compartmented Information Communications (SCI COMMS) is a Super-High Frequency multi-band satellite communications Family of Systems (FoS), that provides a tactical capability at the Top Secret (TS)/SCI and Secret Collateral levels to USMC intelligence units. The SCI COMMS FoS is the only deployable communications system that is dedicated for TS/SCI data and voice communications that can receive, transmit, and disseminate bulk data and imagery products to and from national tactical intelligence sources. The FoS consists of palletized, team level, and man-packable systems - High Bandwidth Special Intelligence-Palletized Terminal (HBSI-PT), and Sensitive Compartmented Intelligence Kit (SCIK) - which provide USMC tactical commanders with high-capacity, near-real-time access to intelligence from national agencies, joint, coalition, service activities, intelligence producers, and other tactical units via connectivity to Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System, National Security Agency (NSA) Network, coalition networks, and Secret Internet Protocol Router Network.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $72.968M ($72.439M Active; $0.529M Reserve)
CESAS: $5.556M initiates procurement of 19 CESAS II man-packable and 19 core systems. These procurements will provide required man-packable ground mobile electronic attack capability to meet planned production schedule. Decrease of $3.667M from FY18 to FY19 aligns to procurement plan for CESAS II.
CIHEP: $6.066M procured Data Processing Module software to interface with the new Mobile user Objective System waveform which increased the capability to transmit intelligence data over tactical radios and continued to procure components for the Technical Surveillance Countermeasures (TSCM) which modernized current capability and provided two new systems. Increase of $2.541M from FY18 to FY19 reflected procurement of components for TSCM.
IAS: $9.570M ($9.041M Active; $.529M Reserves) supports the procurement of hardware associated with the Tier I server refresh, Tier II common components and Tier III technical fielding support. Increase of $1.174M from FY18 to FY19 supports the Tier I server procurement.
IBR: $3.472M procures ENTR V4 systems, components and support. These systems, supporting eight (8) battalions, will be fielded to the company-level, and provide the capability of strategic, theater and tactical sensor-to-shooter intelligence data to the tactical edge of the battlefield. Decrease of $2.568M from FY18 to FY19 reflects funding aligned with procurement plan and support schedule.
JWICS: $6.312M procures garrison and tactical equipment and integration costs for SCI Enterprise Office (SEO) and the Marine Corps Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance Enterprise (MCISRE) Fixed Site located at the Marine Corps Intelligence Activity (MCIA). Funding will procure garrison hardware such as desktops, laptops, servers, routers, switches, maintenance of equipment, technical refreshes of hardware, Electronic Key Management System (EKMS) for SEO services and Storage Area Network (SAN/NAS). Reduction to the JWICS program constricts access to National intelligence data, services and assets in support of current and future operations of the Marine Corps Leaders. Reduction puts the primary conduit for national-to-tactical SCI integration, network operations, specialized capabilities, remote production, exploitation, and dissemination across all intelligence domains at risk.
SCI COMMS: $7.325M procured additional HBSI-PT systems and ancillary components; and fielding and initial support. Funding also procured modification kits and upgrades such as modems for SCIK and updated test measurement and diagnostic equipment.
TCAC: $6.749M procures Remote Analysis Workstations (RAWS) Hardware Refresh and supports fielding activities related to the delivery of the TWS and TCAC-G and software baseline for TCAC FoS.
TSCS: $21.476M initiates procurement of TSCS FoS Increment I, which consists of core receivers and completes procurement of Tactical Servers. The program conducted an acquisition strategy change due to fidelity of costs models. The original strategy to procure one (1) Core Receiver variant was changed to procure four (4) different Core Receivers due to technology maturation not being conducive to capture all necessary signals of interest. The TSCS Core Receivers are the foundation of the TSCS FoS, replacing the TPCS receivers, and are capable of operating stand-alone (without a case or Platform Integration Kit). Tactical Servers will fulfill an AAO increase. Fluctuations in cost from year to year is caused by different components availability being prioritized based on obsolescence, operational user input and required capability upgrades against advanced target sets.
Terrestrial Collection: $6.442M supported the procurement of Advanced Network upgrade kits for fielded G-BOSS systems to increase network and computing performance for systems currently fielded in support of combat operations directly resulting in increased ability to conduct force protection and intelligence collections functions. Additionally, funds provided for the procurement of the Hand-Held Programmer-Monitors (HHPM) and Signature Data Recorder (SDR)components. The HHPM provides a portable, programmable, dual-band, sensor emplacement tool for programming sensor equipment, monitoring sensor activity, recording sensor positions, and testing RF communications paths between remote device sites. The SDR components provides connection with the Common Sensor Radio component and the SDR to meet to modern Security Standards. Funds also supported the procurement of MSIDS imagery transmission components providing the MAGTF commander the ability to transmit video and still imagery from eyes-on-target ashore in remote/austere locations from MSIDS outstation terminal to the Command Operations Center (COC) to support intelligence imagery gathering requirements. In FY19, GBOSS, MSIDS, and TRSS transitioned to Terrestrial Collection.
FY 2020: $56.896M ($56.896M Active; $0.000M Reserve)
CESAS: $5.187M initiates procurement of CESAS II FoS Team-Portable Kits and procures additional Core Systems. The Constructive Electromagnetic Operational Environment System (CEMOES) procurement originally planned in FY20 being curtailed by the Marine Corps to revalidate the requirement. The Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) Platform Integration Kit (PIK) procurement previously planned in FY20 is deferred due to cross team coordination. Decrease of $0.369M from FY19 to FY20 aligns to procurement plan for CESAS II.
CIHEP: $12.974M continues procurement and fielding of essential equipment for Technical Surveillance Countermeasures (TSCM) suites providing four additional systems and spares. Will also complete procurement of an in-production Engineer Change Proposal (ECP) to upgrade the configuration of the Broadband Global Area Network (BGAN) Antenna for Commercial Satellite Communications Set (CSCS) to significantly increase the usability and decrease the operational set up time. Procures external hard drives to meet storage requirements for fielded systems. The Marine Corps postponed the procurement of the Data Processing Module (DPM) suites. Current existing requirements were determined to be insufficient to meet the emerging operational needs. As a result, the Marine Corps developed updated requirements to meet current and future operational needs in a peer/near peer environment. In light of these new requirements, the CIHEP is changing to meet the newly documented requirement. Increase of $6.908M from FY19 to FY20 reflects technical refresh and the procurement of mission critical TSCM suites and spares.
IAS: Beginning FY20, IAS transitions to BLI 4767, Distributed Common Ground/Surface System-Marine Corps (DCGS-MC) in the support of the Marine Corps Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance Enterprise (MCISRE) Plan.
IBR: $3.014M continues procurement of Embedded National Tactical Receiver (ENTR) Version 4 systems, components, and support. These systems, supporting eight (8) battalions, will be fielded to the company-level, and provide the capability of strategic, theater and tactical sensor-to-shooter intelligence data to the tactical edge of the battlefield. Decrease of $0.458M from FY19 to FY20 is in alignment with procurement plan for various host systems.
JWICS: $6.861M procures garrison and tactical equipment and integration costs for SCI Enterprise Office (SEO) and the Marine Corps Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance Enterprise (MCISRE) Fixed Site located at the Intelligence Enterprise Management Office (IEMO). Funding will procure garrison hardware such as desktops, thin clients, laptops, hyper-converged servers, routers, switches, maintenance of equipment, and technical refreshes of hardware, Electronic Key Management System (EKMS) for SEO services and Storage Area Network (SAN/NAS) to include the Tactical JWICS planned fielding of High Bandwidth Special Intelligence-Palletized Terminal (HBSI-PT) sites and Sensitive Compartmented Information Communications Kit (SCIK)s. Reduction to the JWICS program constricts access to National intelligence data, services and assets in support of current and future operations of the Marine Corps Leaders. Reduction puts the primary conduit for national-to-tactical SCI integration, network operations, specialized capabilities, remote production, exploitation, and dissemination across all intelligence domains at risk. Increase of $0.549M from FY19 to FY20 reflects Tactical JWICS meeting planned fielding requirements.
TCAC: Beginning FY20, TCAC transitions to BLI 4767, Distributed Common Ground/Surface System-Marine Corps (DCGS-MC) in the support of the Marine Corps Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance Enterprise (MCISRE) Plan.
TSCS: $17.104M continues procurement of TSCS FoS Increment I, which consists of core receivers. The original strategy to procure one (1) Core Receiver variant was changed to procure four (4) different Core Receivers due to technology maturation not being conducive to capture all necessary signals of interest. The TSCS Core Receivers are the foundation of the TSCS FoS, replacing existing TPCS receivers, and are capable of operating stand-alone (without a case or Platform Integration Kit). Fluctuations in cost from year to year is caused by different components availability being prioritized based on obsolescence, operational user input and required capability upgrades against advanced target sets. Decrease of $4.372M from FY19 to FY20 aligns with the procurement plan for core receivers.
Terrestrial Collection: $6.642M completes the procurement of Advanced Network upgrade kits for fielded G-BOSS systems to increase network and computing performance for systems currently fielded in support of combat operations directly resulting in increased ability to conduct force protection and intelligence collections functions. Funds also provide for the continued procurement of TRSS Common Sensor Radio (CSR) and hardware components toward a full networking capability to form wireless networks. Increase of $0.200M from FY19 to FY20 reflects procurement plan of components within Terrestrial Collection.
SCI COMMS: $5.114M procures items such as, (3) HBSI-PT systems to support Authorized Acquisition Objective (AAO) increase, and modems for HBSI-PT and SCIK systems to modernize the Family of Systems with new Enterprise SATCOM Gateway Modem (ESGM) technologies, which will be the future infrastructure standard, and program support.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $50.728M ($50.728M Active; $0.000M Reserve)
CESAS: $10.217M will continue procurement of the CESAS II FoS Core Systems, Man-Packable Kits, and Team Portable Kits. Increase of $5.030M from FY20 to FY21 aligns to the additional procurement of multiple ground electronic attack systems.
CIHEP: $4.823M will complete the procurement and fielding of components for the Technical Surveillance Countermeasures (TSCM) suites. Funding will also procure surveillance systems for a refreshed capability. This includes updated technology to replace the current night vision device as well as it contributes to multi-modal communications to facilitate real-time distribution of source data and counterintelligence operations support. The surveillance systems include a counterintelligence event kit that provides a hasty surveillance capability for special events to track persons of interest. Decrease of $8.151M from FY20 to FY21 is in alignment with procurement schedule of technical surveillance countermeasure components for CIHEP.
IBR: $1.494M will continue procurement of Embedded National Tactical Receiver (ENTR) Version 4 systems, components, and associated support. These systems, supporting eight (8) battalions, will be fielded to the company-level, and provide the capability of strategic, theater, and tactical sensor-to-shooter intelligence data to the tactical edge of the battlefield. Decrease of $1.520M from FY20 to FY21 is most directly related to the procurement of 49 fewer IBR ENTR v4s.
TSCS: $16.310M will complete procurement of TSCS FoS Increment I, which consists of core receivers. In addition, will initiate procurement of TSCS FoS Increment II which consists of the Mini PIK, LAV-EW PIK, TSCS Modular (Mods) Case, and SAS-260 antenna. The original Increment 2 components also included the MV-22 Aviation Platform Kits and Advanced Signal Processor (ASP) but they are delayed due to technology maturation. The TSCS Mods Case, replacing the TPCS Mods Case, will be fielded with blank sleeves, facilitating the insertion of the core receivers and tactical servers fielded in Increment I. Decrease of $0.794 from FY20 to FY21 reflects completion of Increment I core receiver procurements.
Terrestrial Collection: $2.448M will continue to provide for the procurement of TRSS Common Sensor Radio Components toward a full networking capability to form wireless networks to meet modern security standards. Decrease of $4.191M from FY20 to FY21 reflects completion of Advanced Network upgrade kits for fielded G-BOSS systems. Decrease also reflects procurements of TRSS Hardware Components (Common Sensor Radio Components) in accordance with the TRSS procurement plan.
SCI COMMS: $8.634M will procure Man-packable systems and spares, including fielding and initial support. Funding also supports upgrades such as procurement of SCIK modems. Increase of $3.520M from FY20 to FY21 will procure (26) Man-packable systems, which will provide Marines with lightweight, packable Top Secret (TS)/Secure Compartmented Information (SCI) data transport.
JWICS: $6.802M will procure, field, and sustain servers, storage and network equipment based on operational needs throughout the Marine Corps Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance Enterprise (MCISRE) Fixed Site located at the Intelligence Enterprise Management Office (IEMO) for garrison and tactical requirements. Funding will provide technological refresh of SCI systems necessary to support the tactical SCI local area network and support reach-back interoperability. Funding will provide contractor engineering and integration support for hardware/software refresh of SCI systems.
OCO: FY 2021 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: ($10.124M)
CIHEP: $10.124M will procure surveillance systems which include updated technology to replace the current night vision device, providing multi-modal communications to facilitate real-time distribution of source data and counter intelligence operations in direct support of Operation Inherent Resolve, Operation Freedom's Sentinel, Horn of Africa and other expeditionary operations conducted by U.S. Marine Corps Forces Central Command and other Operational Forces. These systems enable Marines to support Intelligence operations, Force Protection, Military Source Operations, Counter Intelligence Investigations, Material Protection, Supply Chain Risk Management, Operational Security, and Force-On-Force threat analysis.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Family of Small Unmanned Aircraft Systems (FoSUAS) [Formerly Small Unit Remote Scouting System (SURSS)] - The FoSUAS program procures unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) to provide battalion/company/detachment level units with scalable airborne Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) capabilities to aid in detecting, identifying, engaging, and/or avoiding enemy units. Currently procured RQ-12 Wasp, RQ-11 Raven, RQ-20 Puma and various Nano/Vertical Takeoff & Landing (VTOL) UASs meet validated operational requirements delineated in the Operational Requirements Document (ORD) and UUNS 16014UA. Puma and the VTOL UAS continue to be planned as the current solutions for Group 1 and Group 2 capability needs while both Navy and Marine Corps finalize the transition of revised requirements to address Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (ISR) Capability Set via a new Capability Development Document (CDD), the intended successor to the current Operational Requirements Document (ORD).
The new CDD shall incorporate unique mission kits, mission payloads, air vehicle enhancements, and modifications of UAS and related ground control stations for the family of Group 1 tactical UAS systems including Group 1 Short Range/Short Endurance (SR/SE), Group 1 Medium Range/Medium Endurance (MR/ME), and Group1/Group 2 Long Range/Long Endurance (LR/LE). Group 1 UAS are small systems, less than 20 pounds in weight and Group 2 are medium systems, between 21 pounds and 55 pounds in weight. The SURSS program also conducts Field User Evaluations (FUEs) to support Universal Urgent Needs Statements (UUNS) that inform future USMC systems procurements. A Movement towards SUAS Common Control Architecture (SCCA) capability [formerly considered as Single Operator Man-Portable Ground Control System (GCS) / Target Handoff System (SOMGCS/THS)] reduces the size, weight, and manpower required to operate a FoSUAS GCS, increases the mobility of the operator, and improves digital interoperability. A SCCA capability shall be fully mobile and can be attached to the operator while the fielded GCS requires setup at a static location.
SR/SE capabilities are transitioning with revised requirements vice the existing ORD (Block 0/1) requirements to a next generation capability: Existing ORD (Block 0) capabilities are satisfied by the RQ-11 Raven and RQ-12A Wasp UAS. Wasp is a small, all environment UAS with a wingspan of 3.3 feet weight of 2.25 pounds and endurance of 60 minutes. The payload consists of a gimbaled turret with Electro Optical/Infrared (EO/IR) sensor. It allows maximum portability and provides near-real-time reconnaissance required by the platoon and rifle squad. RQ-11B Raven UAS. Raven is a small UAS with a wingspan of 4.6 feet, weight of 5 pounds and endurance of 90 minutes. Raven employs a gimbaled EO/IR sensor. Raven provides the company level unit an organic, near-real-time ISR capability that facilitates rapid battlefield decision making. Although USMC is divesting of Raven, additional Puma assets will fill the future void pending identification and procurement of an alternative solution set under revised requirements documentation. SR/SE (ORD Block 0) assets reduce the request-to-response timeframe for ISR services by eliminating delays or denials for ISR coverage due to an imbalance of other UAS assets that might otherwise be available. Although USMC is divesting of Wasp and Raven on an attrition basis, additional Puma assets will fill the future void pending identification and procurement of alternative solution sets under revised requirements documentation.
MR/ME capabilities are transitioning with revised requirements vice the existing ORD (Block 2) requirements to a next generation capability: Existing ORD (Block 2) capabilities are satisfied the RQ-20B Puma UAS. Puma is an all environment UAS with a wingspan of 9.2 feet, weight of 13 pounds and endurance of 2.5 hours. The Puma has demonstrated ranges of up to 28 kilometers. The standard payload consists of a gimbaled turret with an EO/IR sensor; a Signals Intelligence payload is also available. Puma provides an organic, persistent ISR capability to battalion level units, Route Clearance Platoons (RCP) and Combat Logistics Patrols (CLP) to enhance force protection and detect Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs). Puma or other MR/ME UAS solution sets will see increased procurements as Wasp and Raven attrite and as revised requirements are definitized.
LR/LE capabilities are transitioning with revised requirements vice the existing ORD (Block 3) requirements to a next generation capability. The solution set continues to mature and at present includes, but it not limited to, Sky Raider, Indago, and Stalker UAS based on tech demos and field user evaluations. Type, model, and series for procurement is under review at the time of this submission.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $3.848M $3.848M procured Puma as Medium Range/Medium Endurance (MR/ME) Systems as alternative to originally planned Short Range/Short Endurance (SR/SE) Systems due to divestiture of Wasp and Raven UAS.
FY 2020: $28.036M
$5.611M procures NextGen SR/SE Systems. The VTOL SR/SE UAS will provide dispersed Marine Corps units (Companies, Platoons, and Squads) an organic capability to operate in combat zones with significant vertical obstructions such as urban, jungle, and rugged terrains. Quantities are notional and unit cost is an average across many VTOL variants/configurations. Actual quantities of each UAS type/model/series will be determined in the execution year based on fleet need.
$10.456M procures defined SR/SE capabilities. Short Range/Short Endurance (SR/SE) was formally called RQ-12 WASP. Due to rapid changes in technologies, the name was changed to capabilities instead of platforms. The SR/ SE capability solution set will include VTOL starting in FY20.
$11.101M procures Medium Range/Medium Endurance (MR/ME) capabilities. Medium Range/Medium Endurance (MR/ME) was formally called RQ-20 PUMA. Due to rapid changes in technologies, the name was changed to capabilities instead of platforms. FY20 increase in unit cost of Medium Range/Medium Endurance (MR/ME)RQ-20B Puma is due to a new configuration that includes the I45 camera/sensor and other platform enhancements.
$0.868M procures SOMGCS/THS. The Single Operator Man-Portable Ground Control System/Target Handoff System (SOMGCS/THS) provides enhanced opportunities to detect irregular and asymmetric threats in a variety of domains, to include urban domains, providing the warfighter with enhanced situational awareness and understanding. SOMGCS/THS reduces the size, weight, and man power required to operate a SURSS GCS, increases the mobility of the operator, and improves digital interoperability.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $24.853M Due to continuing rapid changes in SUAS technologies, we changed the verbiage to address capabilities instead of platforms.
$4.600M will procure SR/SE capabilities. The Vertical Takeoff and Landing (VTOL) SR/SE UAS (including PD-100) will provide dispersed Marine Corps units (Companies, Platoons, and Squads) an organic capability to operate in combat zones, such as urban, jungle, and rugged terrains, with significant vertical obstructions. Quantities are notional and unit cost is an average across many VTOL variants/configurations. As with the FY20 plan, replacement Fixed Wing (FW) solution sets for the SR/SE capability requirement, due to the USMC approved plan for divestiture of Wasp and Raven (MROC DM 15-2018 of July 2018), and additional VTOL solution sets are under consideration. Actual quantities of each UAS type/model/series (T/M/S) will be determined in the execution year based on fleet needs, such as replacement of operational losses to maintain AAO.
$13.289M will procure defined Medium Range/Medium Endurance (MR/ME) capabilities. The RQ-20 PUMA solution set satisfies the MR/ME capability requirement as a FW variant. Due to the USMC approved plan for divestiture of Wasp and Raven as the Fixed Wing (FW) as solution sets for SR/SE capabilities, RQ-20 Puma will fill the SR/SE FW void pending determination of another viable FW solution set in conjunction with the SR/SE VTOL solution sets. The VTOL MR/ME solution set (which includes Instant Eye) continues to be reviewed for additional T/M/S SUAS platforms. Actual quantities of each LR/LE UAS T/M/S will be determined in the execution year based on fleet needs, replacement of operational losses to maintain AAO.
$6.964M will procure Long Range/Long Endurance (LR/LE) capabilities. The LR/LE capability solution sets (including Sky Raider) continues to mature with potential T/M/S LR/LE SUAS platforms being determined. Actual quantities of each LR/LE UAS T/M/S will be determined in the execution year based on fleet needs, such as replacement of operational losses to maintain AAO.
The reduction in funding from FY20 to FY21 of $3.183M as well as quantity decrease of 84 UAS are due to service rebalancing and the revision of FoSUAS (formerly SURSS) Approved Acquisition Objective across all variants as delineated by HQMC Capabilities Development Directorate. The revised AAO supports the Marine Corps Capabilities Based Assessment (MC CBA). This document identifies and refines Marine Corps capabilities, capability gaps, overlaps/redundancies, and risks within the Future Years Defense Program (FYDP) pertaining to the Program Objective Memorandum (POM) year of analysis.

proc:Name.footnote: Medium Range/Medium Endurance (MR/ME) was formally called RQ-20 PUMA. Due to rapid changes in technologies, the name was changed to capabilities instead of platforms. FY21 decrease in unit cost of (MR/ME) is due to the cost element consisting of multiple MR/ME platforms, which have different unit costs. In FY20, only RQ-20 Pumas, which have a high unit price, are being procured. In FY 21, only 20% of the budgeted quantity are RQ-20 Pumas. The other 80% of the budgeted quantity are platforms with significantly lower unit costs, thus resulting in a unit cost decrease in FY21.

Short Range/Short Endurance (SR/SE) was formally called RQ-12 WASP. Due to rapid changes in technologies, the name was changed to capabilities instead of platforms. The SR/SE capability solution set will include VTOL starting in FY20. FY21 decrease in unit cost of (SR/SE) is due to the cost element consisting of multiple SR/SE platforms, which have different unit costs. The budgeted procurement mix in FY21 consists of platforms with significantly lower unit costs, thus resulting in a unit cost decrease in FY21.

Quantities and unit cost are incorporated in SR/SE, MR/ME, and LR/LE cost elements beginning in FY20. Actual quantities of each UAS type/model/series will be determined in the execution year based on fleet need and a buy to budget methodology.

The SOMGCS/THS LRIP-1 is scheduled for delivery in FY20 for field user evaluation prior to fulfilling the full replacement requirement to transition to common control station. Ongoing field user evaluation results will determine FY21 requirements.

Quantity and cost are notional based on best candidate solution set at the time of this submission as well as providing a quantity based on historical attrition rates before receiving FMF feedback.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This is a Military Intelligence Program (MIP) budget line item.
Distributed Common Ground/Surface System Marine Corps (DCGS-MC) is integral to delivering decision advantage at the speed of operational relevance outlined in the 2019 National Defense Strategy. DCGS-MC provides an analysis and production capability within garrison and deployed Marine Corps organizations. DCGS-MC complies with the Department of Defense (DoD) DCGS Enterprise interoperability and information sharing requirements by migrating select processing, exploitation, analysis, and production capabilities into a single, integrated, net-centric baseline within the Marine Corps Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance Enterprise (MCISRE). This baseline will enable MCISRE analysts to deliver tactically focused, operational, and strategic intelligence at the tactical edge throughout all phases of operations and will provide relevant, precise decision support for Joint Task Force (JTF), Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF), and subordinate Marine units. The DCGS-MC portfolio currently consists of enterprise services and functional analytic and production tools that provide analysts with the ability to process, disseminate, exploit, analyze, and produce intelligence for discovery via the DCGS Integration Backbone (DIB). The functional capabilities are grouped by DCGS-MC GEOINT, DCGS-MC All Source, and DCGS-MC SIGINT. Future capabilities will be delivered via clearly defined Capability Drops determined by an integrated assessment of user needs, technology readiness, risk mitigation, and affordability.
DCGS-MC Geospatial Intelligence (DCGS-MC GEOINT)
DCGS-MC GEOINT provides geo-referenced data and products that establish the GEOINT foundation for battlespace visualization and a common frame of reference to support the Commander's decision making process. It enables the ability to rapidly respond to, or predict, threats around the world by providing near real time geospatially referenced data and products that serve as the Authoritative Data Source for the full spectrum of Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF), joint, and multinational partner's operations. DCGS-MC GEOINT enables mission accomplishment across the range of military operations and with all mission partners. The DCGS-MC GEOINT provides the tasking, collection, processing, exploitation, analysis, production, storage, and dissemination of imagery and geospatial information to describe, assess, produce, and visually depict physical features and geographically referenced activities on the Earth. DCGS-MC GEOINT will incorporate those capabilities formally provided by the Tactical Exploitation Group, Topographic Production Capability, Virtual Imagery Processing - Marine Corps, and Target Materials Production legacy systems.
DCGS-MC All Source
DCGS-MC All Source incorporates those capabilities formally provided by the Intelligence Analysis System (IAS) project. This acquisition program is the Marine Corps' primary intelligence analytical toolset at all levels of the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF). DCGS-MC All Source enables global collaboration with Marine and joint analytical systems. It provides Marines the capability to conduct all-source fusion, analysis, and production of intelligence by automating multiple intelligence functions and processes. This includes the display of current enemy situation, collection requirements, asset management, message parsing, and database updates. DCGS-MC All Source automatically logs intelligence activities into a journal and provides access to intelligence produced by tactical, theater, and national systems and agencies. It facilitates the dissemination and exchange of intelligence and information with other echelons through tactical local area networks and wide area networks from the Marine Expeditionary Force (MEF) garrison facility down to the infantry company level. DCGS-MC All Source consists of intelligence servers and workstations with their associated peripherals and software.
DCGS-MC Signals Intelligence (DCGS-MC SIGINT)
The Technical Control Analysis Center (TCAC) FoS is the DCGS-MC SIGINT capability and consists of the TCAC Remote Analysis Workstation (RAWS), the Transportable Workstation (TWS) and the Cross Domain Solution (CDS), and is the focal point of Radio Battalions (RADBN), Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command (MARFORSOC), and Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Signal Intelligence (SIGINT) operations. TCAC automatically collects, stores, retrieves and plays back digital audio signals. It fuses and analyzes SIGINT data from tactical, theater, and national collectors and databases for dissemination to tactical commanders. TCAC provides SIGINT analysis applications to deployable MAGTF units capable of directing and managing the technical and operational functions of other RADBN SIGINT/EW assets. Additionally, TCAC provides a focal point for national, theater, and tactical data networks for data exchange with tactical SIGINT/EW assets, the IAS and national databases. TCAC will enable the transfer of USMC tactical SIGINT collection and analytical data into the Real-Time Regional Gateway (RT-RG) and by producing DIB enabled products that will be discoverable by any DCGS enabled Marine. The system provides ground processing of Electronic Warfare (EW) information including EW Support and Electronic Attack (EA) data collected by the RADBN and JSF aircraft. The Cross Domain Solution also enables the TCAC to transfer approved and sanitized file types from Top Secret/Sensitive Compartmented Information (TS/SCI) networks (e.g. JWICS/NSAnet) to Marine Corps Enterprise Network-SIPR (MCEN-S) networks for delivery to Tactical Commanders.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $16.081M (active)
DCGS-MC GEOINT: Funding procured geospatial intelligence peripheral components, MAVEN hardware, software integration into DCGS-MC Common Intel Server and Common Geospatial Intelligence (GEOINT) hardware and software consolidation efforts.
In FY 2019, DCGS-MC All Source (IAS) and DCGS-MC SIGINT (TCAC) were executed under BLI 4747.
FY 2020: $32.562M (active)
DCGS-MC GEOINT: $20.516M supports modernization efforts such as geospatial intelligence peripheral components, software integration into DCGS-MC Common Intel Server, and Common Geospatial Intelligence (GEOINT) hardware and software consolidation efforts as well as ECP's across the DCGS-MC portfolio of systems. Additionally, funding supports the collapsing of GEOINT/Target Intelligence, hardware/software baselines and sustaining and advancing critical technology investments in AI/ML and intelligence cloud services.
DCGS-MC All Source: $7.770M supports the procurement of hardware associated with the Tier II common components and Tier III technical fielding support. The IAS program was previously funded in BLI 4747 in FY 2019 and prior.
DCGS-MC SIGINT: $4.276M will procure the Transportable Work Station (TWS) hardware, fielding and initial engineering, and tech and management support. The TCAC program was previously funded in LI 4747 in FY 2019 and prior.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $38.260M (active)
DCGS-MC GEOINT: $23.571M will support the Common Data Link (CDL) Antenna Refresh. Additionally, funding will support advancing GEOINT critical technology investments in AI/ML and intelligence cloud services. The $3.055M increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 supports procurement and fielding of GEOINT hardware and software necessary to support Marine Corps Future Force 2025 intelligence structure increases, this will include the Contingency Operations (COOP) server stacks in support of MCISRE cloud initiative (eHUB).
DCGS-MC ALL SOURCE: $8.228M will support the procurement of Common Intel Workstations, Fielding and Initial Engineering, and Tech and Management support for the Common Intel Server and software enhancements in support of Advanced Analytics Technical Solution (AATS). $0.458M increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 reflects software enhancements to the Advanced Analytics Technical Solution (AATS) required in order to keep pace with emerging technology and to meet the needs of Marine Corps Intelligence Analysts.
DCGS-MC SIGINT: $6.461M will procure Cross Domain Solution (CDS) hardware refresh, fielding and initial support, and software procurement for TCAC Family of Systems (FoS). Increase of $2.185M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 will support the refresh of Cross Domain Solution (CDS) hardware procurement.
Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
OCO: FY 2019 OCO: $3.125M
DCGS-MC GEOINT: $3.125M supported MAVEN Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) operations and Processing, Exploitation and Dissemination (PED) capabilities.
