proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Networking On The Move (NOTM) - NOTM provides a command and control (C2) capability by integrating tactical data systems with on the move satellite communications (SATCOM) for beyond line-of-sight communication that allows commanders to have uninterrupted two-way access to digital data, anywhere on the battlefield. NOTM provides Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) commanders and staffs with full Common Operational Picture (COP) access, virtually unlimited situational awareness and a powerful ability to issue digital orders (fires, maneuver, planning) to Ground Combat Element (GCE), Air Combat Element (ACE) and Logistics Combat Element (LCE) units at all echelons while on-the-move or at-the-halt. NOTM also provides Marine units the capability to link with and extend Defense Information System Network (DISN) services; SIPRNet, NIPRNet, and Defense Switched Networks (DSN). Integrated full motion video (receipt and retransmission), tactical voice communications, plus three options for secure wireless local area network (LAN) connectivity between staff members makes this capability a crucial asset to all elements of the MAGTF. Currently the USMC has three variants depending on the type of transportation being used; the NOTM Ground Combat Vehicle (GCV), NOTM Utility Task Vehicle (UTV), and NOTM Airborne (NOTM-A).
Joint Battle Command - Platform (JBC-P) Family of Systems (FoS) - JBC-P FoS is an Army led ACAT II program of Joint Requirements Oversight Council (JROC) interest formerly known as the Blue Force Tracker (BFT) FoS. It is comprised of L-Band Satellite Communications (SATCOM) and is a digital, battle command information FoS that provides integrated, on the move, timely, relevant Command and Control Situational Awareness (C2SA) information to tactical combat, combat support, and combat service support commanders, leaders, and key C2 nodes. JBC-P FoS will provide JROC mandated C2SA convergence across Combat Operations Centers (COC), ground vehicles and dismounted personnel.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations System (GCCS-TCO) - GCCS-TCO is the principal tool within the MAGTF for situational awareness through distribution of the Common Tactical Picture (CTP). It supports tactical operations by providing information via high speed computer systems in a timely manner and includes the Tactical COP Workstations/Servers. Procurement funding allows for system refresh and replacements to match the program's acquisition objective.
Advanced Field Artillery Tactical Data Family of Systems (AFATDS FoS) - AFATDS FoS consists of three programs: AFATDS, Back Up Computer System (BUCS), and Mobile Tactical Shelter (MTS). The AFATDS automates the fires planning, tactical fire direction, and fire support coordination required to support maneuver from the sea and subsequent operations ashore. AFATDS integrates all supporting arms assets within the MAGTF such as mortars, cannon artillery, rockets and missiles, close air support, and naval surface fire support systems. BUCS is a hand-held computer system designed to provide a backup to the AFATDS in computing ballistic firing solutions as well as provide survey and meteorological functions in support of artillery. Additionally, BUCS is the primary ballistic firing solution system during Ship To Objective Maneuver (STOM) and for the Expeditionary Fire Support System (EFSS). The MTS is a Lightweight Multi-purpose Shelter (LMS) mounted on a High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle (HMMWV) which protects both the AFATDS and operators from the environment. MTS enables rapid emplacement and displacement of fire support elements and provides networked communications on the move. Transition to BLI 4733 in FY19.
Target Hand-Off System (THS) - The THS addresses a Marine Corps operational requirement for a lightweight, handheld, and digital target acquisition engagement coordination system. The THS is interoperable with all Fire Support platforms and Target Locating Devices designed for the Forward Air Controllers (FACs), Forward Observers (FOs), Fire Support Teams (FSTs), Firepower Control Teams (FCTs), Tactical Air Control Parties (TACPs), and Reconnaissance Teams. The THS provides the ability to quickly acquire and digitally prosecute targets in day, night, and near-all-weather visibility conditions in order to conduct precise and rapid indirect surface fire support, Naval Surface Fire Support (NSFS), and Close Air Support (CAS). Transition to BLI 4733 in FY19.
Marine Corps Information Operation Program (MCIOP) - provides MAGTF commanders and the Marine Corps a responsive and effective full-spectrum information operations (IO) planning and psychological operations delivery capability by means of deployable support teams and a comprehensive general support IO reach-back capability in order to integrate IO into Marine Corps operations. Multiple classification levels require separate Information Technology (IT) infrastructure to support each classification level in accordance with National Security Agency and Defense Intelligence Agency standards. This includes equipment necessary for connecting internal MCIOC IT infrastructure (voice, video, and data) with the existing Marine Corps Base Quantico support infrastructure. Transition to BLI 4620 in FY19.
Combat Operations Center (COC) - The COC provides commanders with a rapidly deployable, common, modular, and scalable operational agency that facilitates command and control across the full spectrum of MAGTF operations. The AN/TSQ-239A Family of Systems (FoS) is designed to provide centralized C2 Operational Facilities (OPFAC) to collect, process, and disseminate tactical data for the commander and staff of a Marine Expeditionary Force (MEF), Division, Wing, Marine Logistics Group, Regiment, Marine Air Group, Battalion, and Squadron. The COC provides the commander with a Common Operational Picture (COP) and tactical data and communications assets needed to plan and conduct operations in an expeditionary combat environment. The system enables analytical and intuitive decision-making with a modular and scalable equipment set consisting of a common module OPFAC, C2 system, visual displays, and SW. Existing Tactical Data System software, previously resident on numerous platforms throughout the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF), have been re-hosted on the COC system to provide commanders with integrated data access and communications. COC program office will begin developing a design for an update to the current COC configuration called Next Generation Operational Facility (OPFAC). The Next Generation OPFAC will provide the MAGTF with a more agile and modular COC capability to better support future Expeditionary Advanced Based Operations (EABO) that require a smaller physical presence. In FY21 the Combat Operations Center (COC) requirements transitions into the Combat Data Network (CDN) BLI 4634 under the title Common Hosting Environment (CHE).
Hand Held Command and Control (H2C2) - Provides the dismounted user at the tactical edge, a handheld devices that provides integrated, on-the-move, secure, timely, and relevant Command & Control/Situational Awareness (C2/SA) information to tactical combat, combat support and combat service support commanders, leaders, and key C2 nodes. H2C2 provides leaders with a capability for selecting, managing, and assimilating relevant data and information. This allows them to pass orders and graphics that will provide the joint warfighter the capability to visualize the commander's intent and scheme of maneuver, and provide enhanced SA of friendly, reported enemy, neutral, and civilian entities.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $117.281M ($115.123M Active, $2.158M Reserves)
Networking On The Move (NOTM): $86.042M ($86.035M Active; $0.007M Reserves) - FY19 funds procured (24) NOTM-GCV systems and (20) NOTM-A systems. Funds also supported technology refresh kits in support of system reliability and provided support services for production, fielding and training.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations (GCCS-TCO): $2.955M Active - FY19 funding procured technical refresh of "workstations" (laptops/clients) across the operational forces.
Joint Battle Command - Platform Family of Systems (JBC-P FoS): $14.481M Active - FY19 funds continued support for items such as, software and hardware integration, hardware refresh, ancillary equipment, NET and field support, and procures Mounted Family of Computer Systems (MFoCS).
Combat Operations Center (COC): $13.803M ($11.652M Active; $2.151M Reserves) - FY19 funds required for hardware server refresh supporting existing software baseline.
FY 2020: $80.897 ($78.699M Active, $2.198M Reserve)
Networking on the Move (NOTM): $51.373M ($51.359M Active, $0.014M Reserve) - FY20 funding procures NOTM-GCV systems and NOTM-A aircraft modification kits. FY20 funding will also support tech refresh, as well as acquisition, fielding, and training support associated with production systems.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations (GCCS-TCO): $1.409M Active - FY20 funding procures Tactical COP Servers (TCS) and Tactical COP Workstations for the replenishment of currently fielded systems due to harsh field environment and obsolescence.
Joint Battle Command - Platform Family of Systems (JBC-P FoS): $8.159M Active - FY20 funding supports JLTV availability and will continue support for items such as, software and hardware integration, hardware refresh, ancillary equipment, NET and field support, and it will procure Mounted Family of Computer Systems (MFoCS). FY20 funding request is in accordance with the JBC-P hardware refresh cycle that occurs every two years (i.e. FY18, FY20).
Combat Operations Center (COC): $8.440M ($6.256M Active, $2.184M Reserves) - FY20 funds are required for hardware refresh activities in support of a common hardware baseline. Funding will also be used to align the COC software and hardware baseline with systems currently hosted within the COC in order to manage software growth and interoperability. Supporting the existing software baseline is necessary to maintain Authority To Operate (ATO) and integration with Tactical Service Oriented Architecture (TSOA), Joint Tactical Command Operational Picture (COP) Workstation (JTCW), and Command and Control Personal Computer (C2PC).
Handheld Command and Control (H2C2): $11.516M Active - The H2C2 program is now comprised of two increments which are procured and fielded separately. Increment I provides a dismounted C2SA capability at the squad level via a tethered connection to tactical radios and received a 1QFY20 fielding decision. FY20 PMC funded activities include fielding of Increment I systems starting in 1QFY20 and continuing throughout the FY, and procurement of low rate initial production articles for the MAGTF Common Handheld Increment II End user Device. Prior to FY20 the H2C2 effort was captured under the JBCP-FoS Handheld End User Device Early Capability Release.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $33.713M ($32.933M Active, $0.780M Reserve)
FY21 funds will primarily support the procurement of Qty 40 NOTM-A modification kits and Qty 9 NOTM-UTV systems. The NOTM-A modification kits are critical to maintaining command and control (C2) and operational awareness while moving throughout the battlespace. The NOTM-UTV systems integrate the NOTM capabilities onto an MV-22 transportable vehicle, providing increased operational speed and maneuverability while maintaining operational awareness. Remaining funding will support procurement of tech refresh equipment, fielding support, and naval integration efforts which include installing common NOTM hardware and software to integrate C2 onboard Naval L-Class ships. Decrease of $18.417M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the completion of NOTM-GCV system procurements.
Global Command and Control System - Tactical Combat Operations (GCCS TCO): $0.753M ($0.000M Active, $0.753 Reserve) FY21 funds will be used to procure peripherals for the replenishment of currently fielded equipment due to harsh field conditions. The decrease of $0.656M from FY20 to FY21 reflects alignment with procurement schedule for technical refresh of servers and workstations.
Joint Battle Command - Platform Family of Systems (JBC-P FoS): The decrease of $8.159M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the Marine Corps' concerted effort to modernize in accordance with the National Defense Strategy (NDS)/Defense Planning Guidance (DPG).
Combat Operations Center (COC): $0.004M FY21 funds efforts towards divesture. Decrease of $8.436M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the Marine Corps' concerted effort to modernize in accordance with the National Defense Strategy (NDS)/Defense Planning Guidance (DPG).
Handheld Command and Control (H2C2): The decrease of $11.516M from FY20 to FY21 reflects completed procurement of low rate initial production articles for the MAGTF Common Handheld Increment II End user Device and Marine Corps prioritization and modernization efforts reflected in the National Defense Strategy.

proc:Item.proc:Name: 1.3) Hardware/Software Integration, NET and Fielding Support

proc:Name.footnote: JBC-P FY20 funding request is in accordance with the JBC-P hardware refresh cycle that occurs every two years (i.e. FY18, FY20). The decrease in funding from FY20 to FY21 reflects the Marine Corps concerted effort to modernize in accordance with the National Defense Strategy (NDS) and Defense Planning Guidance (DPG).
GCCS TCO Reserves: Increase of $0.753M from FY20 to FY21 supports the procurement of peripherals for the replenishment of currently fielded equipment due to harsh field conditions.
GCCS TCO: Decrease of $1.409 from FY20 to FY21 aligns to the technical refresh cycle requirements.
NOTM Program Support - decrease of $4.104M from FY20 to FY21 aligns with decreased installation and fielding activities associated with the NOTM procurement schedule.

proc:Item.proc:Name: 3.2) Program and Systems, Support, Fielding, & Training

proc:Name.footnote: NOTM Systems Refresh/Equipment Upgrades is for various components with varying quantities and prices. The decrease of $7.877 from FY20 to FY21 aligns to reduction in equipment upgrades and technology refresh plans.
NOTM-GCV Systems - decrease of $22.605M from FY20 to FY21 reflects completion of GCV system procurement.
NOTM-A Mod Kits - increase $6.076M from FY20 to FY21 reflects increase in procurement quantities from 24 to 40.
NOTM UTV Increase of $10.080 from FY20 to FY21 reflects procurement quantity increase from 0 UTV systems to 9 UTV systems.
COC: Program Management Support decrease of $2.266M from FY20 to FY21 reflects divestiture of the COC program.

COC: COC Refresh decrease of $3.986M from FY20 to FY21 reflects divestiture of the COC program. In FY21 the Combat Operations Center (COC) requirements transitions into the Combat Data Network (CDN) program BLI 4634 under the title Common Hosting Environment (CHE).
COC: Reserves COC Refresh decrease of $2.184M from FY20 to FY21 reflects divestiture of the COC program.

Decrease of $11.513M from FY20 to FY21 for Dismounted Handheld Systems reflects completed procurement of low rate initial production MCH Increment II end user devices. Systems are comprised of the end user device, peripherals, and associated software licenses. This program has no procurement funding beyond FY20.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This budget line item procures radios, radio systems, satellite communications systems, and associated equipment.
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): GBS is a smart-push/user-pull Satellite Communication (SATCOM) system that provides large volumes of information to deployed, or garrison forces. The AN/TSR-9 and AN/TSR-11 receives and disseminates GBS broadcasts at up to 45 Mbps, and is capable of processing both classified and unclassified information products such as: imagery, intelligence, video (NTSC and Digital), theater message traffic, Joint and service-unique news, weather and MWR programming. Each Transportable Ground Receive Suite (TGRS) consists of a Receive Terminal (including a 1-meter parabolic dish antenna), Receive Broadcast Manager Server, Power Controller Unit, Crypto Device (KG-250), Integrated Receiver-Decoder (for NTSC video), Managed Ethernet Switch, Unmanaged Ethernet Switch, Video Converter, and transit cases. The Portable Receive Suite (PRS) is a man-portable ground station single enclave (Classified or Unclassified) receive suite. The PRS can be connected to a LAN with the addition of a user supplied Ethernet switch. The PRS receives information products broadcasted through the Global Broadcast Service (GBS) via the Ka-band transponders via the Wideband Global SATCOM (WGS) satellites' Ka-band downlink transponders.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): The VSAT Family of Systems (FoS) provides wideband, beyond-line-of-sight (BLOS), low-cost satellite communications to Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) commanders from the Major Subordinate Command to Battalion levels. The VSAT FoS provides the RF communications link in support of the transfer of voice, video, and data services.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): SMART-T provides tactical users with protected data and voice via Advanced Extremely High Frequency (AEHF) satellite communications. The SMART-T system is transported on High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicles (HMMWVs), providing MAGTF Commanders a secure, survivable, long-haul, low/medium data rate communications link not subject to terrain masking and horizon limitations. The SMART-T is the only USMC asset that possesses a SATCOM AEHF capability.
Military Global Positioning System (GPS) User Equipment (MGUE) (formerly DAGR): MGUE efforts are focused on increasing the resiliency and assurance of Positioning, Navigation, and Timing (PNT) capabilities across the enterprise, which enable Marine Air/Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Commanders to know and trust position, effectively navigate, and receive precise and accurate timing for users, platforms, and systems across warfighting functions. Current MGUE efforts will enable the Marine Corps to transition to the modernized military GPS signal (M-Code) through participation in both Air Force-led MGUE Increment I and Increment II programs. Increment I will deliver a receiver card capable of being embedded and integrated within a variety of USMC platforms and end items, while Increment II will deliver the next generation handheld device and will replace the Defense Advanced GPS Receiver (DAGR). Under the MGUE program, the Marine Corps will continuously test, evaluate, and facilitate integration of PNT solutions across platforms and devices.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): TCM addresses the requirements to enhance, replace, and sustain tactical radio systems while achieving interoperability and minimizing the affects of equipment obsolescence. TCM enables Command, Control (C2) and situational awareness at all echelons and elements of the MAGTF. TCM provides for Line of Sight (LOS), Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) secure voice, and data, operating in frequency bands from 1.6MHz to 2.5GHz. TCM procurements enable joint interoperability, mobile networking, and support National Security Agency (NSA) Communications Security (COMSEC) Modernization requirements down to the squad level.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission Systems (TWTS): TWTS is a capabilities portfolio that provides the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) with a continued capability of secure Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) and Line of Sight (LOS) terrestrial digital data transmission. The BLOS systems include the Army/Navy Transportable Radio Communications-170A (AN/TRC-170A) and its replacement system the Next Generation Troposcatter (NGT). The NGT capability will provide a high bandwidth communications data link to support remote locations where satellite communication is not available. The LOS systems include the Army-Navy/Mobile Radio Communications (AN/MRC-142), Wireless Point to Point Link (WPPL), Tactical Elevated Antenna Mast (TEAMS), and the future Line-of-Site Radio System Family of Systems (LRS FoS) which will include both Radio Frequency (RF) and Optical capabilities. In FY21, to align with the Marine Corps Strategy for assured Command and Control requirements and to meet technology readiness requirements, the Line of Site Replacement (LOS-R) will begin to transition to the LRS FoS. The LRS FoS programs will meet shore-to-shore (RF and Optical capabilities) and shore-to ship (RF capability) operational requirements as well as provide spectrum diversity and flexibility. The RF capability will provide secure RF PTP and PMP digital connectivity for voice and data traffic while the Optical capability provides a Low Probability of Intercept (LPI)/ Low Probability of Detection (LPD) communication pathway and increased data throughput.
[P40A / Tech Refresh (Reserve)]: SMART-T Tech Refresh (Reserve): Increase of $.013M from FY20 to FY21 supports refresh of various elements to mitigate obsolescence issues.
[P40A / Line of Sight Replacement (LOS-R) Mast Trailer]: TWTS LOS-R Mast Trailer: Based on acquisition strategy change, program office is no longer procuring the Mast Trailer in FY20; new strategy is to procure in FY23 to support validation and verification for integration of the mast onto the JLTV trailer.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $231.619M
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): $1.815M - Funding procured planned hardware tech refresh efforts to mitigate obsolescence issues. Funding also provided for fielding efforts and program support.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): $7.567M - Funding provided for system tech refreshes and upgrades, such as the Master Reference Terminal (MRT), servers, and switches to continue mitigation of end-of-life/end-of-support and obsolescence issues; and program support.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): $0.778M - Funding allocated to procure tech refresh components, such as digital transmitter and circuit card assemblies, to mitigate end of life/end of sale and obsolescence issues until Next Generation (NEXGEN) Advanced Extremely High Frequency (AEHF) solution is identified. Funding also provided for program support.
Military Global Positioning System (GPS) User Equipment (MGUE): $0.531M - Funding procured ancillary components such as cables and logistics support.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): $184.285M - provided the ability to procure multiple families of radio systems which support the primary voice and data communication requirements for the operational forces, fielding requirements, and program support. Funds supported completion of the MUOS FW and MUOS antenna procurements ($75.020M) which replaced aging Ultra High Frequency (UHF) tactical satellite capabilities; and initial procurement of High Frequency Radio II (HFR II) systems ($93.643M) which replaces aging legacy HFR systems to meet the National Security Agency (NSA) mandate for Communications Security (COMSEC) modernization with approved cryptopgraphic products and is considered a high priority in the TCM portfolio. Remaining funds ($15.622M) procured fielding/production support and ancillaries/accessories components.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission System (TWTS): $36.643M - Funding supports procurement of NGT assets as well as associated ancillary components and program support. NGT replaces the AN/TRC-170A system that is facing severe diminishing manufacturing sources and material shortages (DMSMS) and will provide C and X band alternative satellite communication frequencies.
FY 2020: $213.218M
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): $3.764M - $2M Congressional add funding will procure 16 GBS Receive Suites (AN/PRS-11) to support the Modeled Meteorological Information Manager (MMIM) program. Remaining $1.096M will continues to procure hardware to support planned tech refresh efforts and programmatic support.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): $15.957M - Funding enables acceleration for procurement of (89) Marine Corps Wideband Satellite - Expeditionary (MCWS-X) production assets, which will provide the warfighter with a man-packable, lighter, smaller, and more capable terminal. Funding also supports procurement of ancillary components, such as tech manuals, training manuals, and sparing.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): $0.000M - Decrease from FY19 to FY20 of $0.778M reflects the realignment of funding to support higher Marine Corps requirements to better align with the National Defense Strategy.
Military Global Positioning System (GPS) User Equipment (MGUE): $7.965M - Funding supports transition from DAGR to MGUE, adding to the M-Code capability.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): $156.965M - Funding continues to provide for the procurement of multiple families of radio systems which support the primary voice and data communication requirements for the operational forces. Funding will complete procurement of High Frequency Radio II (HFR II) Manpack capability, and initiate procurement of the HFR II Vehicle Radio Communication (VRC), Mobile Radio Communication (MRC) and Transportable Radio Communication (TRC) capabilities ($96.830M). Funding will also initiate procurement of Multi-Channel Manpack (MCMP) capabilities ($40.975M), spares for radio systems ($13.229M); fielding/production support and ancillaries/accessories components ($5.931M). HFR II replaces aging legacy HFR systems to meet the National Security Agency (NSA) mandate for Communications Security (COMSEC) modernization with approved cryptographic products and the procurement is considered the higher priority of the TCM portfolio. MCMP replaces legacy single channel radios to meet the NSA mandate for COMSEC modernization. During multiple field user evaluations/testing events significant temperature concerns were realized causing a procurement delay of the MCMP and MCHH radios from FY20 to FY21.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission System (TWTS): $28.567M - Funding supports procurement of LOS-R radios, ancillary components, and masts as well as engineering and program support for the TWTS portfolio. The LOS-R radio procurement enables the Marine Corps to mitigate sustainment issues and readiness concerns due to component obsolescence and end-of-life/end-of-sale (EOL/EOS) of the AN/MRC-142 and WPPL-T. The LOS-R system ensures interoperability with the Navy and is compatible with the Army's TRILOS system.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $343.250M
Global Broadcast Service (GBS): $6.294M - Funding will support hardware tech refresh efforts to mitigate obsolescence issues as well as program and fielding support. Increase of $2.530M from FY20 to FY21 procures multiple antennas, such as the Third Generation Receive Terminal antenna, or the Parabolic Dish antenna, at multiple unit costs, to support refresh and upgrades to fielded GBS systems, and fielding efforts.
Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT): $14.602M - Funding will procure remaining 47% (80) MCWS-X systems to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO). In addition, funding will continue to provide for ancillary components and fielding support. Decrease of $1.355M from FY20 to FY21 is due to procurement of 9 less MCWS-X systems in FY21 and thus achieving AAO requirement.
Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T): $1.552M ($1.539M Base; $.013M Reserve) - Increase of $1.552M from FY20 to FY21 will support tech refresh to mitigate EOL/EOS obsolescence issues. Funding allocated to procure and support tech refresh components, such as digital transmitter and circuit card assemblies, to mitigate EOL/EOS and obsolescence issues until NEXGEN AEHF solution is identified.
Military Global Positioning System (GPS) User System (MGUE): $0.150M - Decrease of $7.815M from FY20 to FY21 reflects a transition to the development phase of the Positioning, Navigation, and Timing (PNT) capabilities; remaining $0.150M will continue to support Increment I integration and ancillary equipment.
Tactical Communications Modernization (TCM): $264.421M ($230.002M Base; $34.419M Reserve) - Funding will continue to provide for the procurement of multiple families of radio systems which support the primary voice and data communication requirements for the operational forces. Funding will support procurement of Multi-Channel Manpack (MCMP) and MCMP VRC capabilities, Multi-Channel Hand Held (MCHH) and MCHH Vehicle Integration Kit (VIK) capabilities; and fielding/production support and ancillaries/accessories components. HFR II replaces aging legacy HFR systems to meet the National Security Agency (NSA) mandate for Communications Security (COMSEC) modernization with approved cryptographic products. Multi-Channel Radio Family of Systems (MCR FoS), MCMP and MCHH, replaces legacy single channel radios to meet the NSA mandate for COMSEC modernization. Increase of $107.456M from FY20 to FY21 supports the procurement of the remaining MCMP systems and the initial procurement of MCHH systems.
Terrestrial Wideband Transmission System (TWTS): $56.231M - Funding supports procurement of (45) Line of Sight Replacement radios; remaining 39% of total Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO); and program and fielding support. In FY21, to align with the Marine Corps Strategy for assured Command and Control requirements and to meet technology readiness requirements, the Line of Site Replacement (LOS-R) will begin to transition to the Line-of-Site Radio System (LRS) Family of Systems (FoS). The LRS FoS will encompass both Radio Frequency (RF) and Optical transmission capabilities through different configurations of radio, optical and mast components. Additionally, funds will procure (122) LRS FoS Mobile Radio Communication (MRC) RF capability radios. Increase of $27.664M from FY20 to FY21 supports procurement of 25% of the Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) of the LRS MRC RF capability radios.

proc:Name.footnote: GBS Program/Training Support - Decrease of $0.475M from FY20 to FY21 is due to procuring multiple antennas, such as the Third Generation Receive Terminal antenna, or the Parabolic Dish antenna, at multiple unit costs, to support refresh and upgrades to fielded GBS systems, and fielding efforts.

GBS Tech Refresh: Increase of $4.605M from FY20 to FY21 procures multiple antennas such as the Third Generation Receive Terminal antenna and the Parabolic Dish antenna which have varying unit costs, to support refresh and upgrades to fielded GBS systems.

GBS Fielding Support - Increase of $0.400M from FY20 to FY21 supports fielding costs associated with procurement of multiple antennas, such as the Third Generation Receive Terminal antenna, or the Parabolic Dish antenna as well as upgraded equipment.
VSAT Logistics/Fielding/Training Support - Increase of $0.862M from FY20 to FY21 supports MRT refresh fielding efforts occurring Q1 FY21 through Q3 FY21.

VSAT MCWS-X: Decrease of $1.350M from FY20 to FY21 supports procurement of remaining (80) MCWS-X systems; 47% of Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO). The MCWS-X will provide the warfighter with a man-packable, lighter, smaller, and more capable terminal.
VSAT MCWS Ancillary Components: Decrease of $0.867M from FY20 to FY21 reflects reduction in tech manuals, training manuals, and sparing requirements.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Communications Security (COMSEC): COMSEC is the USMC Commodities Management Office (CMO) providing support for installations and designated acquisition program COMSEC requirements, intermediate logistics, and configuration management. COMSEC provides support for Protected Secure Voice and Data transmissions, Key Management Infrastructure (KMI), the National Security Agency (NSA) directed Cryptographic Modernization of the COMSEC infrastructure, Installations (base, posts, and station), and platforms. COMSEC CMO ensures the protection of Marine Corps and Joint cyberspace systems from exploitation and attack. Cyberspace systems include wired and wireless telecommunications systems, Information Technology (IT) systems, and the content processed, stored, or transmitted therein. Rapid changes in the underlying commercial and government cyber infrastructures makes cyber security an increasingly complex and dynamic problem. COMSEC CMO provides the Warfighter the essential information trust characteristics of availability, confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation.
Joint Communications Support Element (JCSE): Joint Communications Support Element (JCSE), headquartered at MacDill Air Force Base, Fla., rapidly delivers secure, reliable, and scalable command, control, communications, and computer capabilities (C4) ranging from small mobile team missions to full Joint task force headquarters (JTF HQ) deployments.
Combat Data Network (CDN) (formerly Tactical Data Network (TDN) Data Distribution System - Modular (DDS-M)): The CDN provides the commander a modular, integrated, and interoperable Internet Protocol (IP) - based Local Area Network (LAN) and Wide Area Network (WAN) capability that forms the data communications backbone to tactical organizations within a Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF). The CDN provides an extension of the Defense Information System Network (DISN), Secret Internet Protocol Router Network (SIPRNet), Sensitive But Unclassified (SBU), Non-secure Internet Protocol Router Network (NIPRNet) as well as a coalition networking. The CDN provides Marine Corps maneuver elements with a modular and scalable IP data transport capability by providing computers, servers, routers, data switches, cabling, multiple connections to various tactical transmission devices, contains integral In-line Network Encryption (INE) device supporting IP Security (IPSec), and Virtual Private Networking (VPN). CDN also provides software support for email, telephone, and internet services while in a tactical environment. CDN is currently designated as the Common Hosting Environment (CHE) for tactical networking. CHE will consolidate like capabilities from various programs of record, primarily server capacity and network access switching, under a single program of record. CHE will simplify the equipment string and will help reduce the overall Size, Weight, and Power (SWaP) requirements for the MAGTF. In FY21 the Combat Operations Center (COC) requirements transitions into the Combat Data Network (CDN) program under the title Common Hosting Environment (CHE).
Tactical Voice Switching System (TVSS): The TVSS is a modular Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) circuit switch capable system that provides Voice Over Internet Protocol telecommunications, multiplexing, transmission encryption, and group modem capabilities in one system for tactical telephony voice communications. TVSS is reaching end of life and is planned to be removed from the fleet inventory by the end of FY21.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $31.175M ($28.727M Active, $2.448M Reserves)
COMSEC: $0.324M ($0.066M Active, $0.258M Reserves). Funding provided for procurements of replacement COMSEC equipment and ancillary devices.
JCSE: $0.481M. Funds the Marine Corps mandated share of efforts to keep the JCSE equipped with the latest state-of-the-art equipment to accomplish its Joint Staff Mission. The specific purpose will be determined at the annual JCSE modernization review.
CDN: $30.370M ($28.180M Active, $2.190M Reserves). FY19 funds supported technology refresh Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs), procurement, and fielding for various CDN equipment. 3.1 Program Spt/Fielding/CLS/Training funds supported management, acquisition, logistics, manpower support, personnel, and training analysis as well as training plan development and associated support. 3.3 ECP Network Equipment funds supported procurement of the Local Area Network (LAN) Services Module (Routers). 3.4 Small Form Factor funds supported procurement of additional quantities of Small Form Factor equipment to reduce size, weight, and power (SWaP). 3.9 ECP Network Equipment funds supported procurement of the Local Area Network (LAN) Services Module (Routers) for Reserve Units. 3.10 Small Form Factor (Reserve) funds supported procurement of additional quantities of Small Form Factor equipment to reduce size, weight, and power (SWaP) for Reserve Units.
FY 2020: $23.781M ($19.282M Active, $4.499M Reserves)
COMSEC: $1.250M ($0.987M Active, $0.263M Reserves). Funding continues to procure replacement components for damaged COMSEC equipment, ancillary devices, and program support for product verification/validation testing.
JCSE: $0.491M. Funds the Marine Corps mandated share of efforts to keep the JCSE equipped with the latest state-of-the-art equipment to accomplish its Joint Staff Mission. The specific purpose will be determined at the annual JCSE modernization review.
CDN: $22.040M ($17.804M Active, $4.236M Reserves). FY20 funds support technology refresh Engineering Change Proposals, procurement and fielding for various parts of the CDN equipment family. The Small Form Factor activities in FY20 include the execution of material optional contract line items based on the FY19 procurement engineering effort. Additionally, Small Form Factor funds (active/reserve) support the procurement of additional quantities of Small Form Factor equipment to reduce size, weight, and power (SWaP). ECP Network Equipment funds support the procurement of routers. ECP Network Equipment (Reserves) funds support the procurement of hardware associated with the technology refresh cycle which upgrades the equipment every three to five years.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $40.627M ($32.564M Active, $8.063M Reserves)
COMSEC: $1.283M ($1.031M Active, $0.252M Reserves). The increase of $0.047M from FY20 to FY21 supports COMSEC modernization and Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) upgrades to currently fielded assets. FY21 funds will continue to support COMSEC modernization and Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) upgrades to currently fielded assets, in support of Expeditionary Force 21 and National Security Agency guidelines. Additionally, funding will continue to procure replacements for COMSEC equipment, ancillary devices, and program support for product verification/validation testing.
JCSE: Active, $0.552M ($0.501M Active, $0.051M Reserves). The increase of $0.0610M from FY20 to FY21 reflects the Marine Corps mandated share of efforts to keep the JCSE equipped with the latest state-of-the-art equipment to accomplish its Joint Staff Mission. The specific purpose will be determined at the annual JCSE modernization review.
CDN: $38.792M ($31.032M Active, $7.760M Reserves). The increase of $16.752M from FY20 to FY21 supports the procurement of network switches. There is a more robust requirement moving forward to ensure up-to-date, effective equipment with the absorption of COC equipment and requirements into the Common Hosting Environment (CHE) underneath CDN. Specifically, FY21 funds will support technology refresh Engineering Change Proposals, procurement, and fielding for various parts of the CDN equipment family. 3.1 Program Support/Fielding/Contractor Logistics Support/Training funds will support management, acquisition, logistics, manpower support, personnel, and training analysis as well as training plan development and associated support. 3.3 ECP Network Equipment funds will support procurement of the Switches, which will be a multiple year procurement across FY21 and FY22. Switches are at the end of support in FY23 and the manufacturer will no longer provide cyber security updates. The program will procure over 3,300 switches and other critical components necessary across the procurement timeline. 3.7 ECP Network Equipment (Reserves) funds will also support a multiple year procurement across FY21 and FY22 of switches and other components necessary to support the reserve component equipment set. The program office will procure over 900 switches and other critical components.

proc:Name.footnote: COMSEC Hardware - Increase of $0.047M from FY20 to FY21 supports COMSEC modernization and Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) upgrades to currently fielded assets.

CDN: Program Spt/Fielding/CLS/Training decrease of $1.278M from FY20 to FY21 reflects efficiencies achieved as a result of Common Hosting Environment (CHE) activities reducing the number of efforts necessary to maintain capability.

CDN: ECP Network Equipment increase of $20.773M from FY20 to FY21 reflects procurement of switches and other components that extend the network to end user devices. This will be a multiple year procurement across FY21 and FY22. The program office will procure over 3,300 switches and other critical components necessary to provide a resilient and secure network. The increased requirement is due to the absorption of COC equipment and requirements into the CHE.
ECP Small Form Factor decrease of $6.267M from FY20 to FY21 reflects initial procurement of the Small Form Factor systems and the transition to a refresh cycle.

CDN: ECP Network Equipment (Reserves) increase of $5.714M from FY20 to FY21 reflects procurement of switches and other components that extend the network to end user devices, which will be a multiple year procurement across FY21 and FY22. The program office will procure over 900 switches and other critical components necessary to provide a resilient and secure network and operational environment to enable deployed Marines [by way of connectivity to every end user device] access to the tactical network.
CDN ECP Small Form Factor (Reserves) decrease of $2.190M from FY20 to FY21 reflects initial procurement of the Small Form Factor systems and the transition to a refresh cycle.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) provides all Marine Corps installations with the base area network communications infrastructure that connects the end-user to the DISA network. BTI modernizes, sustains, upgrades and enhances the telecommunications systems infrastructure for all Marine Corps Installations in order to meet the demands required to support the 5th Element of the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF). BTI is designed to maintain current industry standards as they relate to technological capabilities for all voice, video and data services (both wired and wireless connections) and are transported via each installation's infrastructure. These data services include, support for but are not limited to, Enhanced 911 (E911), Video-Teleconferencing, Integrated Services Digital Network, Marine Corps Enterprise Network, Energy Monitoring Control Systems, Intrusion Detection Systems, Access Control Systems, Fire Alarm Control Networks and Fleet Training Systems. This includes supporting systems such as optical networks, telecommunications management systems, primary power, voice mail, teleconferencing, and outside plant infrastructure. The ongoing focus is technology refresh and standardization on DISA Unified Capabilities (UC) (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through modernization of installation infrastructure in order to maintain connection to the DISA network. This line item includes funding specified for Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) within the above details.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI) is a framework of laws, policies, procedures, and technologies for the use of digital credentials, which provide confidentiality, integrity, authenticity, and non-repudiation in electronic communications and transactions. PKI allows secure access to IT systems. PKI has the ability to electronically sign documents, encrypt messages and documents, and to authenticate and protect web access... In compliance with DOD policy and direction, the USMC Public Key Infrastructure Program (PKI) program provides the resources, manpower and equipment (hardware and software), dedicated to the management (i.e.: generation, production, distribution, control, accounting and destruction) of keys and certificates used by public key-based security services to include NIPRNet and SIPRNet both garrison and deployed. The PKI program operates the USMC Certificate Validation Infrastructure necessary to ensure that only authorized users and server based applications are allowed to operate on the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN). These services are required for user access to all information system components on the MCEN including network accounts, applications and web sites. PKI must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments. Beginning in FY20, PKI was transferred to a new procurement line item, 4645 Cyberspace Activities, in order to consolidate Marine Corps Cyberspace Procurement Activities into one LI.
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS) is a centrally managed program to field a technology solution in support of emergency dispatch personnel that facilitates timely responses when emergency calls for service are received. CERS provides command and coordination dispatch functions for first responders to support All-Hazard missions. It standardizes Emergency Dispatch Centers to provide notification functions, resource management and situational awareness in order to increase efficient emergency and day-to-day first responder operations. CERS capability is achieved through delivery of Enhanced 911 (E911) and emergency dispatch capabilities consisting of Computer Aided Dispatch (CAD), Fire Station Alerting (FSA) and Mobile Data Computers (MDC) for first responder's vehicles.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR) is a modern, digital, Association of Public Safety Communications Officials Project 25 Trunked radio system at all Marine Corps Bases, Posts and Stations (BPS). It provides the wireless Radio Frequency (RF) communications that are required to support the Consolidated Emergency Response System and First Responders (i.e. Police, Fire, Emergency Medical Services) as part of the Emergency Management Command and Coordination initiative. Specifically, the radio system provides RF coverage to BPS populated areas and roads in-between, permitting positive command and coordination between Dispatchers and First Responders and enables their ability to respond to incidents during normal, crisis, and recovery operations. In the wake of 9/11 and the Ft. Hood incident, DoD recognized that effective emergency communications and mutual aid support operation are key elements in providing homeland security, reducing the loss of life and the preservation of property. Thus, the objective for the E-LMR acquisition is to bring forth a reliable interoperability wireless communication system with a limited data capability. This line item includes funding specified for Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) within the above details.
TEST, EVALUATION, & ENGINEER ENVIRONMENT (T&E) is a Marine Corps Tactical Systems Support Activity (MCTSSA) provides the only Marine Corps organic, operationally relevant, MAGTF Command, Control, Communications, Computers, and Intelligence (C4I) architecture for testing and engineering tasks. This environment is the sole organic solution in the Marine Corps for Link-16 Tactical Data Link Networks for air-to- air, ship, and shore targeting and messaging, validated at MCTSSA before Marine/Navy use in theater. The environment also provides Marine Corps organic equipment, environments, operators, and testers for Joint Communications Exercises, Joint Interoperability Testing, and Systems of System testing. Funding supports modernization and expansion of the MAGTF Systems Integration Environment at MCTSSA for non-Table of Equipment items: Communications Backbone, Test Tool/Data Collection Hardware/Software, and Computers. The environment is essential to operating forces support for fielded C4I systems, as well as evaluating USMC and Joint C4I systems in a controlled, repeatable, and re-configurable manner that reduces program risk and identifies significant deficiencies prior to fielding to the operating forces. More than forty Marine Corps C4I programs and systems rely on MCTSSA support.
MARINE CORPS INFORMATION OPERATIONS PROGRAM (MCIOP) provides MAGTF commanders and the Marine Corps a responsive and effective full-spectrum information operations (IO) planning and psychological operations delivery capability by means of deployable support teams and a comprehensive general support IO reach-back capability in order to integrate IO into Marine Corps operations. Multiple classification levels require separate Information Technology (IT) infrastructure to support each classification level in accordance with National Security Agency and Defense Intelligence Agency standards. This includes equipment necessary for connecting internal MCIOC IT infrastructure (voice, video, and data) with the existing Marine Corps Base Quantico support infrastructure.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $72.842M
Beginning in FY19, MCIOP and TEEE funding moved from BLI 4635 (COMM & ELEC INFRASTRUCTURE SUPT) to BLI 4620 (ITEMS UNDER $5 MILLION-COMM & ELEC).
Beginning in FY20, PKI funding moves to BLI 4645 (CYBERSPACE ACTIVITIES).
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) $44.725M:
DPRI - $21.006M FY 2019 funding, executed by Space and Naval Warfare Center (SPAWAR), procured, installed, and accredited Information Technology (IT) systems. The scope of the work supported the ongoing eight MILCON projects. There are two Japanese funded MILCON projects (J-007 Waterfront HQ and J-755 Urban Combat Trng) and six U.S. funded MILCON projects (P-250 MALS Fac, P-260 Corrosion Ctrl Hangar, P-270 ACE Gym & Dining, P-295 Ordnance Ops, P-601 Aircraft Maintenance #2, and P-715 KD Ranges). The IT systems are integral to making the facilities complete and useable. All projects are vital to supporting the relocation of Marines from Okinawa to Guam.
UC/DWDM - $23.719M supported the technology refresh and standardization of DISA Unified Capabilities (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through UC/DWDM modernization at two Marine Corps Installations. Modernization and upgrade of the network telecommunications infrastructure is necessary to ensure the delivery of voice, video, and data services that support the day-to-day operations of the Base, Post, and Station.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI): $0.119M funding supported the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the (NIPRNet and SIPRNet) for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet CYBERCOM's Tasking Order requiring the use of hardware tokens for access to networks, network resources and secure email in accordance with DODI 8520.02 and DODI 8520.03. Funding will also be utilized to procure necessary tokens and equipment for SIPRNet Token issuance across the MCEN as well as implementation of the DOD PKI NIPRNet Enterprise Alternate Token Management System.
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS): $10.601M supported network connection, procurement, and fielding of emergency dispatch systems as well as the start of the hardware/software upgrade to support the DoD CIO Windows 10 mandate. This requirement is necessary to provide effective Public Safety Communications and notifications to emergency responders.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR): $11.275M supported the completion of the Western Region Infrastructure (WRI) modernization and the hardware/software upgrade to support the DoD CIO Windows 10 mandate
DPRI $6.122M funding supported DPRI Guam requirements for ELMR capability expansion from 10 GTR channels to 20 GTR channels in support of P-715 Live Fire Training Range Complex project for the planned build-up of USMC personnel at Northwest Field to Finegayan (future MCB Guam). It will also increase two way radio usage on the Joint Regional Marianas (JRM) ELMR System's Ritidian site and max-out the site's capacity.
FY 2020: $79.740M
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) $73.497M
DPRI (Cost Element 1.1), $0.248M funding supports DPRI Okinawa Telecom infrastructure supporting internal and external communications. Projects include MC0508: Base Communications Building, MC0512-T: Theater, MC0512-T-E: 4 BEQs.
Unified Capabilities/Dense Wave Division Multiplexing (Cost Element 1.2) $14.649M funding provides for the upgrade and standardization of DISA Unified Capabilities (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through UC/DWDM modernization at one Marine Corps Installation. Modernization and upgrade of the Installation's transport infrastructure is necessary to ensure the delivery of voice, video, and data services that support the day-to-day operations of the Base, Post, and Station. This modernized transport capability provides for the underlying infrastructure supporting transformational requirements identified in the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control strategy (i.e. migration to the cloud, modernizing the network). These modernizations to the transport infrastructure are required to avoid severe degradation and potential loss of voice, video, and data services, jeopardizing Base operations, unit coordination and critical life safety services.
Hurricane Disaster Recovery (Cost Element 1.4) $58.6M funding provides for replacement and upgrade of communications equipment impacted by natural disasters. This procurement will replace damaged equipment and enhance existing equipment with more hurricane resilient infrastructure
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS): $1.958M
Tech Refresh Modernization (Cost Element 2.1) $1.000M funding provides for the modernization of the E911 system to ensure that the components in the current system do not become end of life and unsupported by the vendor. If the aging, end of life equipment is not replaced, then these aging network devices will be removed from the network as a result of not receiving cybersecurity updates which will lead to the Consolidated Emergency Response System being unable to operate which will significantly degrade the first responder's ability to respond to emergency situations in a timely manner.
Tech Refresh Engineering (Cost Element 2.2) $0.958M funding provides for engineering associated with the start of technical refresh modernization.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR): $4.285M
Subscriber Units Multi-Band Radios (MBRs) Refresh (Cost Element 4.1) $3.207M funding provides for the continued replacement of MBRs which are becoming end of life and unsupported by the vendor. If this equipment is not replaced then these antiquated end of life mobile radios would prevent USMC First Responders and Range and Training Area personnel from achieving operational mission support to protect life and property on USMC Installations.
Fielding Activities (Cost Element 4.6) $1.045M funding provides for the fielding activities associated with the multi-band radio (MBR) technical refresh which replaces end of life mobile radios. This cost element directly supports Cost Element 4.1.
E-LMR DPRI (Cost Element 4.8) $0.033M funding is required to procure equipment to expand the current ELMR network that supports JRM. JRM provides ELMR support for all DOD and Federal organizations on the island of Guam. ELMR expansion is vital to supporting the relocation of Marines from Okinawa to Guam.
FY 2021 Request: $43.782M
BASE TELECOMMUNICATIONS INFRASTRUCTURE (BTI) $27.651M:
DPRI (Cost Element 1.1) $16.399M will support DPRI in FY 2021 funding, executed by Naval Information Warfare Systems Command (NAVWAR), and will procure, install, and accredit, Information Technology (IT) systems. BTI funding (DPRI Guam: $11.114M) for FY21 supports the C4IT outfitting of newly constructed facilities for MCBG. Specifically, MILCON projects J-011 Base Admin Building, J-016 BEQ A, P-311 Central Fuel Station, and P-270 ACE Gym & Dining, P-735 Guam MG Range, P-804 CIF Warehouse, and Mamizu project J-030 BEQ B are scheduled for procurement and installation. Without this funding, facilities will not be complete/usable, and forces will be unable to move off of Okinawa. Any delays to force flow have both negative political and cost ramifications. The IT systems are integral to making the facilities complete and useable. BTI funding (DPRI Okinawa: $4.941M - (Futenma Replacement Facility (FRF) ($64K) and Okinawa Consolidation (OKICON) ($4.877M)) for FY21 supports the scope of the work on 13 construction projects in Okinawa funded by the Government of Japan related to the Futenma Replacement Facility: MC0518T Schwab Chapel,MC2541T Schwab Waste Water Treatment Plant, and MC2579T Schwab Electrical Substation; and Okinawa Consolidation: MC4008T Hansen Fire Station, MC4201T Foster Mega Warehouse, MC4202T Foster 3rd Dental BN HQ/Warehouse, MC4203T Foster MCIPAC EOD, MC4206T Foster IPAC/Base Safety/ Licensing/ FRF, MC4209T Foster III MEF BSTF, MC4212T Foster Postal Distribution Center, MC4213T Foster III MEF Division/Wing HQ, MC4216T Foster 1st MAW HQ/MWHS-1 HQ/ Battalion/ Sq HQ of Special Sec Comm, and MC4217T Foster III MEF HQ Parking Structure. Cost Element 1.1 funding increase of $16.151M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the alignment of the DPRI BTI installation schedule with the Guam and Okinawa construction schedule.
Unified Capabilities/Dense Wave Division Multiplexing (Cost Element 1.2) $11.252M. Funding decrease of $3.397M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the decrease in scope and complexity of the modernization effort at the Installation receiving the UC/DWDM upgrade. Funding in this cost element will provide for the upgrade and standardization of DISA Unified Capabilities (voice, video, collaboration, and data) through UC/DWDM modernization at one Marine Corps Installation. Modernization and upgrade of the Installation's transport infrastructure is necessary to ensure the delivery of voice, video, and data services that support the day-to-day operations of the Base, Post, and Station. This modernized transport capability provides for the underlying infrastructure supporting transformational requirements identified in the Marine Corps' Assured Command and Control strategy (i.e. migration to the cloud, modernizing the network). These modernizations to the transport infrastructure are required to avoid severe degradation and potential loss of voice, video, and data services, jeopardizing Base operations, unit coordination and critical life safety services.
CONSOLIDATED EMERGENCY RESPONSE SYSTEM (CERS): $5.385M
Tech Refresh Modernization (Cost Element 2.1) $4.500M. Funding increase of $3.500M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 provides for the modernization of the E911 system to ensure that the components in the current system do not become end of life and unsupported by the vendor. If the aging, end of life equipment is not replaced, then these aging network devices will be removed from the network as a result of not receiving cybersecurity updates which will lead to the Consolidated Emergency Response System being unable to operate which will significantly degrade the first responder's ability to respond to emergency situations in a timely manner. Without modernization of the E911 system, potential loss of life is increased due to late response time to emergency situations.
Tech Refresh Engineering (Cost Element 2.2) $0.000M. Cost Element 2.2 funding decrease of $0.958M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the planned completion of technical refresh engineering in FY 2020 as technical refresh modernization and initial hardware procurement begins in FY 2020.
Tech Refresh Fielding Activities (Cost Element 2.3) $0.885M. Funding increase of $0.885M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 supports the planned modernization efforts occurring in FY 2021.
ENTERPRISE LAND MOBILE RADIOS (E-LMR): $10.746M
Subscriber Units Multi-Band Radios (MBRs) Refresh (Cost Element 4.1) $3.336M. Funding provides for the continued replacement of MBRs which are becoming end of life and unsupported by the vendor. If this equipment is not replaced then these antiquated end of life mobile radios would prevent USMC First Responders and Range and Training Area personnel from achieving operational mission support to protect life and property on USMC Installations. Cost Element 4.1 funding increase of $0.129M from FY 2020 is due to the ramp up of MBR refresh in FY 2021.
Eastern Region Infrastructure (ERI) Refresh (Cost Element 4.3) funding increase of $4.204M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the start of ERI refresh in FY 2021. This cost element will provide for the replacement of equipment that will be going end of life, if this equipment is not replaced then it will impact the first responders ability to carry out their missions. This equipment is required to ensure that First Responders are able to effectively communicate and respond to emergencies in a timely manner. The program is on a 7 year refresh cycle and its current equipment is becoming obsolete and requires immediate replacement and modernization.
Fielding Activities (Cost Element 4.6) $3.070M. Funding provides for the fielding activities associated with the multi-band radio (MBR) technical refresh and the Eastern Region Infrastructure (ERI) refresh. Fielding Activities (Cost Element 4.6) increase of $2.025M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the start of the Eastern Region Infrastructure (ERI) tech refresh. This cost element provides fielding support for the ongoing fielding efforts for ELMR.
E-LMR DPRI (Cost Element 4.8) $0.136M. Funding increased $0.103M from FY 2020 to FY 2021, funding is required to procure equipment to expand the current ELMR network that supports JRM. JRM provides ELMR support for all DOD and Federal organizations on the island of Guam. ELMR expansion is vital to supporting the relocation of Marines from Okinawa to Guam.
Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
