proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Beginning in FY20, efforts in this line item (LI) 4645 (Cyberspace Activities) were transferred from other LIs in order to better align resources with mission and to increase transparency to support better decisions. Specifically, U.S. Marine Forces Cyberspace Command investments were transferred from LI 4630 (Common Computer Resources) and LI 4635 (Communications and Electrical Infrastructure Support) into LI 4645 (Cyberspace Activities).
ROBUST INFRASTRUCTURE (FORMERLY TITLED MARFORCYBER) directly supports U.S. Cyber Command Execute Order 19-0035: Cyber Capability to Support the Cyber Mission Force. U.S. Cyber Command Execute Order 19-0035 directs MARFORCYBER to establish and sustain a secure and effective common firing platform for offensive cyber missions. Currently used platforms are not interoperable or efficient, limiting flexibility and effectiveness of cyber mission forces. Through divesting in multiple legacy platforms and investing in a joint common access platform (JCAP) that will be established across all Joint Mission Operations Centers (JMOCs), offensive operations will be more effective and efficient, improving mobility, resiliency, collaboration, force multiplication, and scalability.
SECURE, OPERATE, DEFEND AND ENABLE the Marine Corps Cyberspace Environment (MCCE)(FORMERLY TITLED MCCOG) . Marine Forces Cyberspace Command is responsible for enhancing freedom of action across the Cyberspace domain, while denying the efforts of adversaries to degrade or disrupt this advantage through cyberspace. The Marine Corps Cyberspace Operations Group (MCCOG) is a command element under Marine Corps Forces Cyberspace Command responsible for securing, operating, and defending the Marine Corps Cyberspace Environment (MCCE) - to include providing network situational awareness; command and control; and technical support to Marine Corps operating forces and supporting establishment organizations, both in garrison and while deployed. In addition to being the primary DOD Cybersecurity Service Provider (CSSP) for the U.S. Marine Corps and only certified Red Team, MCCOG performs Vulnerability Management, Malware Protection, Web Assessment, Hunt Operations, and Cyber Incident Response focused on preventing and responding to prevent and respond to security incidents. The MCCOG delivers enterprise services for the Marine Corps to include Directory, Enterprise Storage, Messaging, Application Management, Mobility, Deployed Support, Mainframe, and Unified Communication.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI) is a framework of laws, policies, procedures, and technologies for the use of digital credentials, which provide confidentiality, integrity, authenticity, and non-repudiation in electronic communications and transactions. PKI allows secure access to IT systems. PKI has the ability to electronically sign documents, encrypt messages and documents, and to authenticate and protect web access... In compliance with DOD policy and direction, the USMC Public Key Infrastructure Program (PKI) program provides the resources, manpower and equipment (hardware and software), dedicated to the management (i.e.: generation, production, distribution, control, accounting and destruction) of keys and certificates used by public key-based security services to include NIPRNet and SIPRNet both garrison and deployed. The PKI program operates the USMC Certificate Validation Infrastructure necessary to ensure that only authorized users and server based applications are allowed to operate on the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN). These services are required for user access to all information system components on the MCEN including network accounts, applications and web sites. PKI must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments.
USMC MAGTF DCO-IDM Suite: The USMC Marine Corps Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Defensive Cyberspace Operations-Internal Defensive Measures (DCO-IDM) Suite program provides the self-contained, fly-away equipment (hardware and software) for MAGTF DCO-IDM Teams to conduct vulnerability analysis (VA), incident response (IR), and other DCO-IDM functions concurrently on classified and unclassified networks. The teams utilize the interface (a laptop), data from passive and active sensors (servers, laptops, and taps), and the analytic capability from the hardware and software in order to determine the state of the supported commander's network, host, and major weapon systems. Software includes Government Off-the-Shelf (GOTS), Commercial Off-the-Shelf (COTS), and free and open-source software (FOSS). MAGTF DCO Suites are intended to be part of a common family of systems in support of MAGTF cyberspace operations. MAGTF DCO-IDM Suites must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2020: $27.632M Active; $0.0M Reserve
MARINE CORPS CYBERSPACE OPERATIONS GROUP (MCCOG): FY20 Base Appropriation Request: $7.841M procures hardware and software for Defensive Cyber Operations Support, remote forensics solutions, and Hunt Deployable suites and provides technical refresh for the USMC Unified Communications project items such as Distributed Computing Equipment, Video Teleconferencing and Multi-Media Equipment, Network Hardware, Telephone Equipment, and Telepresence Content Server. Prior to FY20 this program was aligned to LI 4630.
MARFORCYBER: FY20 Base Appropriation Request: $14.289M procures hardware and software for Deployable Mission Support Systems (DMSS). DMSS kits are required in order for MARFORCYBER to provide Marine Corps units all across the globe with cyberspace activity support. Procures tools, platforms, infrastructure, and sustainment for various Offensive Cyberspace Operations (OCO) requirements to encourage an appropriate Service-Level analysis for the Joint Mission Operations Center (JMOC) Meade requirement in support of United States Cyberspace Command (USCC) and Joint Forces Headquarters Cyber (JFHQ-c) mission, and procures a Defensive Cyberspace Operations War room, Commercial Solutions for Classified (CSfC), engineering, tools, platforms, OCO, DCO infrastructure, and sustainment requirements. Prior to FY20 this program was aligned to LI 4630.
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI): FY20 Appropriation Request: $0.502M funding supports the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the (NIPRNet and SIPRNet) for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet DOD CIO requirement. The CVI is required in order for end users to authenticate themselves when signing onto Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) accounts. These services are required for user access to all information system components on the MCEN including network accounts, applications and web sites. PKI must be operable in garrison and tactical/deployed environments. Prior to FY20 this program was aligned to LI 4635.
USMC MAGTF DCO-IDM Suite: $5.000M procures MAGTF DCO-IDM Suites for fielding to I, II, & III MEF DCO-IDM Companies and Marine Corps Communications-Electronics School. Previously the Operating Forces utilized the DMSS kits for Defensive Cyberspace Operations. This is a new start in FY20.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation: $53.896M Active; $0.0M Reserve
ROBUST INFRASTRUCTURE (FORMERLY TITLED MARFORCYBER) ($38.110 million): Supports Commander, U.S. Cyber Command Executive Order 19-0035: Cyber Capability to Support the Cyber Mission Forces. Specifically, the increase of $23.821M from FY20 to FY21 will procure a cyber attack platform that will improve cyberspace operations by increasing the capacity for offensive cyber missions; increasing resiliency of the offensive cyber platform; increasing the availability of the offensive cyber platform and associated weapons/targets for the conduct of missions; increasing automation in order to decrease manpower requirements and delays in setup/disassembly to execute operations.
These investment will enable consolidation, convergence, and configuration of cyber infrastructure into a common firing platform to enable operations based on cyber tasking orders as well as providing operable hardware and workstations for cyber mission forces to conduct operations. Robust Infrastructure will increase the capacity for offensive cyber missions by 66% and will increase the availability of the offensive cyberspace platforms and associated weapons by 300%.
SECURE, OPERATE, DEFEND AND ENABLE (FORMERLY TITLED MCCOG) ($7.994 million): The increase of $0.153M from FY20 to FY21 will cover the increased costs and inflation of hardware and software required to refresh outdated hardware and software that is vulnerable to attacks from adversaries. These resources will procure hardware and software to refreshe outdated hardware and software that is vulnerable to attacks from adversaries. In addition, the hardware and software increases system performance to improve network operational availability for warfighters and commanders.
DEFENSIVE CYBER OPERATIONS - INTERNAL DEFENSIVE MEASURES (DCO-IDM) ($6.324 million): The $1.324M increase from FY20 to FY21 due to requirement for additional 3 DCO-IDM's in FY21 to defend against increased sophistication from near peer adversaries. $6.324M in FY21 will procure 13 DCO-IDM for fielding to First, Second, and Third Marine Expeditionary Forces. Also, $0.789M funding supports procurement of Cyber Immersive Training Environment (CITE 2.0), which enables cyber mission forces to conduct training, and mission rehearsal that increase the knowledge, skills, and abilities of Marines defending the Marine Corps Cyberspace Environment (MCCE).
PUBLIC KEY INFRASTRUCTURE (PKI) ($1.468 million): Funding will support the continuation of PKI hardware and software implementation across the (NIPRNet and SIPRNet) for both garrison and deployed networks in order to meet national requirements for the use of hardware tokens for access to networks, network resources, and secure email. Funding will also be utilized to procure necessary equipment and tokens for SIPRNet Token issuance across the MCEN as well as implementation of the DOD PKI NIPRNet Enterprise Alternate Token Management System. The increase of $0.966M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the technical refresh cycle of equipment scheduled in FY21.

proc:Name.footnote: The $1.324M increase from FY20 to FY21 results from requiring an additional 3 DCO-IDM suites in FY21 to defend against increased sophistication from near peer adversaries.

proc:Item.proc:Name: 1.1) DEFENSIVE CYBER OPERATIONS - INTERNAL DEFENSIVE MEASURES

proc:Name.footnote: The $23.821M increase from FY20 to FY21 is due to the procurement of software and hardware that form a common cyber firing attack platform. USCYBERCOM Executive Order (EXORD) 19-0035 directs MARFORCYBER to establish and sustain a secure and effective common firing platform for offensive cyber missions. Currently used platforms are not interoperable or efficient, limiting flexibility and effectiveness of cyber mission forces.
Prior to FY20, PKI funds were requested in LI 4635, Cost Element 3.1. The increase of $0.966M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the technical refresh cycle of equipment scheduled in FY21.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - The Commercial Cargo Vehicles program is a centrally managed program for procurement of commercially-available and general purpose vehicles such as heavy and light trucks, special purpose trucks, certain fire department trucks, refuse collection trucks, tanker trucks and all types of trailers. Additionally, the program supports Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) requirements.
Emergency Response Vehicles (ERV) - Replaces firefighting apparatuses for maintaining the minimal installations ERV requirements for structural and airfield operations capabilities throughout the Marine Corps. Additionally, the program supports DPRI requirements to outfit the new Government of Japan funded J-008 Fire Station for the future Marine Corps Base Guam. Specifically, this funding will procure the Command Vehicle, Aerial Ladder Truck, Fire Engine, HAZMAT Rescue Vehicle, and Water Tender.
Commercial Passenger Vehicles (CPV) - CPV is a centrally managed program for the procurement of commercially available vehicles, such as sedans, vans and buses of various sizes. These vehicles are primarily used for passenger transportation on Marine Corps Base Japan, where leases are rarely economical.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - Funds the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $22.464M
Commercial Passenger Vehicles - $3.643M: Funds continued to procure buses capable of transporting 33-60 passengers to replace the over-aged buses currently being used to provide intra shuttle services for Marine Corps bases in Okinawa. Additionally, vans capable of seating 7-8 passengers, sedans and law enforcement sedans will be procured to replace over-aged vehicles to better support the operation and mission of Marine Corps Installations Pacific (MCIPAC). This operating force support provides quality of life transportation for service-members and families stationed on Marine Corps Installations. Funds will also be used for the procurement of mission critical passenger vehicles (pickup trucks and passenger vans capable of transporting 7-8 passengers) needed for the recent transition of Townsend Bombing Range from the Georgia Air National Guard to the Marine Corps. The aging vehicles are increasingly unreliable and are costly to maintain and negatively impact mission capability.
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - $8.469M: Funds continued to procure low speed electric vehicles, various types of trailers (specialty, lowbed & flatbed) and trucks (fuel, stake-bed, nurse unit, semi-tractor, sewer maintenance & pickup) necessary for Installations support and to provide support for operating forces' critical training and logistics missions. Additionally, provide lift for combat readiness training, the transportation of equipment in support of deployments and the return of deployed forces. Vehicles being procured for California Bases will comply with California Air Resource Board (CARB) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality. Non-compliance results in fines of $10k per day, per vehicle. Funds will also be used to procure mission critical commercial cargo vehicles (tractor trucks, low-boy trailers, etc.) used to move equipment needed to operate and maintain ranges, training areas, facilities, and fight wild land fires on Marine Corps Installations.
Commercial Cargo Vehicles Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) Guam - $1.826M procured (4) JP-5 fuel trucks required to support Marine Corps aviation operations on the North ramp of Naval Support Activity Andersen Air Force Base.
Emergency Response Vehicles - $3.492M: Funds procured fire trucks (pumpers/aerial), rescue trucks, and ambulances for Marine Corps activities and commands. The funds will also procure brush trucks and water extenders to maintain ranges, training areas and facilities on Marine Corps Installations.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - $5.034M - Funded the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies.
FY 2020: $28.913M
Commercial Passenger Vehicles - $4.411M: Funding continues to recapitalize over-aged buses capable of transporting 33-60 passengers in order to provide safe intra shuttle services for Marine Corps bases in Okinawa. Additionally, vans capable of seating 7-8 passengers, sedans and law enforcement sedans will be procured to replace over-aged vehicles to better support the operation and mission of Marine Corps Installations Pacific (MCIPAC) and provide vehicle transportation primarily used for operational forces on Marine Corps Bases Japan, where the Marine Corps cannot lease these vehicles economically. Replacing these vehicles provide a "right-type" and "right-size" solution to support the operation and mission of the USMC OCONUS (Japan) commands by making it possible to safely move operational forces for home station training and deployments. The aged vehicles are increasingly unreliable and are costly to maintain and negatively impact mission capability.
Funds in the amount of $0.136M are for the procurement of mission critical passenger vehicles (pickup trucks, vans, etc.) that is essential to the continuity of operating and maintaining 35K acres of Townsend Bombing Range (TBR) to accommodate air-to-ground delivery of precision guided munitions (PGM).
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - $10.444M: Funds recapitalizes a portfolio of non-tactical vehicles such as low speed electric vehicles, various types of trailers (specialty, lowbed & flatbed) and trucks (fuel, stake-bed, nurse unit, semi-tractor, sewer maintenance & pickup). Recapitalization of over-aged vehicles provide safer non-tactical cargo vehicle support for transportation of things (TOT) necessary to move operational forces for home station training and deployment movements and to support operations and maintenance of Marine Corps Installations. On/off-road vehicles being procured for California Bases must comply with California Air Resource Board (CARB) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality. Non-compliance results in fines of $10k per day, per vehicle.
Funds in the amount of $0.370M of the $10.444M procures mission critical commercial cargo vehicles (tractor trucks, low-boy trailers, etc.) to operate and maintain 35K acres of Townsend Bombing Range (TBR) to accommodate air-to-ground delivery of precision guided munitions (PGM).
Emergency Response Vehicles - $5.820M: Funds procures fire trucks (pumpers/aerial), rescue trucks, and ambulances for Marine Corps activities and commands. The funds will also procure brush trucks and water extenders to maintain ranges, training areas and facilities on Marine Corps Installations.
Funds in the amount of $1.711M of the $5.820M procures an aerial ladder truck for the Government of Japan funded J-008 Fire Station for future Marine Corps Base Guam (DPRI-Guam). Funding will also be used to procure one type 6 brush truck for the P-715 training ranges for future MCBG.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - $8.238M - Funds the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $22.460M
Funding in this budget line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
The FY 2021 funding request was reduced by $4.000M to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.
Commercial Passenger Vehicles - $1.796M: Funding will continue to recapitalize over aged buses, in order to transport passengers to meet mission of providing safe intra shuttle services for Marine Corps bases in Okinawa. Vans with the capability of transporting 7-8 passengers will also be procured to cover any gaps. Funding will continue to provide relief for over-aged units (sedans/law enforcement), in order to assist in keeping reliable vehicles on the roads for Marine Corps Installations Pacific (MCIPAC), since vehicles are not available for lease Outside Continental United States (OCONUS).
Decrease of $2.615M from FY20 to FY21 due to an anticipated reduction in commercial passenger vehicle requirements in accordance with the planned life-cycle replacement schedule.
Commercial Cargo Vehicles - $9.437M: Funds will recapitalize non-tactical vehicle portfolio of over-aged vehicles, in order to provide a safe way of transporting people and things. The necessity to move operational forces for home station training and deployments, require provisions of reliable non-tactical cargo vehicles to support this mission. On/off road vehicles will continue to be procured to meet California Air Resources Board (CARB) mandates. This will help avoid non-compliance fines of $10k per day, per vehicle. As such, vehicles included are low speed electric vehicles, various types of trailers (specialty, lowbed & flatbed) and trucks (fuel, stake bed, nurse unit, semi-tractor, sewer maintenance & pickup). In support of DPRI Guam, $1.826M of funding will procure commercial cargo vehicles for future Marine Corps Base Guam. Commercial Cargo Vehicles Defense Policy Review Initiative (DPRI) Guam -to procure (4) JP-5 fuel trucks required to support Marine Corps aviation operations on the North ramp of Naval Support Activity Andersen Air Force Base.
Decrease $1.007M from FY20 to FY21 due to an anticipated reduction in commercial cargo vehicle requirements in accordance with the planned life-cycle replacement schedule.
Emergency Response Vehicles - $4.818M: Funds will procure fire trucks (pumpers/aerial), rescue trucks, and ambulances for Marine Corps activities and commands. The funds will also procure brush trucks and water extenders to maintain ranges, training areas and facilities on Marine Corps Installations. In support of DPRI Guam, $1.481M of funding will procure emergency response vehicles for future Marine Corps Base Guam: a fire (engine) truck and a Response, Special (HAZMAT/Rescue) Vehicle.
Decrease of $1.002M from FY20 to FY21 due to an anticipated reduction in emergency response vehicles for DPRI Guam and additional support for installation.
Marine Security Guard (Vehicles) - $6.409M - Funds the procurement of commercial vehicles for the Marine Security Guard based on the requirements of the particular command and country embassies. Decrease of $1.829M from FY20 to FY21 due to a decrease in the procurement requirement of new Armored and Unarmored passenger vehicles.

proc:Name.footnote: Funding in this budget line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
Decrease of $2.615M from FY20 to FY21 due to an anticipated reduction in commercial passenger vehicle requirements in accordance with the planned life-cycle replacement schedule.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Motor Transport Modifications funds numerous essential modifications, initiatives, and new vehicle procurements that are required to address operational priorities, engineering change proposals, safety concerns, support equipment inefficiencies, tool malfunctions, product quality deficiencies, and other issues that affect vehicle reliability, safety, availability, and readiness. A proactive and focused approach ensures proper vehicle sustainment and life-cycle management and allows USMC to develop and implement improvements, as needed, to respond to the evolving requirements of the Marine Corps and sustain the fleet.
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) - The MTVR is the Marine Corps' medium ground lift capability supporting all elements of the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF). With its 70% off-road mission profile and the addition of a highly survivable armor package, the MTVR is heavily used in contingency operations as well as missions supporting humanitarian operations. It has a payload of 7.1 tons off-road and 15 tons on-road, a high-performance suspension, traction control, central tire inflation system, and automatic transmission, to transport personnel, ammunition, bulk cargo, and/or bulk fuel and water in a variety of environments. The MTVR family of vehicles includes a cargo variant (both standard and extended wheel base configurations), a dump truck, a wrecker, a tractor and a High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS) Rocket Resupply System Vehicle. This program funds numerous product improvements to the MTVR via engineering change proposals (ECPs), resulting from post-production requirements in force protection, communications, on-board situational awareness, and improved fuel efficiency required across the range of military operations, as well as addressing product quality deficiencies and other issues that impact vehicle safety, reliability, availability and readiness. The requirements capability change to improve fuel efficiency for the MTVR is part of the program's initiatives to lower fuel consumption and extend the vehicle's cruising range, while lowering operating costs over the life of the MTVR.
The Family of Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) Family of Vehicles (FoV): Provides Warfighters multi-mission platforms capable of mitigating Improvised Explosive Devices (IEDs), underbody mines, and small arms fire threats. Multiple MRAP vehicle Categories (CATs) have been procured, fielded, and are now being sustained, such as the MRAP-All Terrain Vehicle (M-ATV), with combat operations (OPS) in rural, mountainous, and urban terrain. Category I - Urban combat operations, ambulance. Category II - Multi-mission ops-convoy lead, troop transport, ambulance, utility vehicle. Category III - Mine/IED clearance ops, explosive ordnance disposal. Funding includes required Government Furnished Equipment (GFE)/subsystems and ECP/Capability Insertion in response to an Urgent Universal Needs Statements (UUNS) and Warfighter safety and survivability requirements.
The Family of P-19 Replacement (P-19R): Vehicles replace the obsolete A/S32P-19A Crash Fire Rescue fleet in support of expeditionary airfield operations and the supporting establishment. The vehicle is outfitted with advanced fire suppression equipment. It provides rescue and aircraft fire fighting capabilities to permanent and expeditionary airfields throughout the Marine Corps. The P-19R may also be employed to fight structural fires in support of base camps and as firefighting support to other elements of the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF), such as ammunition supply points, Petroleum, Oil, and Lubricant (POL) distribution points, or hazardous material storage facilities.
The Family of Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) Modification: The LVSR is the Marine Air-Ground Task Force Heavy Lift Capability system. The LVSR is built on the Oshkosh TAC-4 fully independent suspension, allowing it to traverse a variety of challenging terrain while carrying a payload of up to 22.5 tons. The LVSR accomplishes a variety of tactical logistics missions using armored and unarmored cargo, tractor and recovery variants. Funding provides for modifications required for the LVSR fleet of vehicles, such as updated brackets and cables for warfighter systems (e.g., jammers) as they are upgraded. These modifications also include critical safety upgrades and improved blast seats that reduce occupant injury during IED strikes. Finally, modifications include life cycle issues such as cab reconditioning, parts obsolescence and life cycle cost reductions.
Light Tactical Vehicle Modification (LTVM) - Light Tactical Family of Vehicles (FoV) - Modification program funds numerous essential modifications and initiatives that are required to address operational priorities, engineering change proposals, safety concerns, support equipment inefficiencies, tool malfunctions, product quality deficiencies, and other issues that affect vehicle reliability, availability and readiness. A proactive and focused approach ensures proper sustainment and life-cycle management of the light tactical vehicle fleet and allows the program office to develop and implement improvements, as needed, to respond to the evolving requirements of the Marine Corps.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $11.215M
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $7.147M; In FY19, MTVR funding provided for the three-tier integration effort that spanned across Marine Corps Expeditionary Forces (MEFs), Marine Augmentation Program-Kuwait (MAP-K) and the Marine Forces-Reserve (MFR), for procuring and installing several required modifications. These modification upgrades improved the ability of the Marine to "shoot, move, and communicate" by prioritizing the installation of the C4I (command, control, communications, computers, and intelligence) systems, upgrading the weapons mount kit, as well as the front and rear cab axle mounts that are required due to the addition of heavy armor. Additionally, installation of the Turret Gunner Restraint System (TGRS) provides rollover protection for the Marine in the turret using a full-body, six-point harness; previously there was no restraint system in the turret.
The Family of Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) Modification: $2.520M; $2.305M Active; $.215M Reserve. Provided for modifications required for the LVSR fleet of vehicles, such as updated brackets and cables for warfighter systems such jammer upgrades. These modifications also included critical safety upgrades, which included the brake corrosion modification, which prevents brake failure due to submersion in water during fording, boat and bridge operations, and improved blast seats, that reduce occupant injury during IED strikes. Finally, modifications included life cycle issues such as cab reconditioning, parts obsolescence and life cycle cost reductions.
The Family of P-19 Replacement: $1.470M; $1.448M Active; $.022M Reserves. Funding provided initial support, training, Spares and FSRs for Reserves' vehicles.
The Family of Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) Family of vehicles (FoV): $.076M Funded ECP upgrades/modifications for the enduring MRAP vehicle requirement. ECP upgrades and modifications maintain vehicle relevancy in meeting force protection threats, such as blast, rollover or water submersion events, and responding to operational needs.
FY 2020: $19.234M
Light Tactical Vehicle Modification (LTVM) $.542M; Funding provides for limited quality deficiency resolutions and safety and reliability modifications/ECPs and technical manual updates. The program continues to address deficiencies of HMMWV vehicles due to up armoring and age degradation of the fleet.
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $14.501M; In FY20, MTVR's continue to have a three-tier integration effort to meet approved operational requirements that span across Marine Corps Expeditionary Forces (MEFs), Marine Augmentation Program-Kuwait (MAP-K) and the Marine Forces-Reserve (MFR), for procuring and installing several types of modification kits. These modification upgrades improve the ability of the crew to "shoot, move, and communicate" by prioritizing the installation of the C4I (command, control, communications, computers, and intelligence) systems, upgrading the weapons mount kit to enable the employment of heavy machine guns, as well as the front and rear cab axle mounts that are required due to the addition of heavy armor. C4I kits enable the platform to accept Radios, Intercoms, Jammers and Blue Force Situational Awareness capabilities. Additionally, installation of the Turret Gunner Restraint System (TGRS) provides rollover protection for the Marine in the turret using a full-body, six-point harness.
The Family of Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) $.742M. Procures ECP upgrades/modifications for the enduring MRAP vehicle requirement. Continues ECP upgrades and Modifications to maintain relevancy in meeting force protection threats, such as blast, rollover or water submersion events, and responding to operational needs.
The Family of P-19 Replacement (P-19R) $.362M; $.179M Active; $.183M Reserve. Supports the newly fielded vehicles with DMSMS issues and storage maintenance of electronic configuration data.
The Family of Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) $3.087M; $2.855M Active; $.232M Reserve. Procures modified cabs, which prevents dead lining the vehicle due to corrosion and modified seats to sustain the current level of performance of LVSR during IED strikes.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $10.739M
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $7.966M; In FY21, MTVR's will continue to have a three-tier integration effort to meet approved operational requirements that span across Marine Corps Expeditionary Forces (MEFs), for procuring and installing several types of modification kits. These modification upgrades improve the ability of the crew to "shoot, move, and communicate" by prioritizing the installation of the C4I (command, control, communications, computers, and intelligence) systems, upgrading the weapons mount kit to enable the employment of heavy machine guns, as well as the front and rear cab axle mounts that are required due to the addition of heavy armor. C4I kits enable the platform to accept Radios, Intercoms, Jammers and Blue Force Situational Awareness capabilities. Additionally, installation of the Turret Gunner Restraint System (TGRS) provides rollover protection for the Marine in the turret using a full-body, six-point harness. Installation costs account for over half the total cost of each ECP. These ECP's are part of a continual effort to upgrade the MTVR as the item exit date has been extended from 2024 to 2042. Fuel Efficient upgrades will continue to be installed on the entire MTVR fleet of vehicles. FE upgrades will provide reduced fuel consumption, which will lead to significant cost savings in the out years. Higher fuel economy will improve our warfighter's combat effectiveness by reducing the logistical footprint, increasing expeditionary capability and extending the operational range of fuel-powered equipment. The decrease of $6.535M from FY20 to FY21 is due to reduced number of MTVR Safety ECPs procured and installed in FY21; Fleet Marine Forces and support establishment will continue to rotate vehicles in for ECP installs thru the FYDP.
The Family of Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) $1.096M. Will continue to procure ECP upgrades/modifications for the enduring MRAP vehicle requirement. Continues ECP upgrades and modifications to maintain relevancy in meeting force protection threats, such as blast, rollover or water submersion events, and responding to operational needs. The increase of $.354M from FY20 to FY21 is the result of ECP upgrade support.
The Family of P-19 Replacement (P-19R) $.367M; $.181M Active; $0.186M Reserve. Will continue to support the newly fielded vehicles with DMSMS issues such as storage maintenance of electronic configuration data. The increase of $.005M from FY20 to FY21 is the result of ECPs to the new vehicle.
The Family of Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) $.814M; $.579M Active; $.235M Reserve. Will continue to procure modified cabs, which prevents dead-lining the vehicle due to corrosion and modified seats to sustain the current level of performance of LVSR during IED strikes. The net decrease of $2.276M from FY20 to FY21 is due to reduced rate of ECP procurement.
Light Tactical Vehicle Modification (LTVM) $.496M; Funding will provide for limited quality deficiency resolutions, safety initiatives, and environmental/state transportation mandated vehicle changes. Provides support for ECP integration to include changes such as addressing deficiencies of HMMWV vehicles due to up armoring and age degradation of the fleet, energy storage enhancements and other critical changes required to ensure the vehicles are a viable transportation capability for the Marine Corps Operating Forces. Technical manual updates will occur to capture the Engineering Changes to the vehicles. Funding decrease from FY20 to FY21 of $.046M is due to reduced amount of safety and reliability modifications/ECPs.
OCO: FY 2019 OCO: $44.440M
Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Modification: $21.731M; OCO funded procurement and installation of various ECP kits required for the MTVRs located in the Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU) Augmentation Program-Kuwait (MAP-K), and other Marine units. The ECP Kits included the C4ISR kits which provide cabling and bracketry for the Joint Battle Command Platform (JBC-P) and Counter IED Systems (CVRJ); Rear Cab Mounts, Front Cab Mounts, the Automatic Fire Extinguishing System (AFES) and the Emergency Egress Window (EEW). These kits increase the overall survivability, safety and the Command, Control, Communication, Computers, Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) capabilities of the MTVR Armored Family of Vehicles.
The Family of Logistics Vehicle System Replacement: (LVSR): $.439M OCO. Funded procurement and installation of Engineering Change Proposals (ECP), such as brake safety, JBC-P and counter IED Systems, CVRJs needed for the LVSRs located in the MAP-K. These kits increase force protection of all LVSR variants by ensuring the vehicles have updated ECPs to increase braking capability, navigation and counter IED threats.
The Family of Mine Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) Family of Vehicles (FoV): $22.270M OCO. Funded the installation of Egress kits procured in response to UUNS 08275UC and 10215UC; MARCENT Enduring requirements. The Egress kit increases force protection on all Cougar CAT I and CAT II variants (quantity of 197) by ensuring that vehicle occupants can safely exit the vehicle after blast, rollover or water submersion events.
FY 2021 OCO Appropriation Request: $16.183M
The Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) requires $15.6M of FY21 OCO to complete the ongoing integration effort to install critical combat-enabling and force protection modifications on 130 deployed vehicles at unit cost of $0.120M per vehicle. Modifications include the installation of brackets to convert from the Crew Vehicle Receiver/Jammer (CVRJ-2) to the MODi Vehicle Power Amplifier (MVPA-2), the Turret Gunner Restraint System, the Automatic Fire Extinguisher System (AFES), and the TOCNET communications suite. The MVPA-2 enables the vehicle to block frequencies of IEDs; the Turret Gunner Restraint System installs a six point harness for the gunner in the turret (currently no restraint system in place); the AFES ensures Marines do not incur life threatening burns; and the TOCNET kit enables the driver, turret gunner, and troops in troop carrier to have sufficient communications instead of the current method of voice commands, which is ineffective in combat operations. Due to heavy use in severe conditions, many of the vehicles scheduled for installation needed repairs or were missing prior modifications (such as unique brackets), and were returned to service without the most recent modifications. This funding ensures both the (86) vehicles at the Marine Expeditionary Unit Augmentation Program Kuwait (MAP-K) and the (44) vehicles at Special Purpose Marine Air-Ground Task Force (SPMAGTF) are the highest configuration and have received all combat-enabling modifications. These vehicles support Freedom's Sentinel Afghanistan. Without adequate funding to install the combat-enabling modifications, the vehicles operating in theater will remain ill-equipped for Fleet Marine Force missions.
The Family of Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR) requires $.583M of FY21 OCO to modify and install brackets to convert from Crew Vehicle Receiver/Jammer (CVRJ-2) to the MODi Vehicle Power Amplifier (MVPA-2). This modification includes development of a production level technical data package (TDP), development of modification instructions, production verification and engineering support for installation. Installation of the MVPA-2 will allow for the LVSR to continue to have the ability to counter IED threats.

proc:Name.footnote: FY20 to FY21 decrease of $3.449M is due to reduced number of MTVR Safety ECPs procured and installed in FY21. Operating forces and support establishment will continue to rotate vehicles in for ECP installs thru the FYDP.

FY20 to FY21 decrease of $3.322M is due to reduced number of MTVR ECPs procured and installed in FY21. Operating forces and support establishment will continue to rotate vehicles in for ECP installs thru the FYDP. MTVR increase of $15.6M OCO from FY20 to FY21 is to complete the ongoing integration effort to install critical combat-enabling and force protection modifications on 130 deployed vehicles at unit cost of $0.120M per vehicle.

Increase from FY20 to FY21 of $0.118M is for additional scheduled installations of the FE software kits on various tactical vehicles in the fleet during FY21; initial technical support for those SW kits included in cost.
FY20 to FY21 increase of $0.118M is due to additional support to process/analyze MTVR FE data as upgrades to fleet are completed.

LVSR increase of $0.583 OCO from FY20 to FY21 is to modify and install brackets to convert from Crew Vehicle Receiver/Jammer (CVRJ-2) to the MODi Vehicle Power Amplifier (MVPA-2). This modification includes development of a production level technical data package (TDP), development of modification instructions, production verification and engineering support for installation.

proc:Item.proc:Name: 2.1) LVSR Systems Integrations Equip & Installs (GFE, TOCNET, etc)

proc:Name.footnote: The decrease of $2.276M from FY20 to FY21 is due to reduced rate of procurement of ECPs, such as the brake ECP.
FY20 - FY21 increase of $0.354M is the result of support of ECP safety upgrades.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Joint Light Tactical Vehicle (JLTV) Family of Vehicles (FoV) is a joint U.S. Army and U.S. Marine Corps program, with the Army as lead service. JLTV is a FoV capable of performing multiple mission roles that provide protected, sustained, networked mobility for personnel and payloads across the full Range of Military Operations (ROMO). JLTV features include increased protection and performance over the current fleet; minimizing ownership costs by maximizing commonality, fuel efficiency, reliability, and maintaining effective competition throughout the life cycle. Commonality of components, maintenance procedures, training, etc., among vehicles are inherent in FoV solutions across mission variants to minimize total ownership cost. Unique service requirements have been minimized.
The approved Full Rate Production (FRP) joint cost position incorporates validated requirements identified during Multi-Service Operational Test and Evaluation (MOT&E) as well as other mission critical requirements identified by the warfighter and supported in the FY21 budget request. JLTV achieved a successful FRP decision in June 2019.
The FRP decision documented the requirement for improved situational awareness and external noise reduction. These requirements were identified during MOT&E and documented in the DOT&E report. The program will procure and install new rear doors with larger windows, an external forward facing camera, and mufflers. Also, the Marine Corps will procure Troop Seats to provide Fleet Marine Forces with the ability to move troops in utility vehicles when tactical conditions allow unprotected troop transport. This requirement was codified in a Capability Requirement Change (CRC) letter for the JLTV program.
A LRIP fixed price contract was awarded to Oshkosh Defense LLC on 25 August 2015. This contract consists of a three year LRIP period with options for five additional years of FRP deliveries. JPO JLTV procured the Technical Data Package (TDP) with appropriate data rights to allow for possible future competition for production vehicles and spares. Current contract options may be exercised through 30 November 2023 assuming contractual quantity headspace is still available. Current funding indicates headspace quantity of 16,901 may be achieved in FY 2021, with competitive follow on contract award anticipated in FY 2022.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $572.774M Procured 1,642 LRIP vehicles, kit procurement, System Technical Support, Engineering Change Orders, Vehicle Retrofits, Production Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM), Fielding support, Interim Contractor Support and Program Management support.
The kits supported the baseline vehicle by providing the warfighter the ability to augment the vehicle's configuration to meet required vehicle capabilities such as fording, survivability, hot and cold weather operations, communications/C4I, combat bumpers, winches, and troop seats, etc, in order to respond to environmental conditions or threat situations.
FY 2020: $555.648M Includes the procurement of 1,264 vehicles and kit procurement, Total Package Fielding (TPF) to include Support Equipment, Initial Spares, First Destination Transportation and vehicle storage, Performance Verification Testing (PVT), System Technical Support (STS), Production Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM), Engineering Change Orders (ECO)s and Retrofits and Interim Contractor Support (ICS).
Fielding cost increased from the FY20 request due to the addition of support equipment and special tool kits to provide the units with the additional tools necessary to maintain the vehicles. Fielding includes increased support for harvesting existing communications, C4I, and Gun Protection Kits from HMMWVs to JLTVs. Also the Marine Corps requirement for B-Kit armor at 100% of vehicles requires retrofit of a number of procured vehicles leading to increased support for installation during the fielding process
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $381.675M Pojects will include the procurement of 752 vehicles; various kits associated with mission and vehicle variant; fielding to include Total Package Fielding (TPF) which consists of travel and labor for multiple fielding teams to conduct concurrent fielding events at USMC bases and stations in Okinawa, Hawaii, North Carolina, and California, Support Equipment, Initial Spares, First Destination Transportation (FDT) and vehicle storage; Performance Verification Testing (PVT); System Technical Support (STS); Contractor Systems Engineering Program Management (SEPM); Engineering Change Orders (ECO)s and Retrofits necessary to incorporate changes identified during manufacture on the production line and through operational assessments; and Interim Contractor Support (ICS) which provides vendor support for maintenance and repair of JLTVs between initial fielding and the transition of sustainment to an organic capability; procure 74 JLTV companion trailers and associated kits, Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP) and First Destination Transportation.
Kits will consist of mission essential equipment specific to each vehicle and variant and provide the warfighter the ability to augment the vehicle's configuration to meet required vehicle capabilities such as fording, survivability, hot and cold weather operations, communications/C4I winches, etc, in order to respond to environmental conditions or threat situations. Kit procurement includes up to 75 individual kits options for each vehicle.
Funding in this line has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.

proc:Name.footnote: The JLTV LRIP and FRP production contract was competitively awarded to Oshkosh Defense in 2015. The contract between the Government and Oshkosh includes priced option years through the end of the first contract period (Base plus 8 options). These contracted prices are not negotiable on a year to year basis. Vehicle and kit costs are based on the firm fixed price contract cost, quantity ranges, and option year. These ranges are dependent on total quantities procured across all Services based on both platform and variant. The unit costs are based on contract pricing of the manufacturers projected overhead and commodities forecast (i.e. raw materials, petroleum, and forward pricing rate agreements with labor unions) and are reflected in the contract. The Government agreed to these fixed and non-negotiable prices at the time of the competitively awarded JLTV production contract. The production rates provided in this exhibit are annual estimates. Oshkosh's main production line is not wholly JLTV and has been set up to run multiple other Military Tactical and Commercial Business vehicles on the same line during the same shift. As such they do not have a unique JLTV 1-8-5. The FY 2020 total vehicle quantity cost decreased from the FY20 request due to the documented requirement for improved situational awareness (new rear doors with larger windows and an external forward facing camera) and external noise reduction (addition of muffler). These requirements were identified during MOT&E and documented in the DOT&E report. The program will also procure Troops seats and mission critical special tools. Funding decrease from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $126.136M is due to the reduction of 512 vehicles in FY21 based on available budget. The unit cost increases from FY 2020 to FY 2021 based on the fixed and non-negotiable prices on the JLTV production contract. Vehicle variant mix and final quantities of all services will affect the unit cost based on range pricing; as well as approved changes to the base vehicle.
MS C and contract award occured on 25 August 2015. Production rates for the JLTV variants are shown as annual rates.

proc:FiscalYear.footnote: Due to quantity and budget limitation of the Continuing Resolution, JLTV quantities were procured in mulitple contract awards.. 106 vehicles were procured in Dec 2016 and 106 vehicles were procured in Jul 2017.

Due to quantity and budget limitation of the Continuing Resolution, JLTV quantities were procured in mulitple contract awards.. 192 vehicles were procured in Dec 2017. The balance of 335 vehicles procured in June 2018.

Due to quantity and budget limitation of the Continuing Resolution, JLTV quantities were procured in mulitple contract awards.. 53 vehicles were procured in Dec 2019. The remaining will be procured in Feb 2020 (1151) and in June 2020 (60).

proc:Name.footnote: Engineering Change Orders (ECOs) and retrofit of design changes to vehicles produced and delivered are based on results from observations during manufacture on the production line and through operational assessments, such as MOT&E and others. The funding increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $1.509M is to incorporate vehicle changes identified during manufacture on the production line and through operational assessments.

Kits consist of mission essential equipment specific to each vehicle and variant and are necessary for the various operational requirements. Procurement includes up to 75 individual kit options for each individual vehicle. Kits may include, but are not limited to, armor kits required for force protection and survivability, tactical communications kits, which provide net-ready capabilities, and operational kits that complement base vehicle functionality to achieve requirements for tactical employment and mobility. Final kit procurement density is subject to change and based on operational and mission profile at time of award. A vehicle to kit ratio will not accurately capture kit cost as they are dependent on varying factors and are tied to unit and operational requirement. The FY 2020 kit cost increased from the FY20 request due to the requirement to procure Troop Seats to provide Fleet Marine Forces with the ability to move troops in utility vehicles when tactical conditions allow unprotected troop transport. Funding decrease from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $39.303M is due to the vehicle quantity reduction in FY21 and the fielding requirements of each individual unit.

JLTV companion trailer is purpose built to comply with JLTV requirements for mobility and payload. Infantry battalion expeditionary mobility will be improved by pairing JLTV with its companion trailer, enabling the unit to keep pace with vehicle formations. The increase of $4.121M in FY21 procures 74 trailers and associated kits, Initial Issue Provisioning (IIP) and First Destination Transportation.

ICS provides vendor support for maintenance and repair of JLTVs between initial fielding in FY19 and the transition of sustainment to an organic capability planned to begin in FY22. ICS continues in support of Operator New Equipment Training (OPNET) into FY23. Funding increase from FY20 to FY21 of $1.133M is due to the increase of Interim Contract Support (ICS) to support the cumulatively fielded JLTV vehicles.

Program management includes the Government Systems Integration Laboratory operations in support of fielding requirements and the addition of Liaison Officers on-site at each MEF providing support for MEF mission readiness, and the resolution of maintenance related issues. The Liaison Officers coordinate between OPFORs, the JLTV program office, logistics managers and the vehicle manufacturer. There is a minimal funding increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $.064M due to increased program management and travel required to support ongoing fielding.

Funding increase for Contractor SEPM costs from FY 2020 and FY 2021 of $2.103M is the result of increases in the transition of HMMWV based capabilities to JLTV. This cost element provides for additional Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) engineering to conduct the necessary analysis to ensure required existing capabilities that reside on the operational HMMWV fleet are transitioned to the JLTV platform.

Production Verification Testing (PVT) which is limited reliability and performance testing conducted yearly to verify consistent design and manufacturing; testing related to ECP change to evaluate the successful integration on the vehicle and provide data for decision makers; Continued Command, Control, Communications, Computers, Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) testing necessary for the integration of various weapons platforms. Funding increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $.908M is for testing to validate vehicle performance for weapons platforms planned for integration in the FY21 timeframe.

Total Package Fielding (TPF) of JLTVs to Fleet Marine Forces includes the First Destination Transportation (FDT) for vehicles and kits, and all ancillary equipment required to conduct initial fielding and training to receiving units. Costs also include travel and labor for 3 fielding teams to conduct concurrent fielding events at multiple USMC bases and stations around the globe. The FY20 fielding cost increased $22.047M from the FY20 request to the FY21 request is due to the increase of manpower and resources required to stand up fielding sites at I MEF and II MEF. Fielding includes support for harvesting existing communications, C4I, and Gun Protection Kits from HMMWVs to JLTVs. Also the Marine Corps requirement for B-Kit armor to 100% of vehicles requires increased support for installation during the fielding process. Funding decrease from FY 2020 to FY 2021 of $18.403M is due to the reduction in the support equipment and special tools. The program applies a horizontal fielding strategy that requires common support equipment and tools upon receipt of vehicles. Based on the simultaneous fielding schedule, in FY21 the need for special tools and support equipment declines.

proc:CostElement.proc:Name: 3.8) Training Aids, Devices, Simulators and Simulations (TADSS)

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Family of Trailers and Ancillary Equipment (FT&AE) encompasses equipment upgrades and changes made to fielded trailers.
Family of Tactical Trailers primarily provides for the procurement and support of trailers in the medium and heavy fleet to enhance Marine Corps tactical vehicle mobility capability. This program primarily supports various medium and heavy trailers as well as light, to include the M1076 PLS (Palletized Load System) Trailer, the MK1077 Flatrack for the PLS Trailer and Logistics Vehicle System Replacement (LVSR); MK593 Medium Tactical Vehicle Replacement (MTVR) Trailer; M870 40/50 Ton Low Bed, MK970 Tactical Refueler, M149A2 400 Gallon Water Tank Trailer, MK38 High Mobility Artillery Rocket System (HIMARS) Re-Supply Trailer, MK970 5,000 Gallon Semitrailer, and the Flatrack Refueler Capability (FRC).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $2.493M ($1.825 Active; $0.668M Reserve)
Funds in the amount of $2.493M supported procurement and installation of safety and performance Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) to modify the Medium and Heavy Tactical Trailer fleet of vehicles, including the Palletized Load System Trailer (PLST), M870 (40 & 50 ton trailers), MK1077 (Flatrack), MK970, MTVR MK593 Trailer and Flatrack Refueling Capability (FRC) to enable the operating forces to tow required bulk and liquid cargo within the mission profile of the MTVR and LVSR prime movers.
FY 2020: $2.693M ($2.010M Active; $0.683M Reserve)
Funds in the amount of $2.693M supports procurement and installation of safety and performance Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) to modify the Medium and Heavy Tactical Trailer Fleets, including the Palletized Load System Trailer (PLST), M870 (40 & 50 ton trailers), MK1077 (Flatrack), MK970, MTVR MK593 Trailer and Flatrack Refueling Capability (FRC). Many of these trailer systems were procured prior to or separate of the MTVR and LVSR, do not match the off-road capabilities of those prime movers, but can be improved with modification. Funding also supports procuring various ECPs, such as those addressing corrosion and safety changes by incorporating drain holes, corrosion resistant materials, and improved safety chains.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $2.963M ($2.265M Active; $0.698M Reserve)
Funds in the amount of $2.963M will support procurement and installation of safety and performance Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) to modify the Medium and Heavy Tactical Trailer Fleets, including the Palletized Load System Trailer (PLST), M870 (40 & 50 ton trailers), MK1077 (Flatrack), MK970, MTVR MK593 Trailer and Flatrack Refueling Capability (FRC). Many of these trailer systems were procured prior to or separate of the MTVR and LVSR, do not match the off-road capabilities of those prime movers, but can be improved with modification. Funding will also support procuring various ECPs, such as those addressing corrosion and safety changes by incorporating drain holes, corrosion resistant materials, and improved safety chains. Modifications can span multiple years to outfit a fleet, such as the ECP for the M870, which began in FY19 and will take five (5) years to complete upgrades to all M870 trailers.
The increase in funding of $0.270M from FY 2020 to FY 2021 reflects a reprioritization by the Marine Corps towards these modification efforts, particularly for an ECP to address ground clearance issues for the M870 Heavy Lift trailer. The ECPs will provide the M870 with improved off-road mobility and increased reliability.

proc:Name.footnote: FY20 to FY21 increase of $0.435M will fund additional ECP's, such as those for resolving trailer ground clearance deficiencies for M870. Based on available funding, the M870 ground clearance ECP is projected to be a 5 year procurement beginning in 4th Quarter FY19.
FY20 to FY21 decrease of $0.180M is due to funds redirected to higher Service priorities.
FY20 to FY21 increase of $0.015M will fund additional ECP's, such as those for resolving trailer ground clearance deficiencies for the M870.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description: Funding is for unfunded priority requirement as part of the Hurricane Florence and Michael recovery efforts for trailers which includes temporary facilities such as interim relocatable trailers and temporary shelters.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification: OCO: FY 2020 Funding in the amount of $14.000M will replace sprung shelters destroyed at Marine Corps Logistics Base, Albany, GA as part of the disaster recovery efforts for Hurricanes Michael and Florence. Processing and Storing Military Equipment in a climate controlled environment has proven to be cost effective in maintaining equipment for long term storage. This interim relocatable facility will be used as a storage bridge solution for 5-7 years until MILCON permanent facilities are procured and constructed.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Environmental Control Equipment: The Family of Environmental Control Equipment (ECE) consists of Environmental Control Units (ECU), Field Refrigeration Systems (FRS), and Cooling and Refrigeration Expeditionary Tool Kits (CREK). These systems provide required heating, cooling, storage, and servicing for systems throughout the Marine Corps. Current efforts seek to replace all legacy ECE with systems of higher reliability and higher efficiency using Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) approved refrigerants, which offer more energy efficiency, enhanced mobility, are easier to repair, and quieter than their predecessors. With environmental control systems consuming 50-70% of tactical electric power in theater, these savings will be a significant contribution to reducing the USMC fuel demand, and lightening the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF). The Warfighter benefit includes a decreased logistics footprint, less reliance on petroleum-derived fuels, increased local energy security, and reduced tanker losses (fewer on the road). The operational imperative to reduce fuel usage will consequently reduce refueling operations and exposing Marines to hazardous fuel convoy operations. Efforts include the procurement of the following principal end items and ancillary equipment: (1) Additional 60,000 BTU/hr ECUs to sustain Authorized Acquisition Objective (AAO) due to the disposition of ECU variants utilizing R-22 refrigerant, which has been banned by the EPA. (2) Small Field Refrigeration Systems (SFRS) replacement. This effort seeks to replace legacy SFRSs to comply with restricting EPA regulations while increasing efficiency, thus reducing overall power requirements/demands.
Inflatable Maritime Structures: A fuel bladder designed for autonomous movement under the water's surface that will increase operational persistence and flexibility for distributed operations in contested and uncertain environments, while increasing sustainability, survivability, and maneuverability.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $0.595M (ACTIVE: $0.595M/RESERVE: $0.000M) Funds purchased 5-Ton 60,000 BTU/hr ECUs as a result of the disposition of ECU variants utilizing R-22 refrigerant which is banned by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
FY 2020: $0.495M (ACTIVE: $0.377M/RESERVE: $0.118M) Funds purchase 60,000 BTU/hr ECUs due to an increase in the Authorized Acquisition Objective (AAO). The AAO increase is a result of the disposition of ECU variants utilizing R-22 refrigerant which is banned by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $0.385M (ACTIVE: $0.274M/RESERVE: $0.111M) Funds will continue purchasing 5-Ton 60,000 BTU/hr ECUs as a result of the disposition of ECU variants utilizing R-22 refrigerant which is banned by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Funding decreased from FY20 to FY21 by $0.110M due to this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
OCO: FY 2019 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: N/A FY 2020 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: N/A FY 2021 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: N/A

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Family of Expeditionary Fuel Systems (FEFS) is a family of systems line that contains highly versatile fuel systems designed to receive, test, store, transfer and dispense fuel in support of Marine Air Ground Tactical Force (MAGTF) operations. The family contains individual Table of Allowance Material Control Numbers which support MAGTF operations by providing all aspects of land-based fuel support to include analysis, receipt, storage, transfer and dispensing including all various components.
The future operating environment requires the ability to provide bulk fuel systems that are capable of rapid emplacement and displacement with the right amount of storage capacity and flow rate. The Helicopter Expedient Refueling System (HERS) legacy systems have insufficient capacity, mobility and dispensing rates and therefore do not support Marine Corps Operating Concept (MOC), Littoral Operations in Contested Environments (LOCE), and Expeditionary Advance Base Operations (EABO). The Tactical Air Ground Refueling System (TAGRS) will be a replacement of the HERS. The Expeditionary Mobile Fuel Additive Capability (EMFAC) provides the capability to inject additives for accommodating foraged fuel. The Petroleum Expeditionary Analysis Kit (PEAK) provides testing capability of local fuel sources. The Portable Fuel Analyzer (PFA) provides the capability for any MOS, particularly Infantry or SOF, to test captured fuel on the forward edge of the battlefield which can then be used to extend convoys and possibly refuel aircraft.
This line also supports the Tactical Airfield Fuel Distribution System (TAFDS), Amphibious Assault Fuel System (AAFS), SIXCON Fuel Storage and Pump Module, Fire Suppression System (FSS), Expedient Refueling System (ERS), Ground Refueling System (GERS) (small and medium), 600 Gallons Per Minute (GPM) Fuel Pump Assembly, 150 GPM Fuel Pump Assembly, Hose Reel System - Fuel (HRS-F), Berm Liners, Tanks/Pods (500 Gallon to 50K), Petroleum Quality Analysis System-Enhanced as well as various elastomeric fuel systems components and equipment. Procurement supports centrally managed items with lifecycles, preplanned product improvements, and obsolescence mitigation via newer components and subsystems supported by industry. Procurement also supports repacking current systems into smaller modular packages for scalability and mission tailoring which may require additional subsystems for certain packages to be complete as new TAMCNs and tables of allowances are authorized.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $0.054M (Reserve: $0.054M) Family of Expeditionary Fuel Systems funds purchased various centrally managed Fuel Components (Fuel Pods and 3K/20K/50K), Digital Free Water Detectors (DFWD) (replacing legacy Combined Contaminated Fuel Detector (CCFDs)), Solar Pulse Chargers, and a critical 600 GPM Engineering Change Proposal (ECP).
FY 2020: $0.052M (Active: $0.052M) Family of Expeditionary Fuel Systems funds purchase various Collapsible Fabric Tanks.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $0.501M (Active: $0.501M) The increase from FY20 to FY21 of $0.449M will procure various Family of Expeditionary Fuel Systems and Equipment such as Expeditionary Fuel Systems (Small/Medium/Large), Tactical Air Ground Refueling System (TAGRS), Petroleum Expeditionary Analysis Kit (PEAK), Expeditionary Mobile Fuel Additization Capability (EMFAC) and Portable Fuel Analyzer (PFA).

proc:Name.footnote: FY2021 budget request will procure various Family of Expeditionary Fuel Systems and Equipment such as Expeditionary Fuel Systems (Small/Medium/Large), Tactical Air Ground Refueling System (TAGRS), Petroleum Expeditionary Analysis Kit (PEAK), Expeditionary Mobile Fuel Additization Capability (EMFAC) and Portable Fuel Analyzer (PFA).

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
FAMILY OF MOBILE POWER EQUIPMENT - The Family of Mobile Electric Power Equipment consists of command and control systems for power management and distribution (intelligent power management), tactical generators ranging from 2 to 100 kilowatts, power distribution systems, energy storage systems, load banks, floodlights, cabling, and electrician tool kits. This equipment is procured and fielded to manage and provide electricity on the battlefield. Systems may be mounted on prime movers, skids or trailers. Systems support maneuver, combat support, and combat service support units requiring tactical power to operate weapons systems, Command, Control, Communications, Computers and Intelligence (C4I) systems, medical and messing facilities, environmental control equipment, and water purification systems. With over 10,000 generators and using diesel engines in the Operating Forces, improving their fuel efficiency and reliability will be a significant contribution to reducing the USMC fuel demand, and lightening the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF). The Warfighter benefit includes a decreased logistics footprint, less reliance on petroleum derived fuels, increased local energy security, and reduced tanker losses (fewer on the road). The operational imperative to reduce fuel usage will consequently reduce refueling operations and exposing Marines to hazardous fuel convoy operations.
Efforts encompass procurements of the following principal end items and ancillary equipment: Intelligent Power Management Systems (IPMS) provide a robust, modular, and scalable solution to interconnect, control, store and distribute power from various sources. As a result, the power requirements will be met in a more efficient manner by matching power production to load demand, reducing spinning reserve, extending maintenance cycle times, and reducing fuel consumption. The IPMS will consist of a micro-gridding capability which will consist of the Advance Digital Control System, which is a product improvement for the Advance Medium Mobile Power Source generators, an Intelligent Power Distribution (IPD) system, an Energy Storage Unit (ESU), a Metering and Monitoring capability, and it will eventually integrate renewables.
FAMILY OF ADVANCED POWER SOURCES (APS) - This family consists of multiple suites of devices, grouped into sub-families, that are used to provide highly expeditionary power (hand-carried or vehicle mounted) to operate and power communications equipment, computers and peripheral equipment in place of disposable batteries, and for scenarios where fuel powered generators are too large, too heavy, unsuitable for use, or provide undue logistics burden due to refueling needs
Efforts encompass procurements of the following principal end items and ancillary equipment: Devices encompass renewable and hybrid energy based systems, and includes the man-portable Ground Renewable Expeditionary Energy Network System (GREENS) that supports a company level operations center and Forward Operating Base, the man-packable Solar Portable Alternative Communications Energy Systems (SPACES) that supports Combat Outposts and Observation Points, and the Mobile Electric Hybrid Power Source (MEHPS) that provides up to 10kW to power mission command and control, information networks, communications, environmental control, life support, sustainment and illumination at the battalion level. All of these exploit the use of solar energy and power management technologies to recharge batteries and directly power electronic equipment without a need, or with a reduced need for re-fueling generators.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $14.683M (Active: $14.683M/Reserve: $0.000M)
MOBILE POWER EQUIPMENT $8.122M (ACTIVE: $8.122M/RESERVE: $0.000M) Funded the procurement of IPMS subsystems Advanced Medium Mobile Power Source (AMMPS) Advanced AMMPS Digital Control System (ADCS), AMMPS generators, and various logistics support. Legacy equipment is fueled by fossil fuels. Intelligent Power Management System and micro-gridding serve to decrease the size of diesel-fueled generators required by networking equipment. The "brains" of the system, the controller (Advanced Digital Control System), tells the system when to run off the generator, and when to run off energy storage systems (batteries). The phases of this IPMS system will first acquire IPD, and in a later phase, Energy Storage Units (batteries) that will reduce reliance on fossil fuel, and reduce the volume and frequency of resupply missions required to provide consumable items for corrective or preventive maintenance activities, reducing logistics footprint and lightening the load. The Approved Acquisition Objective (AAO) for Micro-grid Advanced Digital Control System (MADCS), formerly titled AMMPS DCS Kits in the FY 2019 request, increased from 179 to 328 units. This increase is largely being supported by the budget originally identified for Large Advanced Mobile Power System (LAMPS) Program which cancelled in FY18, and IPMS Energy Storage Unit (ESU), formerly titled Micro-grid Storage/IPM in the FY 2019 request, which experienced programmatic adjustments also in FY 2018.
ADVANCED POWER SOURCES $6.561M (Active: $6.561M/Reserve: $0.000M) Continues to fund the procurement and fielding of Advanced Battery Chargers.
FY 2020: $22.441M (Active: $20.573M/Reserve: $1.868M)
MOBILE POWER EQUIPMENT $12.058M (Active: $12.058M/Reserve: $0.000M) Funds the procurement of (AMMPS, Advanced Digital Control System (ADCS), Advance Medium Mobile Power System (AMMPS) generators, and logistics support.
ADVANCED POWER SOURCES $10.383M (Active: $8.515M/Reserve: $1.868M) Continues to fund the procurement and fielding of Advanced Battery Charger as well as awarding the MEHPS production contract.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $23.430M (Active: $21.521M/Reserve: $1.909M)
MOBILE POWER EQUIPMENT $7.670M (Active: $7.670M/Reserve: $0.000M) Funds will continue the procurement of the Intelligent Power Management System (IPMS) Intelligent Power Distribution (IPD) Panels. Funding decreased from FY20 to FY21 by $4.388M due to non-recurring costs absorbed in FY20 with the full rate production of IPDs.
Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
ADVANCED POWER SOURCES $15.760M (Active: $13.851M/Reserve: $1.909M) Continues to fund the procurement and fielding of MEHPS. The increase in Advanced Power Sources funding of $5.377M from FY20 to FY21 is due to the production and fielding of MEHPS.
OCO: FY 2019 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: N/A FY 2020 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: N/A FY 2021 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request: N/A
