proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Family of Construction Equipment (FCE) provides for the replacement and Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) of Marine Corps construction equipment. Funding supports equipment to conduct engineer missions such as constructing counter-mobility obstacles, building pioneer roads, establishing survivability positions, development of expeditionary airfields and general engineering support to forward operating bases and lodgment areas. Construction Equipment includes: Airfield Damage Repair (ADR) Kit which is capable of creating useable landing surfaces by new construction or repair of existing facilities. The ADR Kit uses modern development in construction equipment and materials, is easily deployable, flexible enough to work in all geographic locations and environments, and can quickly repair craters and spalls of all sizes. It also includes the High Mobility Engineer Excavator (HMEE) which is a self-deployable excavation system with attachments to execute a wide range of mobility, counter-mobility, general engineering and survivability missions.
Family of Material Handling Equipment (FMHE) line is a roll-up line that provides for the replacement and Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) of Marine Corps MHE such as forklifts, cranes, and container handlers. This budget line item also includes funding for equipment such as the Light Capability Rough Terrain Forklift (LCRTF), Hydraulic Excavator (HYEX), Extendable Boom Forklift Modernization (EBFL-M), Rough Terrain Container Handler (RTCH) SLEP and the Tractor, Rubber Tires, and Articulated Steering, Multiple Purpose (TRAM) SLEP.
Command Support Equipment - Funds life cycle replacement of industrial equipment and systems with unit cost of $250K or greater to support the operations and mission of United States Marine Corps ground bases, air stations and districts. Examples include equipment such as open water spill equipment, warehouse conveyor systems, power generators and recycling systems. Beginning in FY21, Command Support Equipment is realigned from BLI 6544 Family of Construction Equipment to BLI 6438 Physical Security Equipment.
Garrison Mobile Engineer Equipment (GMEE) - The Garrison Mobile Engineering Equipment (GMEE) program is a centrally-managed program for the procurement of commercial construction and engineering equipment such as graders, backhoes, cranes and other construction equipment. It provides logistical support for facilities and road maintenance, force protection barrier construction and airfield engineering.
Material Handling Equipment (MHE) - The Material Handling Equipment (MHE) program is a centrally-managed program for the procurement of a portfolio of replacement equipment such as forklifts, warehouse cranes and platform trucks, to include Rough Terrain Container Handler (RTCH).
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
Beginning in FY 2021, Command Support Equipment is realigned from BLI 6544 Family of Construction Equipment to BLI 6438 Physical Security Equipment.
FY 2019: $59.909M (ACTIVE: $57.627M/RESERVE: $2.282M)
Family of Construction Equipment - $11.018M (ACTIVE: $9.739M/RESERVE: $1.279M): Funding procured the Airfield Damage Repair (ADR) Kits and Integrated Logistics Support for the Family of Construction Equipment programs. The ADR kit is capable of creating expedient repairs to useable landing surfaces by new construction or repair of existing facilities. ADR Kit(s) have the capability to support repairs for (6) 10-foot diameter concrete craters and (15) 10-foot diameter asphalt craters as well as 45 spalls. It will also fund the High Mobility Engineer Excavator (HMEE) which is a self-deployable excavation system with attachments to execute a wide range of mobility, counter-mobility, general engineering and survivability missions.
Family of Material Handling Equipment - $32.440M (ACTIVE: $31.437M/RESERVE: $1.003M): Funding procured Rough Terrain Container Handlers (RTCH) and additional All-Terrain Crane (ATC/MAC-50) SLEP to replace non-operational forklifts and modernization efforts, required to support the operation and mission of the Operational Forces and Contingency Operations.
Material Handling Equipment - $1.938M: Funds procured a portfolio of warehouse tractors, narrow aisle forklifts (4,000 to 20,000 lbs.), warehouse cranes and platform trucks to include Container Handlers to recapitalize over-aged equipment needed for loading, unloading, and movement of supplies at designated ports, warehouses, passenger/cargo terminals and landfills to better support the operation and mission of the USMC Bases and Stations. Additionally, funds procured equipment used to maintain ranges and fight wild-land fires.
Garrison Mobile Engineering Equipment - $14.122M: Funds procured commercial engineering equipment to recapitalize non-operational and over-aged light, medium or heavy duty tractors, road and runway sweepers, loaders, excavators, bulldozers, and scrapers that improved the readiness for necessary equipment used for construction and maintenance of roads, improvements and maintenance of facilities, ranges, training areas, air fields and maintain landfills to better support the operation and mission of the USMC Bases and Stations. Engineer equipment procured for California Bases and Station will comply with mandates California Air Resource Board (CARB), to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality. Non-compliance results in fines of $10k per day, per vehicle.
Command Support Equipment - $0.391M: Funds procured Open Water Spill Response boat for MCAS Cherry Point, NC.
FY 2020: $35.622M (ACTIVE: $33.287M/RESERVE: $2.335M)
Family of Construction Equipment - $11.630M (ACTIVE: $10.320M/RESERVE: $1.310M): Funds continue to procure the High Mobility Engineer Excavator (HMEE) which is a self-deployable excavation system with attachments to execute a wide range of mobility, counter-mobility, general engineering and survivability missions. Funding increased from FY19 to FY20 by $0.612M due to accelerating the procurement of the High Mobility Engineer Excavator (HMEE).
Family of Material Handling Equipment - $15.233M (ACTIVE: $14.208M/RESERVE: $1.025M): Funds procure the All-Terrain Crane (MAC-50) as well as Rough Terrain Container Handlers (RTCH) SLEP to replace non-operational forklifts and modernization efforts, required to support the operation and mission of the Operational Forces and Contingency Operations. Funding decreased from FY19 to FY20 by $17.707M due to a reduction of production quantities of the ATC All-Terrain Crane (MAC-50) and RTCH SLEP as well as Technical Manuals and Integrated Logistics Support being completed in FY20.
Material Handling Equipment (MHE) - $2.535M: Funds procure a portfolio of warehouse tractors, narrow aisle forklifts (4,000 to 20,000 lbs.), warehouse cranes and platform trucks to include Container Handlers to recapitalize over-aged equipment needed for loading, unloading, and movement of supplies at designated ports, warehouses, passenger/cargo terminals and landfills to better support the operation and mission of the USMC Bases and Stations. Additionally, funds will procure equipment used to maintain ranges, training areas and fight wild-land fires. Funding increased from FY19 to FY20 by $0.597M to recapitalize the MHE fleet required to reduce the over-aged replacement backlog, improve material readiness, and support the operation and mission of the USMC Bases and Stations.
Garrison Mobile Engineering Equipment - $5.788M: Funds procure commercial engineering equipment to recapitalize non-operational and over-aged light, medium or heavy duty tractors, road and runway sweepers, loaders, excavators, bulldozers, and scrapers that will improve the readiness for necessary equipment used for construction and maintenance of roads, improvements and maintenance of facilities, and maintain landfills to better support the operation and mission of the USMC Bases and Stations. Engineer equipment procured for California Bases and Station will comply with mandates California Air Resource Board (CARB), to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality. Non-compliance results in fines of $10k per day, per vehicle.
Command Support Equipment - $0.436M: Funding supports life cycle replacement of warehouse conveyor system MCB Camp Lejeune, NC.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $19.305M (ACTIVE: $16.924M /RESERVE: $2.381M)
Family of Construction Equipment - $6.275M (ACTIVE: $4.939M/RESERVE: $1.336M): Will continue to fund the procurement of the Airfield Damage Repair (ADR) Kits and Integrated Logistics Support for the Family of Construction Equipment programs. The ADR kit is capable of creating expedient repairs to useable landing surfaces by new construction or repair of existing facilities. ADR Kit(s) have the capability to support repairs for (6) 10-foot diameter concrete craters and (15) 10-foot diameter asphalt craters as well as 45 spalls. It will also fund the High Mobility Engineer Excavator (HMEE) which is a self-deployable excavation system with attachments to execute a wide range of mobility, counter-mobility, general engineering and survivability missions. Funding decreased from FY20 to FY21 by $5.355M due to this funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
Family of Material Handling Equipment - $6.582M (ACTIVE: $5.537M/RESERVE: $1.045M): Funds will continue to procure the All-Terrain Crane (ATC/MAC-50) as well as Rough Terrain Container Handlers (RTCH) SLEP to replace non-operational forklifts and modernization efforts, required to support the operation and mission of the Operational Forces and Contingency Operations. Funding decreased from FY20 to FY21 by $8.651M due to a reduction of production quantities of the ATC All-Terrain Crane (MAC-50) and RTCH SLEP as well as Technical Manuals and Integrated Logistics Support being completed in FY21. Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.
Material Handling Equipment (MHE) - $2.087M: Funds will procure a portfolio of warehouse tractors, narrow aisle forklifts (4,000 to 20,000 lbs.), warehouse cranes and platform trucks to include Container Handlers to recapitalize over aged equipment needed for loading, unloading, and movement of supplies at designated ports, warehouses, passenger/cargo terminals and landfills to better support the operation and mission of the USMC Bases and Stations. Funds will also procure equipment used to maintain ranges, training areas and fight wild land fires. Funding decrease from FY20 to FY21 by $0.448M due to funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy
Garrison Mobile Engineering Equipment - $4.361M: Funds will be used to procure commercial engineering equipment in order to recapitalize non-operational, absent and over aged light, medium or heavy duty tractors, road and runway sweepers, loaders, excavators, bulldozers, and scrapers that will improve the readiness for the installation. The necessity for equipment used for construction and maintenance of roads, improvements and maintenance of facilities, and maintain landfills are used to better support the operation and mission of the USMC Bases and Stations. Engineer equipment procured for California Bases and Station will comply with mandates California Air Resource Board (CARB), to reduce greenhouse gas emissions over the coming decade while improving air quality. Non compliance results in fines of $10k per day, per vehicle. Funding decrease from FY20 to FY21 by $1.427 due funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy
Command Support Equipment - $0: A decrease of $0.436M from FY20 to FY21 is due to Command Support Equipment realignment from BLI 6544 Family of Construction Equipment to BLI 6438 Physical Security Equipment. Beginning in FY21, Command Support Equipment is realigned from BLI 6544 Family of Construction Equipment to BLI 6438 Physical Security Equipment. Funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
The Family of Ultra-light Tactical Vehicle (FULTV), which consists of the Utility Task Vehicle (UTV) and the future Ultra-light Tactical Vehicle (ULTV), provides operational capabilities for both infantry logistics and long-range surveillance and reconnaissance missions in support of distributed heliborne operations. The vehicles are transportable in the V-22, CH53E and CH53F tilt selected rotary and fixed wing aircraft. The FULTV vehicles mitigate the infantry and reconnaissance battalion support gaps, with the ability to operate in remote, rural regions where currently fielded ground mobility platforms may be unsuitable due to size, weight, and transportability concerns.
The UTV is a part of the family of vehicles that supports the Fleet Marine Forces by providing infantry and reconnaissance battalions with a reliable, easily maintained, inexpensive vehicle that supports the range of military operations (ROMO) including distributed operations (DO), littoral operation in a contested environment (LOCE), expeditionary advanced based operations (EABO), and Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief (HADR).
Efforts are being planned to replace the UTV with the Ultra-light Tactical Vehicle (ULTV). The replacement vehicle will leverage technology upgrades to improve the operational capabilities for both infantry logistics and long-range intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance missions, as well as other designated missions in support of distributed heliborne operations. The desired outcomes from ULTV employment include but are not limited to, a lighter, faster, more maneuverable and more resilient force, increased ability to operate and be sustained in austere environments, reduced operational risk through reduced logistics footprint and threat exposure, and an increased autonomy and tactical mobility, particularly at the company-level and below.
The FULTV line item will provide for the implementation of engineering change proposals, safety initiatives, and quality design resolutions to fielded UTVs. This hands-on method ensures proper in-service management and vehicle sustainment while allowing the program office to develop and implement improvements as needed to respond to evolving requirements of the Marine Corps that affect vehicle reliability, safety, availability and readiness. The ULTVs will begin to replace the UTVs in FY22, which is a change from the FY20 request, which provided for procurement beginning in FY21. Safety and reliability modifications are planned throughout the life of the FULTV's to ensure maximum readiness as vehicles age.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $0.606M
Funding provided product improvements to the centrally managed UTV fleet for safety and reliability issues and engineering change proposals. The funds supported the associated update of the technical documentation upon modification of the vehicles.
FY 2020: $0.647M Funding provides product improvement to the centrally managed UTV fleet for safety and reliability issues and engineering change proposals like wheel well protection. These engineering change proposals will improve operational readiness by reducing failure rates associated with the mentioned safety and reliability issues.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $0.678M Funding provides product improvement to the centrally managed UTV fleet for safety and reliability issues and engineering change proposals like high clearance trailing arms and control arms. These engineering change proposals will improve operational readiness by reducing failure rates associated with the mentioned safety and reliability issues.
The increase of $0.031M will be used for additional engineering change proposals required to ensure vehicle safety, reliability and enhanced performance associated with the aging UTV fleet.

proc:Name.footnote: UTV ECP modifications will support the remaining 104 vehicles that will not be replaced until FY23.

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
This budget line item includes various procurements such as engineering efforts, engineering change proposals, modifications, and other related items less than $5 million each.
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) Program provides a comprehensive approach to extend the useful life on Marine Corps tactical ground and ground support equipment. The CPAC Program Office is responsible for the governance, oversight and management of both preventive and corrective corrosion control encompassing Acquisition Engineering, Material Development, Corrosion Service Teams, and Corrosion Repair Facility activities. The Consolidated CPAC Program provides a total lifecycle solution focused on Total Ownership Cost reduction and improved readiness.
Engineer Mods and Tool Kits funds critical improvements to various pieces of equipment by enhancing their current capabilities and expanding protection from direct and indirect fire by providing specific tool kits, including the specific chest or case to store and transport the tools, to perform specific missions assigned to engineer units, such as carpentry, grubbing or clearing areas with pioneer type tools, destruction/demolition, masonry, electrical (base camp support), plumbing, etc. including (but not limited to) Construction Shop Kit, Pioneer Platoon Kit, Pioneer Squad Kit, Carpenter Kit, Mason Kit, and tactical weld shop upgrades.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) provides Marine Corps Operating Forces with a fully intermodal transport capability emphasizing dimensional standardization and International Organization for Standardization compatibility. This family of containers includes the Palletized Container (PALCON), Quadruple Container (QUADCON), Quadruple Container with Roll-up door (QUADCON RUD) and Joint Modular Intermodal Container (JMIC). PALCONs and JMICs replace prefabricated wooden mount boxes and flat box pallets. The Joint Modular Intermodal Container (JMIC) provides efficient, seamless, and visible movement of supplies and unit equipment throughout the transportation and distribution systems. All containers support the storage and movement of organizational property and consumable supplies; provide field, garrison and shipboard warehousing; and facilitate ship-to-shore movement.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) is a family of systems line that contains purification, storage, distribution, hygiene, and test systems. This capability is necessary to provide safe and potable water to Marines in expeditionary environments. The family contains individual Table of Allowance Material Control Numbers which supports MAGTF operations by providing all aspects of land-based water support to include analysis, purification, reuse, storage, transfer and dispensing. The line contains items such as the Tactical Water Purification System (TWPS), Lightweight Water Purification System (LWPS), Expeditionary Water Distribution System (EWDS), Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS), Individual Water Purification System (IWPS), Forward Area Water Point Supply System, Pump Unit Set, Containerized Batch Laundry, Shower Systems, Gray Water Recycling, as well as all the various water supply support and analysis components and equipment including Six Container (SIXCON) Pump and Tank Modules, Nozzles, Interconnection Sets, Water Packaging Components, 3k/5k/25k Tanks, Hypocholorination Units, Water Quality Analysis Sets.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $13.711M (Active: $13.201M/Reserve: $0.510M)
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.885M: The consolidated CPAC program currently monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets. FY19 funding continues to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy. The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs. Procurement funding is also used for the fielding and replacement of various personal property/collateral equipment, and highly specialized real property installed equipment such as, but not limited to, compressors, blast booths, aging sanding and painting related equipment and hazardous waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I Marine Expeditionary Force, (I MEF), II MEF, and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii).
Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $7.476M (Active: $7.297M/Reserve: $0.179M): Additional funding provides upgrades to Modified-Full Width Mine Plows (M-FWMP), Field Service Representative (FSR) support and Tech Manual updates for the Assault Breacher Vehicle (ABV). Funds Improved Ribbon Bridge (IRB) Hinge modernization kit increasing the Reliability, Availability, and Maintainability (RAM) lowering future sustainment costs. Funds the Husky and Husky Mounted Detection System FSRs and the Instrument Set, Reconnaissance & Surveying Army system to maintain the Authority to Operate and keep pace with the Army system configuration. Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 Table of Authorized Material Control Numbers (TAMCNs). Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications. Funds Expeditionary Mobile Fuel Additization Capability (EMFAC) due to an Urgent Universal Needs Statement and Cooling and Refrigeration Expeditionary Kits (CREK) Foam Kit Assembly efforts.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.087M: Funds Joint Modular Intermodal Containers (JMIC). The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $4.263M (Active: $3.932M/Reserve: $0.331M): Funds procure PWPS and supports the procurement of a critically needed ECP for the M80 Water Heater.
FY 2020: $10.956M (Active: $10.585M/Reserve: $0.371M)
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.895M: The consolidated CPAC program currently monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets. FY20 funding continues to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy. The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs. Procurement funding is also used for the fielding and replacement of various personal property/collateral equipment, and highly specialized real property installed equipment such as, but not limited to, compressors, blast booths, aging sanding and painting related equipment and hazardous waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I Marine Expeditionary Force, (I MEF), II MEF, and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii).
Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $3.777M: Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 TAMCNs. Funding provides upgrades to mine plows; FSR support and Tech Manual (TM) updates for the Assault Breacher Vehicles (ABV); and Information Assurance (IA) support through Toughbook procurement and refresh. Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications. Decrease of $3.699M from FY19 to FY20 reflects the Marine Corps decision to reprogram to higher priorities.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.213M: Funds equipment such as Joint Modular Intermodal Containers. The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System. The increase in funding of $0.126M from FY19 to FY20 supports the plan to procure increased quantity of JMICs to meet AAO.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $5.071M (Active: $4.700M/Reserve: $0.371M): Funds will procure Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS). The increase in funding from FY19 to FY20 $0.808M supports procurement Platoon Water Purification System (PWPS) program of record.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation: $9.174M (Active: $8.798M/Reserve: $0.376M)
Corrosion Prevention and Control (CPAC) $0.913M: The consolidated CPAC program currently monitors the corrosion condition of 112,672 tactical ground and support equipment assets. FY21 funding continues to procure equipment protective covers designed to reduce and/or eliminate the negative effects of corrosion on USMC ground tactical and support equipment and the replacement of aging covers that have exceeded their life expectancy. The priority will be to provide equipment covers throughout the Operating Forces for equipment placed in an administrative staging program to mitigate the negative impacts of corrosion and decrease total ownership costs. Procurement funding is also used for the fielding and replacement of various personal property/collateral equipment, and highly specialized real property installed equipment such as, but not limited to, compressors, blast booths, aging sanding and painting related equipment and hazardous waste reduction equipment at the Corrosion Repair Facilities (CRFs) located at I Marine Expeditionary Force, (I MEF), II MEF, and III MEF (Okinawa and Hawaii). The increase of funding of $0.018M from FY20 to FY21 supports the continual increasing cost to replace specialized CPAC equipment.
Engineer Modification Kits (EMK) $3.463M: Continues to fund EMK for equipment armor installations, upgrades and safety concerns to prevent deterioration in Fleet readiness for Engineer Systems inventory consisting of over 47,000 end items associated to 120 TAMCNs. Supports modifications and upgrades to fielded legacy as well as newly fielded systems and provides quick response capability for meeting Fleet Marine Force sustainment for safety engineering, readiness, Quality Deficiency Report analysis, and legacy system modifications. Decrease of $0.314M from FY20 to FY21 reflects completion of Light Weight Demolition Device (LWDD) ECP.
Marine Corps Family of Containers (MCFC) $1.248M: Funds equipment such as Joint Modular Intermodal Containers. The JMIC is a collapsible, durable, reusable, easy-to-handle, modular packaging container that can operate world-wide, carried by various modes of transportation, and is envisioned for future use as a compliment to Navy seabasing efforts for automatic loading, handling, and storage systems. The JMIC will enable Marines to fulfill their mission by giving the unit commander the flexibility to configure a mobile/deployable container as necessary to meet the specific mission of the unit. It provides the operating forces with a fully intermodal transport capability which lays flat when not in use. The JMIC also provides a more effective use of storage areas in particularly limited storage facilities. Funding is required to meet the Approved Acquisition Objective outlined in the Total Force Structure Management System. The increase from the FY20 request to the FY21 request of $0.035M aligns to the procurement plan for JMIC.
Family of Expeditionary Water Systems (FEWS) $3.550M (Active: $3.174M/Reserve: $0.376M): Funds will procure Water Supply Support Components. The decrease in funding from FY20 to FY21 $1.521M reflects completion of various Water Supply Support Components and funding in this line item has been reprioritized while ensuring the Marine Corps continues to evolve toward a Force that is aligned with the National Defense Strategy

proc:LineItem.proc:Description:
Spares - Funds are required to reimburse the Navy Working Capital Fund for both repairable and consumable components at the time the initial spare parts package is released with the principal end item (PEI) to the Fleet Marine Force. This concept complies with the Navy Working Capital Fund funding of Initial Spares with reimbursement from the Procurement Account. Funds also provide for direct vendor support of the PEI delivery to the Fleet Marine Force.
This account has funding for the following programs: Secure Mobile Anti-Jam Reliable Tactical-Terminal (SMART-T), Tactical Remote Sensor System (TRSS), Intelligence Analysis System (IAS), Terrestrial Collection, LAV-Anti Tank System Program, LAV Reset Program, M1A1 Modification, Family of Material Handling Equipment (FMHE), Ground/Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR AN/TPS-80), RQ-21A Small Tactical UAS, General Purpose Tool and Test Systems (GPTTS), Amphibious Combat Vehicle Family of Vehicles (ACV FOV), and Training Simulation Support (TSS)/Training Devices.
proc:LineItem.proc:Justification:
FY 2019: $24.137M
ACV Family of Vehicles (FOV) BLI 2025: $6.145M provides for initial spares for communication suites, Driver's Vision Enhancer, Exportable Power, Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P), and Amphibious Remote Weapon Stations (ARWS). Initial spares for ACV FOV are procured commensurate with the end items they support based on lead time for procurement.
LAV Reset BLI 2038: $5.735M procures spares for direct vendor support required for the fielding of the Reset kits on the Light Armored Vehicle.
General Purpose Tool and Test Equipment BLI 4181: $0.174M supports reimbursement to the working capital funds for spares acquired and needed during test support.
AN/TPS-80 Ground Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR) BLI 4655: $11.611M provides spares funding to support Gallium Nitride (GaN) LRIP systems procured in FY18. FY19 Spares funding is required to procure the initial provisioning package to primarily support those GaN LRIP systems being procured in FY18 and fielded in FY20, as over 90 percent of the G/ATOR spares have a lead time exceeding 12 months. The spares funding increases ($0.194M) from FY18 to FY19 supporting the fielding of three (3) new systems in FY20 for a total of fifteen (15) G/ATOR systems fielded through FY20. Adequate sparing is essential so Marine Operational Forces will have the necessary repair parts to operate and maintain newly fielded G/ATOR Radar Systems and to avoid a significant risk of not meeting the program's important Key Performance Parameter (KPP) 8; Sustainment.
IAS BLI 4747: $0.160M of spares funding provides for direct vendor support of the principal end item (PEI) components delivery to the Fleet Marine Force.
Terrestrial Collection BLI 4747: $0.261M provides for purchase of equipment spares necessary to keep ground-based imagery collection and dissemination assets and sensor systems in operation, ensuring spares are available to the warfighter when breakage occurs to minimize equipment down-time.
Training Simulation Support (TSS)/Training Devices BLI 6532: $0.051M funds procurement of low density, minor (low cost) MAGTF ground training equipment, simulators and simulations to include devices such as medical training kits, climbing walls, weapons models and mockups that enhance basic occupational and combat skills across the wide spectrum of tactics, techniques, procedures and proficiency.
FY 2020: $33.470M
ACV FOV BLI 2025: $13.954M will provide for initial spares for communication suites, Driver's Vision Enhancer, Exportable Power, Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P), and Amphibious Remote Weapon Stations (ARWS). Initial spares for ACV 1.1 are procured commensurate with the end items they support based on lead time for procurement.
LAV Reset Program BLI 2038: $5.883M funding will provide spares for direct vendor support required for the fielding of the Reset kits on the Light Armored Vehicle.
General Purpose Tool and Test Equipment BLI 4181: $0.178M procures equipment spares for newly fielded mechanical test equipment, electrical test equipment, and tool sets and kits. Funding ensures critical spares are available to the warfighter when breakage occurs to minimize equipment down time.
AN/TPS-80 Ground Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR) BLI 4655: $13.235M provides spares funding to support the Lot One Full Rate Production (FRP) systems procured in FY19. FY20 spares funding is required to procure the initial provisioning package (IPP) which consists of over one hundred assemblies/parts with over 60 critical items to include Five-Axis Motor Controllers and Dual Leaf Assemblies. Funding will primarily support the Lot One FRP systems being procured in FY19 and fielded in FY22, as over 90 percent of the G/ATOR spares have a lead time exceeding 12 months. Thus, the FY20 spares funding will obligate in FY20 and deliver Spares in FY22 to align with end item systems deliveries. The funding in FY20 is also required for the decentralized distribution of initial spares from LOGCOM to the Repair Inventory Points at each Marine Expeditionary Force, as required. Additionally, adequate sparing is essential so Fleet Marine Forces will have the necessary repair parts to operate and maintain newly fielded G/ATOR Radar Systems and to avoid placing the program at significant risk of not meeting its important Key Performance Parameter (KPP) 8 of Sustainment.
Intelligence Analysis System (IAS) BLI 4767: $0.166M of spares funding will provide for direct vendor support of the principal end item (PEI) components delivery to the Fleet Marine Force.
Family of Material Handling Equipment (FMHE) BLI 6544: $0.054M provides for the replacement and Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) of Marine Corps MHE such as forklifts, cranes, and container handlers. This budget line item also includes funding for equipment such as the Light Capability Rough Terrain Forklift (LCRTF), Hydraulic Excavator (HYEX), Extendable Boom Forklift Modernization (EBFL-M), Rough Terrain Container Handler (RTCH) SLEP and the Tractor, Rubber Tires, and Articulated Steering, Multiple Purpose (TRAM) SLEP.
FY 2021 Base Appropriation Request: $27.295M
The primary reason for the $6.175M decrease between FY20 and FY21 is due to the Spares procurement for LAV Reset was completed in FY20.
ACV FOV BLI 2025: $13.557M will provide for initial spares for communication suites, Driver's Vision Enhancer, Exportable Power, Joint Battle Command-Platform (JBC-P), and Amphibious Remote Weapon Stations (ARWS). Initial spares for ACV FOV are procured commensurate with the end items they support based on lead time for procurement. The decrease of $0.397M between FY20 and FY21 is attributed to decreased requirement for Contractor Furnished Deployment spares.
General Purpose Tool and Test Equipment BLI 4181: $0.180M will procure equipment spares for newly fielded mechanical test equipment, electrical test equipment, and tool sets and kits. Funding ensures critical spares are available to the warfighter when breakage occurs to minimize equipment down time.
Family of Material Handling Equipment (FMHE) BLI 6544: $0.052M will provide for the replacement and Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) of Marine Corps MHE such as forklifts, cranes, and container handlers. This budget line item also includes funding for equipment such as the Light Capability Rough Terrain Forklift (LCRTF), Hydraulic Excavator (HYEX), Extendable Boom Forklift Modernization (EBFL-M), Rough Terrain Container Handler (RTCH) SLEP and the Tractor, Rubber Tires, and Articulated Steering, Multiple Purpose (TRAM) SLEP.
AN/TPS-80 Ground Air Task Oriented Radar (G/ATOR) BLI 4655: $13.506M will provide spares funding to support the Lot Two Full Rate Production (FRP) systems procured in FY20. FY21 spares funding is required to procure the initial provisioning package (IPP) which consists of over one hundred assemblies/parts with over 60 critical items to include Five-Axis Motor Controllers and Dual Leaf Assemblies. Funding will primarily support the Lot Two FRP systems being procured in FY20 and fielded in FY23, as over 90 percent of the G/ATOR spares have a lead time exceeding 12 months. Thus, the FY21 spares funding will obligate in FY21 and deliver Spares in FY23 to align with end item systems deliveries. The spares funding increase of $0.271M will support the fielding of eight (8) new systems beginning in FY23 for a total of twenty five (25) G/ATOR systems fielded through FY23. The funding in FY21 is also required for the decentralized distribution of initial spares from LOGCOM to the Repair Inventory Points at each Marine Expeditionary Force, as required. Additionally, adequate sparing is essential so Fleet Marine Forces will have the necessary repair parts to operate and maintain newly fielded G/ATOR Radar Systems and to avoid placing the program at significant risk of not meeting its important Key Performance Parameter (KPP) 8 of Sustainment.

proc:EndItem.proc:Name: Amphibious Combat Vehicle Family of Vehicles
